    When a patient who has recently recovered from a Yang disease experiences vomiting without any other cause, this is due to residual heat in the stomach. It is advisable to use either Bamboo Leaf and Gypsum Decoction or Tangerine Peel and Bamboo Shavings Decoction. Generally, when a patient has Yang symptoms accompanied by vomiting, this indicates a combined illness; the vomiting suggests that the disease has progressed inward, and it is not simply a Yang condition. I recall a case where someone initially had Yang symptoms and persistent vomiting; when treated with warming prescriptions, there was no effect. Knowing that the Yang condition had been resolved through sweating, it was appropriate to use cooling medications, as the vomiting was due to Yang symptoms, not a combination with the Yangming or Shaoyang; thus, the vomiting was caused by heat and warm medications were ineffective. I have also witnessed a case with significant vomiting from Yang symptoms; in such instances, it sufficed to release the exterior without using emetic herbs. Additionally, there was a case where upon onset of the illness, with clear Yang symptoms and vomiting, everyone in the household displaying similar symptoms responded effectively to eight doses of Stomach Nourishing Decoction. At that time, the movement of Qi naturally aligned this way, indicating a case of cold damage with miscellaneous diseases, which should not be treated according to the regular principles of cold damage. If vomiting occurs with thirst due to summer heat, it is recommended to use Cold Agastache Decoction or Five-Ingredient Powder, along with summer relief pills.[50p]
    For persistent vomiting, use loquat leaf powder mixed with reed roots, and swallow with the herb Dan. If vomiting is accompanied by phlegm, take an antidote for summer heat, like the Xiao Banxia Fuling Decoction or a summer relief drink.

    For injury from alcohol, with nausea and vomiting of stagnant liquor, dizziness, and severe headaches, a remedy such as the Chonghe Decoction is appropriate, or the Banxia Fuling Decoction, or the Lijiang Decoction with seven parts of dried kudzu. Alternatively, mix powdered remedies with the Lijiang Decoction or the Sui Pi Drink.

    For food-related issues causing chest distension, nausea, sour regurgitation, bad egg-smelling belching, and aversion to food, with headache, fever, and chills—symptoms resembling a cold but without body aches—use the Zhongtong Decoction with one qian of cardamom or take Hongyuanzizi or Xiao Qixiangyuanzh with it.

    If overeating leads to food stagnation, causing nausea at the smell of food, use the Erchen Decoction with one qian of cardamom. If it doesn't improve, add half a qian of clove or use the Zhongtong Decoction with one qian of cardamom and ten pieces of clove. For severe continuous vomiting, if bowel movements are ineffective, apply the Zhishi Banxia Decoction with one qian of cardamom and half a qian of white cardamom, with a focus on throat soothing pills.[51p]

    Ming Medical Miscellany by Wang Lun

    Vomit and Swallow Sourness

    If there is phlegm-fire existing, with the chest and diaphragm feeling obstructed, causing sourness in the throat and difficulty in breathing, and if there are symptoms of vomiting and swallowing sourness, or if there is alcohol accumulation leading to diarrhea and pain, all of this is due to damp-heat. The treatment involves taking Zhi Zhu Pills with the addition of one tael each of grilled Huang Lian with ginger juice, roasted Bai Shao Yao, and Chen Pi, along with five qian each of gypsum and licorice, one qian each of sand-reducing agent and wood fragrance, and four qian of Chuan Xiong.

    Note: Vomiting sourness and swallowing sourness differ somewhat. Vomiting sourness occurs due to heat arising from dampness; swallowing sourness arises from internal deficiency and stagnation of heat. Both belong to the category of spleen and stomach deficiency-cold, being the latter stages of affliction. Thus, the "Inner Canon" refers to fire concerning the manifestation of the illness. Dongyuan sees gastric cold as addressing the root cause of the illness. For all who suffer from this, one should first distinguish between vomiting and swallowing, and the treatment should primarily focus on tonifying the root essence. If cold and cool herbs are used, they will further harm stomach qi, leading to a blend of true and false conditions. If the spleen qi is deficient and food and drink cannot be processed, resulting in turbidity not descending, then one should use Liu Jun Zi Decoction to primarily tonify the spleen and stomach, with a slight addition of Yue Ju Pills for clearing. Therefore, Mr. Dongyuan states that if the evil heat does not affect the grain, mistakenly recognizing it as true heat and recklessly using cold and cool herbs will inevitably lead to a deterioration of the condition.[52p]
    Vomit Gate

    Medical Introduction (Ming, Li Zhan)

    Separation of Wet and Dry Vomiting

    Wet vomiting has sound and material; it occurs after eating. Dry vomiting is empty and has no material, both belong to conditions where Yangming Qi and Blood are diseased, hence vomiting is considered more severe than regurgitation. Heat-induced vomiting results in a bitter mouth, irritability, thirst, rapid pulse, warmth in the palms, while cold vomiting presents with headaches, fullness in the chest, cold extremities, and spitting froth; a slow pulse may accompany retching, and there are variations in clinical presentation.

    In cases of damp vomiting, there is a transmission of superficial pathogens to the interior, causing the internal Qi to counterflow, thus many cases of overlapping patterns have abundant vomiting. When the three Yangs are febrile, they are treated with Xiao Chai Hu Tang plus fresh ginger. For fullness in the chest accompanied by afternoon tidal fever, add Mangxiao. If vomiting is persistent and there are bowel issues, use Da Chai Hu Tang. For abundant vomiting indicating Yangming patterns but with a thin stomach unsuitable for purging, use Gan Ju Tang. For irritability and thirst, if vomiting precedes thirst, this indicates a desire for relief, treat with Zhu Ling Tang. If thirst occurs before vomiting, indicating water retention, use Chi Fu Ling Tang. If vomiting occurs immediately upon drinking water, apply Wu Ling San. For virtual thirst, utilize Bamboo Leaf and Gypsum Decoction with ginger juice, or use Zhi Shi Tang. For upper heat and lower cold vomiting, apply Huang Lian Tang. If there is cold in the stomach with diarrhea, cold extremities, and no thirst, use Li Zhong Tang minus Atractylodes with added ginger juice, or use Zheng Qi Tang with ginger juice.

    Regarding the three conditions of Shaoyin: if there is cold drink above causing vomiting and spitting of foam, or if there is vomiting with diarrhea and thirst, treat with Si Ni San plus fresh ginger. If the pulse is deep, or there is coughing or palpitations along with water Qi, use Zhen Wu Tang minus Aconite with added ginger juice.[53p]
    For cold hands and feet with warm feelings in the chest, wanting to vomit but unable to, feeling frustrated and helpless, use half-dried ginger juice with pinellia decoction. For those who are weak after sweating, use dried ginger, scutellaria, and ginseng soup. If after sweating, water or grains cannot be taken, it is critical; a small pinellia decoction can relieve this. If there is warm toxin causing vomiting, along with a feeling of heaviness in the heart and skin rashes, and if there is water evidence and vomiting, first comes the vomiting and confusion. Vomiting pus and blood indicates a reversed foul odor trying to push upwards; if it is expelled completely, one can recover.

    For dry retching, heat in the stomach combines with grain qi rising, causing a feeling of blockage in the heart, hence one vomits with nothing to expel, and cannot eat; use Huanglian Detoxifying Decoction. For dry retching without sweat in a Taiyang condition, it indicates wind-evil obstructing upwards; use Guizhi Decoction. If in a Taiyang and Yangming combined illness, there is no diarrhea but only vomiting or dry retching, it indicates blocked internal qi rising without descending; use Gegen Decoction. For cold stomach and dried fluids with dry retching and thirst, use Lizhong Decoction.

    In a Shaoyin condition with three symptoms: dry retching, diarrhea with weak pulse, use Baitong Decoction. For internal cold and external heat with a faint pulse about to fail, use Tongmai Sijue Decoction. If diarrhea does not stop, and there is restlessness with reversed qi and no pulse, use Baitong with pig bile decoction.

    For Jueyin headaches with dry retching and vomiting phlegm, or self-induced diarrhea, feeling cold and restless, use Sanwei Shenyu Decoction. If there is a feeling of chest tightness that seems like shortness of breath but isn’t, seems like vomiting but isn’t, or seems like hiccuping but isn’t, feeling confused and helpless, use half-dried ginger juice with pinellia decoction or small and large tangerine peel decoction.[54p]
    Vomiting with Fishy and Sour Odors

    Vomiting is silent with no objects present; it occurs immediately after eating. Danxi associates this with blood disorders of the Yang, but it is the stomach that primarily governs it. Vomiting that is fishy and foul indicates cold, while sour and pungent suggests heat, necessitating treatment alongside nausea. If vomiting is accompanied by weakness and pain in the legs, it indicates foot qi issues. Weak pulse during vomiting, with beneficial urination and slight fever accompanied by cold extremities indicates extreme deficiency, which is difficult to treat.[55p]
    There are distinct conditions of cold and hot qi in relation to food.

    For cold in the stomach, symptoms include clear vomiting, cold extremities, and vomiting after prolonged food intake. Treatment includes Er Chen Tang (Two Efficients Decoction) with added ginger and cinnamon. In severe cases, add zingerone and aconite, or use clove and pinellia pills. For heat in the stomach, symptoms include a flushed face, hot extremities, and immediate vomiting after eating. Treatment involves Er Chen Tang with ginger and stir-fried scutellaria, lotus, and gardenia; if symptoms are severe, slightly add betel nut and aquilaria. For stomach pain, add ginger juice, or use kudzu and bamboo shavings soup, or modified tangerine peel and bamboo soup, or Xiao Chai Hu Tang (Minor Bupleurum Decoction) with bamboo shavings.

    If constantly vomiting clear water with cold phlegm rising, it is due to heat in the spleen. For treatment, use Er Chen Tang with equal parts of atractylodes, white peony, cimicifuga, stir-fried scutellaria, gardenia, shen qu, barley sprouts, and dry ginger, either in pill or decoction form.

    For cases of qi vomiting, where qi clashes cause chest pain, and immediate thirst follows vomiting, the treatment should focus on descending qi and harmonizing the middle. Use Liu Jun Zi Tang (Six Gentles Decoction) with added aquilaria, patchouli, platycodon, and loquat leaves, or use Qi Qi Tang (Seven Qi Decoction).

    For vomiting due to middle jiao disturbance, where food accumulates and gas is involved, treatment may include pain followed by vomiting or vice versa. Use equal parts of aquilaria and betel nut, finely ground, and take it mixed. For moving qi, use Zi Chen Wan (Purple Sink Pill). For digesting accumulation, apply common Ping Wei San (Calm the Stomach Powder), or Er Chen Tang with green skin, sand seeds, white cardamom, hawthorn, and shen qu adjusted accordingly.[56p]

    Cold in the Lower Jiao

    The condition of retching in the lower jiao is due to cold. Vomiting in the morning after breakfast and vomiting in the evening after dinner will lead to clear and smooth urination and constipation for a prolonged period. This is due to the yin qi being obstructed and not harmonizing with the yang. The treatment should warm the cold and unblock the secretions, supplemented with middle jiao herbs for reconciliation. This includes formulas like Fuzi Lizhong Tang, Muxiang Yunqi San paired with Lizhong Tang, Sini Tang, Dinghu San, Guding Bantang, Yangzheng Dan, and Guban Liudan Wan.

    No Purging

    In cases of vomiting, purging is generally not advisable. Symptoms such as craving cold, feeling irritable and thirsty, and severe chest and abdominal pain with constipation indicate stagnation in the large and small intestines and bladder. For heat, Da Chaihu Tang may be used to purge, while for deficiency, a moistening treatment is recommended.

    Damp Phlegm Fire Water

    For vomiting due to excess phlegm and fire, modify Er Chen Tang by adding ginger-fried Qinghao. Alternatively, Xiaojiao Zhong Tang may serve as the principal remedy. If liver fire assaults the stomach, use Dan Huang Lian Wan or single Ren Zhongbai mixed with ginger juice for ingestion. In cases with phlegm dampness obstructing the spleen’s channels, resulting in nausea and the expulsion of clear fluids or resembling bean juice, use Weiling Tang with Banxia and Banna. If water is vomited with a feeling of discomfort in the heart, first thirsty then vomiting indicates the use of Chi Fu Ling Tang. If the vomiting occurs first then thirst develops, use Zhu Ling Tang. For immediate vomiting upon taking in water, use Wuling San.

    Pus, Blood, Wind, and Heat[57p]

    Foul odors from fish and meat lead to nausea and vomiting, mixed with saliva and blood. This purulent blood accumulates in the channels; hence, it is said that if a familial history of vomiting exists, and there is a gathering of pus, there is no need for treatment—the pus will resolve on its own. Use a double dose of the Four Substance Decoction with red Poria and Mu Dan Pi. If one's constitution is weak, use the Eight Treasure Decoction with Chen Pi.

    If the wind pathogen affects the stomach, causing unsettled sensations or sour water pooling without the ability to ingest food, do not switch to Jin Zheng Qi Powder, Mai Dong Decoction, or An Pi Pills, as this may aggravate the condition. Only if there is prolonged pain in the hypochondrium, do you dare to use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with Qing Pi, Shao Yao, Chai Hu, Sheng Ma, Chuan Xiong, sand ginger, and Shen Qu. For treating water heat, use the Xiao Chai Hu Decoction added with Qing Dai and ginger juice, and make steamed cakes into pills.

    For summer-related vomiting and thirst, use Huang Lian Xiang Ru San or Liu Yi San with sand ginger, or Pi Pa Ye San and Qian’s Bai Zhu San.

    For long-term illness with weak stomach Qi, unable to take in food and vomiting at the scent of food, use Si Wei Huo Ye Decoction or Si Jun Zi Tang with the removal of Poria and the addition of Xiang Fu, Ren Shen, and Qi. For chest tightness and shortness of breath, use the Tiao Zhong Yi Qi Decoction. If there is weak stomach cold phlegm leading to vomiting, increase the Ban Xia Decoction.

    If there are worms causing frequent nausea, stomach pain, and expelling clear water, while temporarily stopping with food intake but worsening with hunger, this indicates the presence of roundworms in the stomach. Use Er Chen Decoction with Ku Lian Gen, Shi Jun Zi, Bai Zhu, and Wu Mei. Alternatively, one may use a mixture of tin ash and areca nut in equal parts, with rice drink for adjusting consumption. If there is vomiting resembling vegetable juice, it leads to death; this is sudden vomiting and is not due to the stomach turning over.[58p]
    Treatise on Vomiting

    According to ancient practitioners, vomiting belongs to the Yangming category, which is characterized by abundant qi and blood, thus accompanied by sound and material (vomit); both blood and qi are affected. Vomiting (tui) belongs to the Taiyang category, characterized by abundant blood and little qi, hence it involves material (vomit) without sound; this indicates a blood issue. Hiccuping (huè) belongs to the Shaoyang category, defined by abundant qi and limited blood, resulting in sound without material; this is indicative of a qi issue. Dongyuan states that both vomiting and hiccuping arise from a deficiency of the spleen and stomach, either from the invasion of cold or from diet-related harm, leading to upwards reversal and an inability to retain food.

    The elder Jie Gu discusses three causes of qi accumulation due to cold: The upper jiao is located at the stomach area, communicates with celestial qi, and is responsible for receiving but not expelling; the middle jiao is at the center, connects to celestial qi above and terrestrial qi below, and governs the digestion of food; the lower jiao, beneath the navel, connects to terrestrial qi, and is responsible for expulsion rather than reception. Therefore, if vomiting occurs in the upper jiao, it is always caused by qi, which corresponds to the yang of heaven. Its pulse is superficial and strong. The symptoms often involve vomiting shortly after eating, with a thirst for water; treatment should focus on descending qi and harmonizing the center. For the middle jiao, vomiting is due to accumulation, with both yin and yang involved, where qi and food interact. Its pulse is superficial and wiry. Symptoms may involve pain preceding vomiting or vomiting preceding pain; the remedy should aim to eliminate accumulation and harmonize qi. For the lower jiao, vomiting arises from cold, corresponding to earth.[59p]
    The pulse is large and slow. The symptoms include vomiting food eaten in the morning by evening, vomiting food eaten in the evening by morning, clear and smooth urination, and difficulty in bowel movements. The treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction and warming the cold pathogen. Later generations further classified the conditions: if vomiting occurs immediately after food intake, it is called "retching"; if food is ejected shortly after swallowing, use a small Banxia decoction. If vomiting occurs as soon as the food is swallowed, it is termed "violent vomiting," meaning that the food is expelled immediately after being swallowed; use ginger and tangerine peel decoction. If vomiting occurs after eating is completed, it is referred to as "vomiting," meaning that vomiting follows the completion of eating, and the remedy is tangerine peel and Banxia decoction. If vomiting happens long after eating, it is called "reflux," as food has been in the stomach long enough that the stomach cannot separate pure from turbid and expels it again; use boiled Jinhua pills. If vomiting occurs after subsequent eating, it is termed "reversed stomach," meaning that food is retained after the first intake but is expelled on the second; it erupts from the stomach's outlet, use Yilao Zini pills. Vomiting breakfast by evening and dinner by morning indicates the accumulation of a day's worth of food, lasting as long as six hours before vomiting; this concerns the lower body illnesses, treated with Banxia, ginger, and rhubarb decoction. Among the above symptoms, the quicker the vomiting, the more it indicates issues in the upper body; the longer the vomiting, the more it suggests problems in the lower body. The interplay of yin and yang, deficiency and excess, makes it challenging to distinguish the true and false.[60p]
    The ancient method uses Banxia (Pinellia) and Shengjiang (ginger) as the primary agents. Only Dongyuan states that ginger can stop vomiting, but it addresses a condition of obstructed Qi due to excess in the exterior. If there is deficiency in the stomach and the Qi of grain does not flow, one should merely tonify the stomach to promote the flow of grain Qi. Therefore, if Xiao Banxia Decoction does not relieve the condition, taking Da Banxia Decoction will immediately bring relief.

    For those with cold symptoms, there is a preference for warmth and an aversion to cold, with cold limbs and a weak pulse. One may use Erling Decoction with cloves and roasted ginger, or Lichung Decoction with Zhishi. It is essential to take these medications cold, as cold intake prevents vomiting.

    If various medicines are ineffective, Hongdou Pills have remarkable results.

    For those with heat symptoms, there is a preference for coolness and an aversion to heat, with restlessness and a strong pulse. Use Erling Decoction with Huanglian (coptis), Zhizi (gardenia), Zhu Ru (bamboo shavings), Pi Pa Ye (loquat leaves), Ganhua (pueraria), Shengjiang (ginger), and Lu Gen (reed root juice).

    For Qi stagnation, with distension and fullness, add Zhishi (bitter orange), Chenxiang (aloeswood), and Muxiang (saussurea) to Erling Decoction.

    For phlegm-dampness, which occurs upon encountering cold, commonly referred to as “cold saliva,” first use Jiangsu Decoction to take down Ling Sha Dan, followed by Qi-regulating medications.

    For food stagnation, one must promote digestion, using Zhishi, Houpu, Cangzhu, Shenqu, Maiya, Shengjie (hawthorn), and Sharen.

    If vomiting occurs and the various medicines are ineffective, one must depend on heavy settling agents like Ling Sha Dan and Yangzheng Dan.[61p]
    When vomiting and the central qi is long deficient, one must use grains to harmonize it. It is advisable to use charred white rice, dried tangerine peel, poria cocos, pinellia, licorice, aged millet, job's tears, and glutinous rice powder, sipping on aged rice drink regularly. First induce vomiting, then purge, when the body is hot and the abdomen feels distended; this is called "leaky qi." This is due to wind damage in the upper burner, with pathogenic qi lodged within, treated with Mai Men Dong decoction. If there are no bowel movements and qi is stagnant, this is termed "running suckling," indicating excess heat in the lower burner, treated with ginseng decoction. For dry heaving and qi reversal, use equal parts tangerine peel and ginger. For nausea damaging the stomach, in cases of deficiency use ginseng, tangerine peel, poria, licorice, pinellia, and ginger; for excess use bitter orange peel, sand ginger, tangerine peel, pinellia, white cardamom, and patchouli. If the vomiting is bitter, the pathogen resides in the gallbladder, treated with coptis, licorice, ginger, tangerine peel, and Bupleurum. Vomiting sour is attributed to the liver; if accompanied by heat, use Zuo Jin Wan with white cardamom, ginger, bamboo shavings, and gardenia; if accompanied by cold, use Zuo Jin Wan with clove, dried ginger, white atractylodes, and agarwood. For vomiting clear water, this suggests a deficiency of qi, treated with Liu Jun Zi decoction with chi shi zhi. If expelling ascaris, the stomach is cold, treated with Li Zhong decoction adding five grains of Sichuan pepper and half an ounce of areca nut, and swallow black plum pills. Identify the causes clearly; match medicines to symptoms—do not adhere strictly to fixed patterns; only then can one respond to the endless variations.[62p]
    Discussion on Dry Heaving

    Dry heaving refers to the empty retching without any contents being expelled. Generally, this occurs when heat is present in the stomach along with the qi of grains, causing an upward surge of heat that results in a feeling of pressure and blockage under the heart. In cases of external deficiency where sweating leads to dry heaving, the treatment is Gui Zhi Tang, which governs spontaneous sweating. For less yin leading to diarrhea and dry heaving, the treatment is Sheng Jiang Tang, which addresses the diarrhea. If there’s spitting of saliva and foam with dry heaving associated with jueyin, the prescription is Wu Zhu Yu Tang, which governs the salivary foam. Once the pathogen departs, the vomiting will cease.

    There are also conditions related to water qi. If the exterior of the taiyang does not resolve, resulting in water qi beneath the heart with body heat and dry heaving, slight wheezing or spontaneous diarrhea may occur, treated with Xiao Qing Long Tang. If there’s no fever but only chills, side pain, coughing with diarrhea, and dry heaving, this too is related to water qi, treated with Shi Zao Tang. For dry heaving caused by cold drinks in the diaphragm, this pertains to shaoyin, treated with Si Ni Tang.

    In cases of cold damage with heat in the stomach alongside grain qi, causing the upward surge of heat without any contents—that is termed dry heaving—and it is necessary to differentiate between excess heat and water qi for treatment, which differs from the case of hiccups.

    After three to four days, if the pathogen transitions to the shaoyang with gallbladder involvement, resulting in chest and side pain, deafness, alternating chills and fever, bitterness in the mouth, and vomiting, feeling pulse on both yin and yang meridians reveals it is half exterior and half interior. Since the gallbladder has no pathway for discharge or intake, use Xiao Chai Hu Tang. There are three prohibitions in meridian treatment: sweating, purging, and vomiting. This is because yangming and taiyang meridians do not treat from the interior. The state of being half exterior and half interior with the yang intersecting in between is called shaoyang.[63p]
    On Vomiting

    Vomiting (ou) is when both sound and substance are expelled. Expectoration (tu) is when only substance is expelled without sound. Therefore, Zhang Zhongjing emphasizes "gan" to distinguish these, indicating that vomiting clearly involves matter. "Gan" signifies emptiness; thus, it is merely an empty retching without anything being expelled. However, both vomiting and expectoration involve matter being expelled; when compared, vomiting is more severe than expectoration. This is because a pathogenic influence strikes inward, causing the internal qi to rise counter to normal, hence the vomiting and the inability to retain water and food.

    In the case of gastric heat, the pulse is wiry and rapid, and there is thirst and discomfort in the mouth; for gastric cold, the pulse is wiry and slow, there is a reversal of cold, aversion to food, and mild bowel movements; in situations where there is water qi, one feels thirst first followed by vomiting, and experiences discomfort in the diaphragm; in the presence of pus and blood, there is a fishy sensation in the throat, with a rising and surging sensation; this does not require treatment, as vomiting out the pus will lead to self-healing. These four situations must not be confused. Generally speaking, if the pathogen is partly external and partly internal, there will be more vomiting, and vomiting can also occur due to heat in the interior.[64p]
    Therefore, the classics say: If there is much vomiting, even if there are signs of Yangming, it should not be forcefully treated, as the qi is counterflowing, and it has not yet recovered to be solid. If there is vomiting and a weak pulse, a smooth urination, and slight fever with signs of convulsion, it is difficult to treat due to severe deficiency and cold.

    If one feels nauseous after eating grains, it pertains to Yangming. If the condition worsens after taking decoction, it involves the upper jiao; one may use tangerine peel decoction or Xiao Chai Hu decoction. If there are symptoms of nausea, belching, or panting, with a muddled heart region, use major tangerine peel decoction.

    After sweating and purging, if the pulse is slow and there is vomiting, it indicates cold in the stomach, treated with Li Zhong Wan. After recovery, if there is fatigue and vomiting, use bamboo leaf and gypsum decoction with ginger juice added. If there has been repeated sweating and the food qi is obstructed, leading to immediate vomiting upon intake, use dried ginger, huang qin, huang lian, and ren shen decoction.

    If after sweating the water decoction cannot be ingested, it is called counterflow, treated with Ban Xia and Fu Ling decoction. The "Jin Kui" states: For all cases of vomiting where food does not go down, use Ban Xia decoction. If vomiting occurs with a slippery and rapid pulse, or if it is strong and feverish, use Mao Gen decoction.[65p]
    Xue Ji's Medical Case Study
    (Ming Dynasty, Xue Ji)

    Vomiting

    If there is deficiency of spleen and stomach qi, and vomiting with chest and diaphragm obstruction, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction to strengthen the spleen and generate original qi. If there has been excessive consumption of pungent and hot medicines, leading to vomiting and obstruction in the diaphragm, use the Four Gentlemen Decoction with Xiangfu and Danggui to enhance the spleen and suppress yin fire. If there is internal gastric fire preventing food intake, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with Qian and Lian to clear heat and nourish the stomach. If the patient vomits food after intake, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction plus Mu Xiang and Pao Jiang to warm the interior and strengthen the spleen. If qi-depleting medicines have been taken, leading to the absence of blood production and hard and dry stools, use the Four Gentlemen Decoction with Xiangfu and Danggui to nourish the spleen and generate blood. If fire reverses and obstructs upward, preventing food intake, use the Four Gentlemen Decoction with Zhi Mu and Huang Lian to clear heat and nourish the blood. If phlegm and fluids are blocking and preventing food intake, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with Mu Xiang and Zhi Mu to strengthen the spleen and resolve phlegm. If there is cold in the spleen and stomach preventing food intake, or if food enters but does not digest, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with Mu Xiang and Pao Jiang to warm and supplement the spleen and stomach. If one cannot avoid excessive sexual activity, indulgence in rich flavors, and fails to regulate diet, do not treat. Elderly patients with no blood should also not be treated.[66p]
    Causes of Vomiting Vary

    Yang Renzhai said: It is commonly known that vomiting occurs due to disharmony in the stomach's qi. However, there are various causes such as cold in the stomach, heat in the stomach, phlegm and fluid, retention of undigested food, intrusion of wind evil into the stomach, and rebellious qi rising up. Shouldn't we investigate their origins?

    For Long-term Illness with Internal Heat, Use Spicy and Warming Herbs for Acid Vomiting

    The classics say: "Wood yin leads forth, fire yin brings forth." For patients with prolonged illness, the spleen and stomach are generally weak, and many belong to the category of qi stagnation. Thus, for acid vomiting, we should utilize the treatment of Dongyuan to harmonize the stomach, which is the method of using warmth for heat conditions. Some claim that Dongyuan treats acid vomiting as a cold situation, showing a lack of understanding of Dongyuan. I observe that previous scholars have argued, such as the "Jufang," that using warming herbs to treat acid vomiting cannot avoid doubts about cold; this may not have rightly examined the classic's intent, which is specifically for heat conditions. Those who recognize this heat are few, with Liu Hejian being the only notable exception.

    For New Illness with Acid Vomiting, Use Cold Tastes

    Danxi said: For all cases of acid vomiting and acid swallowing, they all belong to heat. One must use Wu Zhu Yu to counter its nature and eliminate it. Stir-fried Huang Lian and stir-fried Zhi Zi are essential medicines; this is to treat the illness caused by heat inducing acidity, thus only employing cold tastes. Wu Zhu Yu must also be used to counter its heat nature. Could it be that only Danxi understands Dongyuan?[67p]
    General Discussion

    Dong Yuan said: Vomiting and belching all pertain to the stomach, which is the chief organ, differing only in terms of the quantity of qi and blood. For example, in cases of vomiting, it relates to the Yangming channel, which has abundant blood and qi, thus resulting in both sound and substance; this indicates an illness of both qi and blood. Zhongjing stated: Even if there is much vomiting with Yangming symptoms, one must be cautious not to purge. Master Sun proclaimed that those who vomit often take fresh ginger, which is indeed the sacred remedy for vomiting. One must disperse the rebellious qi, thus using fresh ginger as the main ingredient. In cases of vomiting, it relates to the Taiyang channel, which has much blood but little qi, hence there is substance without sound; this indicates a blood illness. If food is ingested, then there will be vomiting; if food is already in the stomach, vomiting will occur, and dried tangerine peel can be used to relieve it. Belching relates to the Shaoyang channel, which has much qi and little blood, resulting in sound without substance; this indicates a qi illness, and the main remedy should be ginger combined with pinellia. Therefore, Zhu Feng suggested treating vomiting and belching with fresh ginger, pinellia, dried tangerine peel, and the like. Upon investigating the origins of these three ailments, they are all caused by weak spleen qi, or by cold invading the stomach, aggravated by dietary injuries. Hence, one should primarily use ingredients such as clove, patchouli, pinellia, poria, dried tangerine peel, and fresh ginger. If there has been pre-existing internal injury accompanied by these ailments, one should examine the deficiency and excess to resolve them internally. For phlegm and fluid accumulation, purging is essential. One must differentiate between the channels and match the appropriate remedies; disorder is not permissible.[68p]

    Treatment Method

    From the "Golden Chamber" text: For those who vomit undigested grain and cannot expel it, the primary treatment is Xiaobansha Decoction. It also states: For those who are prone to vomiting and originally felt thirst, but now do not, it is because there is a blockage below the heart due to fluid accumulation, which Xiaobansha Decoction addresses. The ingredients include one pound of Banxia, half a pound of fresh ginger, and seven liters of water, boiled down to one and a half liters and consumed warm in divided doses. It further states: For sudden vomiting, a sensation of fullness below the heart, fluid retention, and dizziness, the appropriate treatment is Xiaobansha Decoction plus Poria, which simply adds four taels of Poria to the previous formula. Both ginger and Banxia are effective primary agents for treating vomiting. However, for cases of obstruction in the upper burner due to excess, where the stomach is weak and the grain qi is not flowing, leading to chest blockage and vomiting, it is crucial to nourish the stomach and promote the flow of grain qi rather than using pungent herbs to drain it. Thus, if Xiaobansha Decoction does not yield results, switching to Dabanxia Decoction will provide immediate relief; this is the principle according to Zhongjing.

    Zhongjing states: If a patient wishes to vomit, one must not force them to do so. Additionally, using Da Huang and Gan Cao to treat vomiting immediately after eating—is this acceptable? It is because the desire to vomit indicates that the illness is located above, and it can be permitted to let it act. Conversely, forcing a downward motion would surely cause stagnation and increase confusion, thus it is prohibited. If one has vomited but is unable to stop and has rising symptoms without descending ones, one should allow the downward motion to occur without haste to use Da Huang, hence it is permitted. Military strategy says: evade the sharp and strike the slow; this embodies the principle. Danxi affirmed this by stating that for any condition of vomiting, one must never forcefully purge; this is indeed correct.[69p]
    The Treatise on Vomiting

    In the case of vomiting, it is crucial to discern between true and false conditions. A true condition involves some form of pathogen; removing it leads to recovery. A false condition lacks pathogen and is entirely due to the deficiency of the stomach qi. The so-called pathogen may arise from sudden cold or heat illnesses, excessive stomach fire, reversed liver qi, phlegm or water accumulation in the chest, or exterior pathogens penetrating inward, gathering between the Shaoyang and Yangming; all lead to vomiting, which are the true pathogens of this condition.

    The so-called false conditions may arise without any internal damage or external afflictions, yet persistently lead to vomiting; since there is no pathogen, the stomach must be deficient. These can occur with slight cold exposure, minor exertion, mild dietary indiscretion, or slight liver qi reversal, all summing up to a deficiency of the stomach. In assessing vomiting's true and false conditions, stomach qi is paramount. If the stomach is strong and the spleen is healthy, then whatever food is ingested should be properly transformed, preventing vomiting. Thus, even with significant harm from cold, heat, hunger, or fullness, the stomach should not falter. However, if there is a slight stimulus and the person cannot withstand it, it is due to a weakness in stomach qi.

    This distinction between true and false conditions should be carefully evaluated to avoid the pitfalls of misdiagnosis. If the stomach qi is inherently deficient and there is stagnation, there exists a mix of deficiency and excess, necessitating initial purification before nourishment. If there is stagnation yet middle qi is weak and struggling, the urgency lies in addressing the deficiency first; one must prioritize restoring the original qi while also providing some purification.[70p]
    In this context, the principles of the beginning and the end are clearly established, emphasizing the importance of understanding the balance of factors. Although those who suffer from vomiting may appear to have a “fire symptom,” as detailed later, most instances of vomiting stem from coldness invading the stomach, with cold stomach conditions being prevalent. In contrast, internal heat is rare. Moreover, vomiting caused by external factors often involves significant cold evil, making the indiscriminate use of cold and cooling medicines inappropriate. If one mistakenly uses such treatments without genuine fire symptoms, those with strong stomachs might endure it, but those with weak stomachs will certainly suffer.

    Liu Hejian noted that intense heat in the stomach leads to vomiting, an assertion that may be an exaggeration; strict adherence to this could cause considerable harm. Additionally, Sun Zhenren asserted that the foremost remedy for vomiting is ginger, a more accurate view that surpasses Hejian’s.

    Zhong Jing stated that in cases of typhoid fever with abundant vomiting, even if there are symptoms of the yangming layer, it should not be purged. This mainly refers to typhoid fever. However, in my opinion, this applies not only to typhoid fever but to all conditions. Why? Because vomiting in mixed conditions is particularly unlike that in typhoid fever. In typhoid fever, there is still heat evil present, but if the heat is in the upper burner and not fully infiltrating the bowels, the resulting reversal means it should not be purged. In contrast, in mixed conditions, vomiting arises not only from a cold stomach but also from a deficiency of the spleen which fails to move. If both spleen and stomach are deficient, can one truly initiate a purging? Furthermore, while the pathogenic factors may not be connected between upper and lower body, the vital energy of both is indeed interdependent. This is precisely why vomiting cannot be purged; the concern is that if disease exists above and one purges below, the lower will become even weaker, and the upper will become increasingly burdened.[71p]
    Deficiency Syndrome

    In general, for those whose stomach is deficient and suffer from vomiting, the symptoms are varied, and one must discern accordingly. If the stomach does not feel bloated, it is not a symptom of real evil. If there is no pain in the chest and diaphragm, it is not due to counterflow of qi. If there is no internal heat or agitation, it is not a fire symptom. If there are no exterior cold or heat symptoms, it is not a superficial evil. If there is no food or heat yet one suddenly vomits, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If vomiting is inconsistent, occurring intermittently, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If food cannot settle and one vomits upon sensing food, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If there is no counterflow of qi and one feels nausea upon smelling, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If slight cold in the back or from eating and drinking leads to vomiting, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If there is sour burping or rancid belching, along with feelings of bitterness and nausea, persistent discomfort when swallowing cold, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If incorrect treatment for illness is administered, mistakenly using harsh cold remedies when there was no vomiting to begin with, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If one eats in the morning and vomits in the evening, or eats in the evening and vomits in the morning, with food entering the middle jiao and not being digested, it is a sign of stomach deficiency. If food enters the lower jiao and is not digested, it indicates a lack of yang in the earth element; thus, the life gate is deficient. In all these deficiency syndromes, it is indeed necessary to tonify. However, since the stomach inherently belongs to the earth element and does not generate unless there is fire, nor can it transform without warmth, if earth is cold, it is also deficient; a deficiency in earth signifies a deficiency in fire.[72p]
    Therefore, it is said that the spleen prefers warmth and dislikes cold, the earth dislikes dampness and enjoys dryness. For this reason, the "Treatise on the Spleen and Stomach" by Dongyuan particularly emphasizes the method of warming and tonifying, which is specifically set for the stomach qi and should not be overlooked! In Hejian, it is mentioned that vomiting arises from stomach fire, which is abundant and solid. Now, I say vomiting arises from stomach cold, which is abundant and deficient. Heat and cold, if both lose their balance, are not aligned with the principle of harmony. It is not to say that there are absolutely no cases of vomiting caused by heat; however, cases of vomiting due to heat are rare, while cases due to cold are common. Vomiting caused by a strong stomach is rare, while that caused by a weak stomach is frequent, hence the necessity for this distinction.

    For the treatment of vomiting due to deficiency, the approach should focus on warming the stomach and tonifying the spleen, and it is appropriate to use Ren Shen Li Zhong Tang as the primary remedy.[73p]
    One may also use warming stomach drinks, such as Sheng Zhu decoction and Ren Ginger drink, or Huang Ya pills, which are particularly effective. If the stomach feels very cold, one should take Fu Zi Li Zhong Decoction, or Si Wei Hui Yang drink, or Yi Qi Dan. If there is deficiency in the yin part, resulting in water retention manifesting as phlegm and vomiting, one should use Jin Shui Liu Jun decoction; if deficiency is severe, then Li Yin decoction or Liu Wei Hui Yang drink should be considered. If there is a long-standing illness causing stomach deficiency and an inability to digest grains, one should treat it as previously mentioned. If there is mild stomach deficiency combined with phlegm, one should use Liu Jun Zi soup. In cases of poisoning accompanied by vomiting, one must ascertain the substance causing the poisoning. Those who vomit due to heat toxins should be treated with cold and bitter remedies; if the cause is cold yin toxins leading to continuous vomiting and diarrhea, one should resolve it with warming remedies. If vomiting and diarrhea have led to spleen and stomach deficiency, it is essential to provide substantial warming and nourishment. This condition involves cold toxin causing vomiting and diarrhea; the treatment is detailed later and should be reviewed.[74p]
    Evidence of Pathology

    Any instance of food stagnation in the stomach leading to vomiting must have a causative factor and supporting evidence. If due to cold stagnation, it will be accompanied by significant pain; if due to food stagnation, there will be substantial bloating; if due to reversed qi, pain and bloating will extend to the ribs; if due to fire constraint, symptoms will include restlessness, dryness, thirst, and a rapid, slippery pulse; if caused by external pathogens, there will be fever in the head and body, with a rapid and tense pulse. If vomiting occurs without concrete evidence of excess conditions or a strong pulse, one must not treat it as an excess pathology.

    When cold pathogens invade the stomach causing vomiting, there are three presentations: Firstly, ingestion of cold or raw foods or mistakenly eating items that are cold in nature can harm the stomach qi and lead to vomiting. If cold stagnation persists, accompanied by bloating and pain, the appropriate approach is to warm the center and move the stagnation using balanced herbal formulas such as Xiao He (Harmonizing Middle) drink, Shen Xiang San, or adding ginger and cinnamon to Er Chen Tang, or using He Wei Yin. Secondly, it may also be due to cold, damp atmospheric conditions, such as rainy weather or cold, wet soil invading the stomach, resulting in vomiting and diarrhea.[75p]
    If there are signs of cold stagnation yet symptoms of swelling or pain, it is advisable to warm the middle and disperse the cold, using medicines such as Ping Wei San, Shen Xiang San, Jia Jian Er Chen Tang, Chu Shi Tang, Ju Fang Si Qi Tang, and Da Qi Xiang Wan.

    Firstly, this may be caused by an external invasion of wind-cold, or it could be due to cold damage or intermittent fever. When the pathogen is in the Shao Yang, and the exterior pathogen has not resolved but is gradually entering the interior, it manifests as cold and heat on the outside, and vomiting on the inside. This is a condition of being half in the exterior and half in the interior. The treatment should focus on resolving the exterior and dispersing the cold with medicines like Chai Chen Jian, Xiao Chai Hu Tang, and Zheng Chai Hu Yin. If there is slight nausea or vomiting, the pathogen is in the Shao Yang. If there is severe nausea and vomiting, this indicates a pathology in the Yang Ming, related to the stomach. One should use Er Chen Tang, or consider Bu Huan Jin Zheng Qi San or Huo Xiang Zheng Qi San. If there is a deficiency in the stomach accompanied by cold, the appropriate remedies would be Li Zhong Tang and Wen Wei Yin.

    If the eating and drinking have harmed the stomach and caused vomiting, and there is retention of undigested food along with swelling and pain, it is advisable to use Da He Zhong Yin, Pai Qi Yin, or Shen Xiang San. Alternatively, you may also consider Qi Pi Wan. If the food has been digested but the vomiting persists, one should prescribe Wen Wei Yin.[76p]
    If there is vomiting due to fire in the middle burner, there must be symptoms of fire and a rapid pulse. It may be accompanied by heat thirst or restlessness, with a pulse that is surging and rapid; vomiting will be forceful, and the overall appearance will be robust. If it is determined that there is indeed a fire pathogen, then reducing the fire will stop the vomiting. If the fire is mild and combined with deficiency, one should use the external formula Huangqin decoction or Banxia Xiexin decoction. If the fire is severe, one should use Chouxin beverage or the major and minor Liangqing drink. If summer heat invades the stomach, causing great thirst and vomiting, with qi deficiency and restlessness, and the fire is not clear, one should use Bamboo leaf and Gypsum decoction. If the heat is severe and vomiting does not stop, with fire in the Yangming and headaches, one should use Baihu decoction, or Taiqing drink, or Liuyi powder. If there is summer heat causing vomiting but the fire is not intense, one should use Xiangru drink or the Five Ingredients Xiangru drink.

    If there is phlegm and fluid retained in the chest, or cold dampness in the stomach, causing water to stagnate in the middle burner and resulting in vomiting, one should use Hewei Erchen decoction, Lingzhi and Bai Zhu Erchen decoction, or Xiao Banxia Jia Fuling decoction or Chenpi Banxia decoction, all of which can be used appropriately.[77p]
    Nausea and vomiting due to reversed qi are often caused by suppressed anger that stirs liver qi, affecting the stomach with liver evil, hence the vomiting occurs. However, a strong stomach may not easily be disturbed, while a more easily disturbed stomach often signifies weakness. Therefore, for such cases, one must pay attention to the stomach qi, suggesting the use of Six Gentlemen Decoction or Regulation of the Middle Decoction. If the reversed qi has not dispersed, or if there is significant distension, one should use Erchen Decoction or a similar prescription such as Orange Peel and Pinellia Decoction; Shenxiang Powder is also good.

    For vomiting caused by malaria and dysentery, in malaria, it results from external evil penetrating inward. Any pathogen residing in the Shaoyang, Yangming, or Taiyin can cause vomiting. When the exterior is resolved, the vomiting will stop. In the case of dysenteric vomiting, it is often due to weak and cold stomach qi. Indeed, if the exterior is not a cold evil, malaria cannot develop; if the interior is not a cold evil, dysentery cannot occur. If the illness does not understand its root, what can be treated? Discussions of two syndromes are fully recorded in relevant texts.

    Vomiting after breakfast, after lunch, or after breakfast and into the evening should be detailed later under the topic of reversed stomach.

    For extreme cases of vomiting or when vomit causes near death upon ingestion of congee or soup, use two taels of ginseng, one liter of water, boiled until reduced to four portions, and administer while hot, twice daily. Additionally, consuming congee made with ginseng will prevent vomiting.[78p]
    Expulsion of Tapeworms

    When one expels tapeworms, it is always due to an illness causing the expulsion, not the tapeworms causing vomiting. Therefore, it is unnecessary to treat the tapeworms directly; rather, one should treat the underlying cause of the vomiting, after which the tapeworms will cease to present themselves.

    For those who expel tapeworms due to excessive stomach heat, the internal heat is so severe that the tapeworms have nowhere to remain and thus come out. Simply cooling the heat will settle the tapeworms; for mild cases, herbal infusions to reduce the heat suffice, while for more severe conditions, the use of the "Ten Thousand Responding Pills" is applicable.

    For those who expel tapeworms due to excessive stomach cold, the internal cold is too potent, preventing the tapeworms from staying inside. Warming the stomach will restore calmness to the tapeworms, and remedies like "Wu Mei Pills" by Zhongjing can be used.

    If the expulsion is due to a deficiency of the stomach with no food, this indicates that the stomach storage is empty, leading the tapeworms to seek nourishment and thus come out. This is a sign of significant stomach qi deficiency; therefore, it is critical to nourish the stomach and warm the center to protect against fundamental failure, employing practices such as warming the stomach infusion, regulating the middle soup, and the "Sheng Zhu Decoction."

    The aforementioned three methods indeed address the tapeworms. However, it should be noted that there are dead and live tapeworms. If dead tapeworms are expelled, one may simply treat the vomiting as previously discussed. If live tapeworms continue to emerge, one must take measures to eliminate them. Tapeworms are instinctively deterred by sour and bitter substances, so adding Wu Mei as an adjunct will help subdue them. For cases of robust heat in the stomach, one may add bitter neem root or Coptis as they are also effective. Any lingering issues will be detailed in the subsequent sections on tapeworms and their treatment.[79p]
    On Treating Vomiting Caused by Weak Stomach

    In treating vomiting due to stomach deficiency, it is crucial to carefully consider the qualities of the substances used. For those with a strong stomach, even toxic substances can be tolerated, regardless of their qualities. However, for a weak stomach, differentiation of suitable and unsuitable substances becomes essential. The more severe the stomach weakness, the more significant the relationship between substances' qualities and the condition. A weak stomach is highly sensitive to unmanageable qualities. Not only can it not tolerate strong, fishy, or foul odors, but even mild fragrances and ordinary food smells can be intolerable. The same goes for those who are aware of their condition. A weak stomach is particularly sensitive to flavors; it cannot withstand extreme bitterness or poor tastes, nor can it tolerate even mild saltiness or bitterness, along with the intrinsic tastes of grains. This highlights why vomiting from stomach deficiency is so impacted by flavors. If there is any slight mismatch, it can lead to immediate vomiting upon ingestion, which offers no benefit. Therefore, in treating symptoms like vomiting due to yang deficiency, all fragrant, salty, sour, and spicy flavors should be measured with personal discretion. If anything appears unsuitable, it must not be used. Instead, one should focus on supplementing the yang; once the yang is restored, the vomiting will inevitably stop. This is the most reliable method and should not be neglected.[80p]
    I once encountered a man with the surname Shen, who was a physician by trade and worked very hard. He was nearly forty years old and due to suffering from a hernia that fell downward, he attempted to raise it using a saline solution to induce vomiting. Unaware that his stomach was weak and could not tolerate salty substances, he ended up vomiting incessantly, with both salt water and food coming up for a whole day and night. Suddenly, he passed dark blood in his stool, one or two bowls worth, and his pulse became weak and barely detectable, almost as if it would stop altogether. This was due to the vomiting harming his stomach qi and the extreme weakness of his spleen, compounded by the saline solution which caused blood to flow, preventing it from being retained in the body.

    I instructed him to immediately use ginseng and ginger to revive the vital energy that was on the verge of collapse, hoping it might help. Suddenly, another physician arrived and said, "All rejections and upward pressures are related to heat. The blood in the stool is also due to heat; can we still use ginseng and ginger? It is better to quickly drink young boy's urine; then the vomiting can be cured, and the bleeding will stop." The man believed there was reasoning in this, and upon swallowing the urine, he experienced extreme nausea and continued to vomit uncontrollably, until his life subsequently faded away.

    Ah! Even a person with a strong stomach would feel nauseated at the mere thought of urine, let alone adding it to someone who cannot stop vomiting! It is not only pitiful for those who die this way but how resentful it is that such a practitioner dares to call himself a physician! Therefore, I write this to emphasize the importance of understanding the nature and characteristics of treatments.[81p]
    Nausea Treatment

    Nausea is a condition characterized by a rebellious stomach, leading to discomfort and restlessness. Generally, when there is a desire to vomit, saliva will flow from the mouth, making swallowing difficult. The more one tries to swallow, the more nausea follows, often leading to vomiting. However, there are instances of nausea without actual vomiting. Although this condition is termed nausea, it fundamentally pertains to stomach issues rather than heart problems.

    The causes of this condition can include cold, food stagnation, phlegm and fluids, foul Qi, fire pathogens, and dampness injuring the stomach, or other pathogens from maladies like cold, malaria, or dysentery affecting the stomach. To understand it better, one must discern between deficiency and excess, and between cold and heat. In cases of excess, the nausea ceases once the pathogen is removed; it comes quickly and goes quickly. In cases of deficiency, the stomach Qi must be significantly restored for recovery to occur.

    Moreover, this condition is predominantly due to deficiency and cold, with at least eight or nine out of ten cases falling into this category. Even in cases of excess nausea, the spleen Qi is often weak and unable to properly transform food, leading to the symptoms. Therefore, in treating nausea, one must recognize the presence of both excess and deficiency, and avoid rash attacks while considering the importance of the stomach Qi.

    For cases of deficiency and cold nausea, these are the most frequent presentations. If not acute and common, or if individuals lack sufficient vitality, it is always due to weakened stomach Qi. Therefore, treatment should primarily focus on warming and strengthening.[82p]
    If there is slight deficiency in the spleen and stomach leading to phlegm, or if one experiences sour belching and a cough with nausea, the Six Gentlemen Decoction should be used. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and stomach with phlegm stagnation causing nausea, the Jinshui Six Gentlemen Decoction is appropriate. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and stomach, or if the Taiyin is overly beneficial, causing abdominal pain, vomiting, and nausea, one can take Warm Stomach Drink, or the Lizhong Decoction or the Shengzhi Decoction. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and kidney, preventing movement up and down, leading to distention, vomiting, or signs of a cold with yin damage, with deep cold evil causing persistent nausea and vomiting, the Liyin Decoction or Warm Stomach Drink should be applied.

    If the evil is real causing nausea due to a momentary stagnation affecting the stomach, if vomiting occurs, the stagnation will resolve and the nausea will naturally subside. If there is residual evil, treat it accordingly. If nausea is accompanied by excess phlegm, or if there is a cough from wind-cold, or suffering from cold or excessive drinking, leading to disharmony in the spleen and stomach, use the Erchen Decoction or the Tangerine Peel and Pinellia Decoction. If there is significant stagnation in the spleen and stomach, or if cold dampness injures the spleen leading to nausea, apply the Pingwei Powder. If the stomach is excessively cold and has much stagnation, or suffers from cold injuries, or if cold phlegm is unclear, with sour belching and distention causing nausea, use the Harmonizing Stomach Drink or the Harmonizing Stomach Erchen Decoction. If exposed to foul, turbid cold evil leads to distention and abdominal pain with nausea, use the Tiqi Pingwei Powder. If experiencing a cold or summer heat, with rampant fire causing irritability and nausea, apply the Zhongjing Bamboo Leaf and Gypsum Decoction. If nausea arises from toxic Chinese herbs or other toxins, seek treatment from the relevant toxicology methods promptly.[83p]
    The occurrence of sour vomiting is discussed as follows: In Hejian, it is said to be caused by heat, while in Dongyuan, it is said to be caused by cold. The principles of medicine have a certain consistency; how can there be such discrepancies? Is it possible that the reasoning can be switched based on these two opinions? Surely, one of these views must be erroneous, and I cannot refrain from voicing my stance that Dongyuan's perspective is correct while Hejian's is wrong.

    How can this be demonstrated? The reasoning from Hejian is actually rooted in the "Inner Canon." The text states that all instances of sour vomiting, due to sudden force or pressure downwards, belong to heat. Thus, Hejian interprets all disease processes as resulting from fire, and harshly criticizes the stance that predominantly attributes this to cold. Yet, they do not recognize that the "Inner Canon" is merely addressing conditions in relation to changes in Qi and broadly categorizing illnesses, rather than asserting that all vomiting and diarrhea are internal heat conditions.

    If we discuss heat, how then is it also said that cold Qi attacks the intestines and stomach, causing pain and resulting in vomiting? Further, it is said that when Taiyang is revived, the heart and stomach produce cold, leading to disharmony in the chest, resulting in the expulsion of clear fluid, and causing belching. This indicates that there are cold factors involved in vomiting; can we thus classify everything as heat? Moreover, it is said that excessive cold enters the lower regions, resulting in diarrhea.[84p]
    This statement reveals that there is coldness in the discharge; could it also be heat? From this, if the text speaks of heat here and coldness there, is it not self-contradictory and not erroneous? Not understanding the principles of the "Neijing," which are comprehensive and detailed, nothing is left out. Thus, there are statements about constancy and others about change, some discussing harmony and others discussing opposition. There are parts not fully covered yet complemented by other arguments, and general statements followed by specific diagnoses. This is the profound essence of the "Neijing," which is not easily exhausted. Therefore, those who can observe this well should aim to grasp its origins, discern its combinations, and understand that its breadth can encompass thousands, while its succinctness must connect back to a single principle. If one can do so, they are indeed worthy of being called a discerning individual.[85p]
    If one cannot grasp its peak and details, but only knows a small part, how can one fully appreciate its wonders? Moreover, there are those who misunderstand the fundamental principles, engage in irrational talks, and misquote scriptures to support their biases, which are too numerous to mention and difficult to clarify. Due to the discussion between the two, I will include it here and request that viewers raise their discernment!

    Regarding the argument that the acidity from Hejian is incorrect. Hejian states: Acid is the flavor of the liver's wood. When fire is strong and governs metal, it cannot balance wood; thus, the liver's wood becomes excessive, resulting in acidity. For instance, when foods are hot, they easily lead to acidity. Some say that vomiting acid is due to cold, which is a mistake. Those who mistakenly claim it is cold merely suggest that excessive consumption can harden and create stickiness or damage cold substances, causing the phenomena of belching acid. Therefore, folk medicine focuses on temperate and harmonious treatments for the spleen and stomach.

    Little do they know that the classics say that when a person is harmed by cold, it manifests as a heat illness. Hence, any internal harm caused by cold substances could lead to an excess of yin over yang, resulting in illness due to cold, or the clash of cold and heat causing the stomach and intestines' yang energy to stagnate, leading to heat. There are also cases of internal harm from cold resulting in a rebound illness of heat, where profuse sweating and heat relief may occur, leading to recovery.[86p]
    If one has long been troubled by sourness and it does not cease, then it is inappropriate to warm it; instead, it is advisable to use cold medications to purge it, and later to adjust it with cooling medicines, leading to the resolution of heat and the harmonization of qi. All of this are the teachings of Hejian; whenever I see it, I cannot help but repeatedly marvel. Observing what is said about the pathogenesis, it stems from fire to metal, from metal to wood, and from wood to the spleen, hence the sourness. If one speaks faintly in inquiry, it could indeed turn around; under such circumstances, pointing at a deer and calling it a horse would face no reproach. It is solely because they hold steadfastly to it being heat that they cannot help but twist and turn in explanation like this. However, if I say it is cold, it is not so. Sourness fundamentally belongs to the flavor of the liver wood. Why not say that the fire is weak and cannot generate earth, thus the spleen's qi is deficient and the liver's evil burdens it, resulting in sourness? Would this not be clearer in reasoning? Why then insist on such convoluted explanations? Furthermore, as the "Inner Canon" states, when a person is harmed by cold, it is considered a disease of heat; this refers to the injury of cold evils at the surface, leading to the fever of the three yangs, and when transmitted internally, it becomes the internal heat of yangming. Can it really be said that internal injuries from cold substances also represent disease heat? Is it plausible to think that one can resolve inner injuries from cold by sweating them out? Even for robust individuals, should they inadvertently be harmed by raw cold, lingering for a long time and accumulating into heat, this is a case of prolonged stagnation transforming into heat; could it truly be due to raw cold causing subsequent heat? Moreover, the "Inner Canon" originally speaks of external pathogens, while Hejian improperly uses it as evidence for internal injuries, which is quite erroneous.[87p]
    This not only harms the essence of Xuanqi, but also leads future generations to use it as an excuse; what greater harm could follow? To clarify the argument of Dongyuan regarding sourness: according to "Explanation," the "Inner Canon" states that all sour vomiting belongs to heat, which occurs when the upper burner is invaded by external evil. The stomach qi does not accept the external evil, resulting in vomiting. Zhongjing treated this with ginger and pinellia. Discussing it in terms of mixed diseases, those who vomit sour water may suffer severely, with the sour water permeating their heart; next, they will vomit sour water, causing their upper and lower teeth to feel sour and unable to meet. Treating this with potent hot herbs will definitely reduce it.[88p]
    The sour taste represents the gathering of energy; in the west, the lung is associated with metal, which is strong. Cold water is the child of metal; the child can cause the mother to bear fruit. Thus, one should use large doses of salty, warming agents to drain the child, complemented by acrid and warming substances, to drain the lung's fullness. If the illness arises from heat attacking, this is a mistake. The essence of various illnesses is related to the heart being affected, with turbid energy not descending, resulting in a fullness in the center. Can cold medicine treat this? This is the argument of Dongyuan, which I believe is most reasonable. However, the way he articulates it can be too obscure; terms like "gathering energy" and "the west's metal being strong, water as the child of metal" may not be easily understood, and many often overlook them. Even in Danxi’s teachings, he also mentions that Dongyuan does not speak of external wind and cold but establishes the idea of gathering energy to drain the fullness of lung metal. He further argues that cold medicine cannot treat sourness, yet employs Anwei Decoction and the modified Erchen Decoction, both containing clove, while lacking methods for treating damp-heat accumulation. This does not align with the classic understanding. Upon examining Danxi's treatment methods, they utilize Zhu Lian Pill and Erchen Decoction, and also mention that it is advisable to use fried Wu Zhu Yu, aligning with its nature to properly address the issue. Therefore, yellow lily must be used as the sovereign medicine to treat it.[89p]
    The intention of Danxi is primarily about heat, which is directly contrary to Dongyuan's views. However, when using Qinnian to treat acid reflux, one must discern carefully. Therefore, I will elaborate on Dongyuan's theories. The so-called "gathering of qi" refers to the metal qi, or autumn qi. The "Inner Canon" states: "Autumn qi begins above." This indicates that the gradual increase of yin must start above, as the yang qi is about to retreat. The gradual onset of cold must begin above as well, as the yang qi declines. When it is said that the metal is strong, it does not mean the fullness of lung qi; it actually refers to an excess of cold qi. The saying that the son envelops the mother implies that with cold in the upper burner, the gathering of qi becomes more intense. Thus, using warm and hot remedies to drain the son is merely a suitable way to support yang and suppress yin. If Danxi did not grasp this intention and instead criticized it, what is the reason? For instance, cloves possess a spicy and refreshing flavor without toxicity; they are most appropriate for addressing cold stagnation in the middle burner, where qi is not flowing smoothly. How could one warn against them as if they are dangerous and instill fear in future generations? Danxi only understood that cloves should not be treated harshly, yet he did not realize the roles of Huanglian and Huangqin. How could one lightly treat sour substances that are suited for such cases? Nonetheless, even though my explanation stands, I must further clarify the discussions on cold and heat, as doubts remain. Thus, I will reiterate my arguments.[90p]
    The arguments stating that sourness is due to heat must each have their explanations, right? Liu Hejian says that when food is hot, it easily becomes sour. Dai Yuanli states that if grains and meat are in a moist and hot vessel, they can easily turn sour. Others claim that when observing winemaking, if the fermentation process is cool, the wine turns sweet, but if it’s overly hot, it turns sour. Isn't it clear that sourness arises from heat? All these theories sound credible, but insisting that people do not accept them is impossible. In matters of this nature, they are often mistaken. It’s like an archer who claims to be skilled simply by not deviating from front, back, or sides. They do not realize that even such basic errors are enough to question their skill in archery. The various theories about this are very much the same. How can we know? One must examine patients by reasoning; reasoning must be based on truth. Just as the sourness of food seems to stem from heat, it appears plausible, yet when food is in a pot, if it can transform without becoming sour, it is because the heat is strong and quickly changes it without leaving anything behind. However, if placed in a vessel, it will take a long time to sour; this is due to accumulation and does not arise from heat. I have often seen water that has been cold and stagnant for a long time, which inevitably becomes sour. Is this due to heat? No, it’s due to inactivity. Furthermore, when winemaking is concerned, heat leading to sourness seems plausible. However, it is only after two or three days of fermentation, when the accumulated heat dissipates, that it becomes sour. There has never been a case where heat immediately causes sourness. Moreover, the digestive energy in humans is primarily derived from strong heat, so when food enters the stomach during meals, it can be digested in an instant; this reflects the true response of yang fire in its proper state.[91p]
    If, like a winemaker, one must wait until the end of the day for the wine to be complete, then one cannot eat again that day; how can one not feel weary in the stomach? If it must be like cold fermentation that yields no sourness and thus is said to be without heat, then the transformation of food must also take days. Is it not evident that the yang energy in the stomach would have already depleted? It is clear that the stomach's energy should be warm; it cannot endure being slightly cool. A wine vessel should remain open; it should not become damp and stagnant. Therefore, how can the transformation in a wine vessel be as swift as the energy in the stomach, and how can the strength of stomach energy be compared to the slowness of a wine vessel? This is a matter of nature and reasoning; it is not merely a matter of tenfold, and there is no need for further clarification. Moreover, the leftover food in the stomach values quick transformation. If the yang energy in the stomach does not decline and operates healthily as usual, why would there be any sourness? If the firepower is insufficient, then the transformation must be slow. Once the transformation is delayed, food accumulates and cannot move, leading to sourness and rotting; this sourness is a gradual onset of spoilage. Thus, any illnesses characterized by sour stomach discomfort are often seen when food does not move quickly, resulting in discomfort from self-consumption, and will inevitably lead to fullness, stifling, and diarrhea. Could it not be the weakness of the spleen and yang deficiency in the stomach, yet still be misinterpreted as heat? I once encountered a gentleman in the capital who suffered from this and sought treatment from me; I told him it was cold, yet he persisted in believing it was heat, adhering to the winemaking argument, unable to differentiate, and ultimately fell victim to the likes of qinlian, never coming to understand. Is this not a case of misunderstanding from earlier discussions? It is indeed lamentable! Thus, I say: it is vital for one to discern truth and reason. If one grasps false reasoning and stubbornly clings to misplaced doubts, leading to major harm, it is nothing but this sort of case.[92p]
    This may seem like valid discourse, but it must not go unexamined. There are three types of experiencing acidity: First, when there is belching with sour water like vinegar effervescing in the throat, accompanied by discomfort in the heart (chest), this is known as "swallowing acid," commonly referred to as "having acidity." This condition is located at the highest point of the upper abdomen, where sourness often appears, causing unease.

    Second, it is not as close to "swallowing acid." It is situated between the middle and upper parts of the stomach; often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, with everything expelled being sour, this is called "vomiting acid," typically involving excessive moisture that fails to resolve.[93p]
    Furthermore, regarding the secondary issues, there is fundamentally no evidence for sour vomiting or sour regurgitation; these may arise incidentally due to vomiting, whether sour or bitter, along with various intolerable flavors. All of these are caused by phlegm and fluid accumulation in the stomach and intestines, leading to foul or turbid tastes, especially below the middle burner (Zhongwan). If the movement is downward, it goes unnoticed by people; if it rises, it is difficult to endure at the throat and mouth.

    Concerning these three conditions, those in the upper and middle burners are simply due to deficiency and coldness of the spleen and stomach, which are unable to process properly; treatment for this must involve warming. As for those occasionally arising in the lower burner, there may be both cold and heat present, but treatment should be based on the symptoms of vomiting; once vomiting ceases, sour and bitter flavors will no longer be present.

    Nevertheless, this is merely my analysis, and I cannot help but approach the matter delicately. In practical terms, those with strong stomachs have no time to dwell on sourness and bitterness; if these sensations occur, it must be because of stagnation and blockage. This should be carefully examined according to the symptoms. If there are no signs of heat or a heated pulse to rely on, and one insists on the idea of heat arising from dampness without distinguishing between strength and weakness, then solely using coldness and cooling methods has led to many errors.[94p]
    On Treatment

    For the condition of sourness in the stomach, one must discern the subtle differences between excess and deficiency, as well as the vigor of youth versus the frailty of age. In cases of excess, the symptom can be treated; in cases of deficiency, the root must be addressed. If the stomach qi is not weak and the constitution is strong, and there are occasional accumulations causing sourness due to either cold or food, one should use warming and moving remedies such as Erchen Decoction, Pingwei Powder, or Hewei Decoction to treat the symptoms. If there is slight cold in the middle qi, one should modify Erchen Decoction or use Orange Peel Decoction; in severe cases, Warm Stomach Decoction is advisable. If there is a slight deficiency of qi, use Huoxiang Anwei Powder. These are all methods to treat the symptoms.[95p]
    When the spleen and stomach are deficient in qi, especially in middle age as one becomes gradually weaker, leading to reduced food intake and occasional sour belching, it is best to gently tonify the spleen and stomach. This can be done with formulas like Lizhong Decoction, Wengui Decoction, or Shengjiang Decoction; one must definitely avoid using cooling and depleting medications. If the deficiency is in the yin aspect and the lower burner is not warm, causing water pathogens to rise and create sourness, it is most effective to use the Recipe for Nourishing Yin.

    Danxi said: To treat sourness, one must use Wu Zhu Yu, following its nature to counter it, which is indeed a method of correction. However, it is not merely about following its nature. Its nature is warm and it is most effective in warming the middle and lower burners; its taste, being pungent and bitter, is best at overcoming the sour and heavy flavors. To call it a corrective method is an exaggeration.

    Using Huang Lian as the sovereign herb to treat sour vomiting is indeed Danxi's method. Observing his case studies, there was a patient who had sour lumps rising from the chest straight to the throat, which was very severe. By making a strong decoction of Huang Lian and cooling it before giving it to address the sour lump, just a few drops caused it to descend. The bitter taste sinks down, so when the sourness encounters bitterness, it immediately descends. This is also a method of calming boiling water with soup.[96p]
    If a young person is strong and has some reserves, and due to alcohol consumption feels a rising acidity and distress, they may use this method without immediately harming their stomach’s energy. It could effectively help in guiding things downward; thus, using it as a temporary remedy is acceptable, though it is not a fundamental solution. However, if one's energy is slightly weak, especially in those who have internal injuries or are older and suffer from acid reflux, one must avoid recklessly using Qinyin, as it further depletes the Yang energy. While it may provide temporary relief from bitter regurgitation, it ultimately damages stomach energy, and the condition will worsen with no recourse.

    For vomiting clear fluids, the traditional methods using Erzhong, Erchen Decoction, or Liu Junzi Decoction are all proper treatments. Yet, I have treated those suffering from water regurgitation by using the method of managing the Yin and simmering it, and the results are remarkably effective. Therefore, all three approaches should be considered for use.[97p]
    When the skin is exposed to wind and cold, it often leads to symptoms of sourness upon swallowing. This occurs because the breath (qi) enters through the nose, and through the meridians, it connects the internal organs to the back.
