Therefore, once cold enters the body, the yang and harmonious qi in the stomach is suppressed and unable to circulate freely, resulting in stagnation and the immediate sensation of sourness, which clearly indicates that cold evil has invaded the stomach.

    Currently, those who spread misinformation claim that when the skin is exposed to wind and cold, internal heat becomes more agitated, and the sour taste pricks the heart—a gross misunderstanding! The development of internal heat due to stagnation must occur gradually over time, whether one day or two, leading to stagnation and then heat. However, anyone who experiences cold and sourness does so immediately; how could it turn into agitated heat so quickly? It is precisely because it is not heat that the remedy involves warming the skin and using fragrant, drying medicines, which are the appropriate treatments for cold. Yet, those who insist on interpreting this as heat forcefully rationalize it. This illustrates the notion of seeking distant truths while ignoring nearby realities; all such misconceptions belong to this category.[98p]
    The symptoms of vomiting are often attributed to a deficiency of the stomach, but they are actually caused by a deficiency of the kidneys. Regardless of whether food is ingested and immediately expelled, it reflects the decline of the kidneys. All instances of vomiting are fundamentally due to kidney deficiency. Thus, treating vomiting without addressing the kidneys fails to address the root of the illness.

    The formula consists of three qian of ginseng, five qian each of white atracary, job’s tears, and foxnut, three grains of amomum, and five fen of wuzhuyu, to be decocted and taken. This formula appears to be a remedy for the spleen and stomach, but it is, in fact, a treatment for the kidneys. Aside from ginseng, which supports the stomach, all other ingredients enter the kidney channel and do not simply remain in the spleen. Kidney fire nourishes the spleen, allowing the spleen’s earth to generate the stomach; when the stomach qi transforms, vomiting and nausea begin to settle. This is a treatment for the stomach using kidney remedies—does anyone realize this?

    Furthermore, in cases of severe vomiting where the tongue resembles a thorn and both eyes are red and swollen, people tend to think it is due to heat, not knowing that it is actually due to the dryness of kidney water, causing fire not to be contained and water not to moisten—resulting in immediate expulsion of food. The appropriate method is to use a decoction of Liuwei Dihuang Tang, allowing ample drinking, which will diminish the excess heat and enable food and drink to be ingested. The stomach serves as the gate of the kidneys; the fire in the stomach must depend on the water from the kidneys to moisten it. If kidney water is depleted and cannot ascend to moisten the spleen and stomach, then stomach fire will boil, surging upwards to cause red and swollen eyes and a thorn-like tongue.

    However, this condition can be both restless and calm—at times longing for water, but when water is offered, there is reluctance to drink. Even when compelled to drink, it doesn’t bring much relief. This indicates a false heat above and true cold below. It is advisable to add fuzi and cinnamon to the Liuwei Tang, decocting it cold for consumption to address the source of the illness.[99p]
    Why is it that nowadays only Liu Wei Di Huang Tang is used? It is because of kidney cold and proper stomach heat. To warm the kidneys, one must use medicine that passes through the stomach channel; if the heat nature arises, the kidneys cannot intervene, and the stomach instead assists the evil fire, leading to an increase in the illness heat. It would be better to use Liu Wei Di Huang Tang directly aimed at the kidney palace, which, although passing through the stomach, does not cause conflict; it is like extinguishing the fire by using an indirect route, where the stomach becomes balanced without direct treatment. This is also a method of reverse treatment.

    For a person with severe vomiting, treatment should not be delayed. The method should employ five qian of ginseng, three qian each of poria and white atractylodes, three fen of licorice, one qian of dried tangerine peel, and three grains of cardamom seeds, boiled in water for consumption. This prescription purely uses ingredients to strengthen the stomach and nourish the spleen, yet many do not understand its underlying intricacies.[100p]
    After a great purge, if the fluids are already depleted, how can one use strengthening the spleen and nourishing the stomach to counteract dryness without causing excessive harm? It is not understood that the energy of the spleen and stomach must be strong for fluids to be generated. If one simply uses moistening medicines, the spleen and stomach, which dislike dampness, will be harmed, thereby injuring their genuine energy. This is why drying medicines are used instead. Other organs may dislike dryness, but the spleen and stomach specifically dislike dampness and prefer dryness. By using ginseng and white atractylodes, one addresses what they need without the fear of excessive dryness.

    After a great purge, if there is cold evil directly entering the kidney palace, and the water from the spleen and stomach is entirely expelled, causing extremities to become cold and abdominal pain unbearable, one must use something hot to provide slight relief; otherwise, the chill may be fatal. Therefore, use one piece of aconite, four ounces of white atractylodes, one pennyweight of cinnamon, three pennyweights of dried ginger, and three ounces of ginseng to rescue them. Once swallowed, relief will be felt; if the vomiting settles, then all will return to normal. The water of the kidneys nourishes a person; how can it counteract the heart to cause death? It is only the invasion of cold evil directly into the kidney palace that causes the kidney fire to retreat, allowing various evils to launch their attacks and disturb the heart monarch.[101p]
    Therefore, it is essential to use aconite, cinnamon, and dried ginger, which are all pungent and warming substances, and to employ ginseng in abundance to stabilize changes. This ensures that the various medicines are evenly distributed, ultimately embodying the warm energy of spring, naturally dispelling cold evils and stopping the vomiting. This is the reason why this formula is both dominant and remarkable.

    In cases of significant vomiting, it is clear that there is a deficiency of cold, and using multiple liang of ginseng is beneficial. However, vomiting should not be uniformly treated; if the condition is not urgent, it is acceptable to use less and gradually increase the dosage. If the cold is not severe and the vomiting is mild, then adding a couple of liang of ginseng might lead to an increase in fullness.

    While significant vomiting predominantly results from cold deficiency, there are also cases of vomiting due to heat, which cannot be overlooked. In cases of heat-induced vomiting, it must be accompanied by phlegm, unlike cold vomiting, which is purely clear water. For heat vomiting, ginseng should not be used; instead, it is appropriate to drink Er Chen Tang.[102p]
    If there is severe vomiting, one must add a small amount of ginseng and mix it with warm and spicy ingredients to stop the vomiting effectively. Ginseng can be used temporarily, but it should not be taken daily. Excessive vomiting can damage the yin; therefore, using ginseng temporarily to stop the vomiting is acceptable, but if taken daily, it will surely lead to an excess of yang and a deficiency of yin, resulting in dryness in the stomach, which may cause blockage. Hence, ginseng can be used temporarily but should not be taken continuously.

    Vomiting is a condition that arises quickly and is a minor ailment. However, if the stomach is tilted and vomits, it will inevitably harm the stomach qi, and once the stomach qi is damaged, it often leads to severe consequences. The symptoms may be caused by heat or cold; for heat-induced vomiting, one should clear the heat but must not suppress it. For cold-induced vomiting, one should dispel the cold but must not suppress it. Suppressing heat brings the heat into the spleen and flows into the large intestine, which may lead to hematochezia; suppressing cold brings the cold into the kidneys and flows into the bladder, likely resulting in urinary incontinence.[103p]
    I have now formulated two remedies:

    The first treats heat-related vomiting, called the Clear Heat and Stop Vomiting Decoction. It consists of one tael of Poria, two qian of Ginseng, three pieces of Sand Ginger, and three qian of Huang Lian, which should be decocted in water and taken orally. This remedy clears heat and reduces fever, thus stopping the vomiting on its own. Its effectiveness lies in Poria's ability to dissipate fire's influence, gently directing the heat downwards rather than forcefully expelling it. Moreover, Ginseng supports the stomach's energy, allowing it to counteract the presence of water naturally, making it unnecessary to deliberately stop the vomiting. Adding Sand Ginger also aids in halting nausea, which is why a single dose is sufficient to stop the vomiting.

    The second treats cold-related vomiting, called the Disperse Cold and Stop Vomiting Decoction. It contains two taels of Bai Zhu, five qian of Ginseng, one qian each of Fu Zi and Gan Jiang, and three fen of Clove, decocted in water and taken orally. This formula disperses cold while still using tonics to strengthen the spleen and support digestion. Thus, the cold cannot rise uncontrollably, and it also cannot descend freely; it must escape from the center and outwards.[104p]
    A single dose acts effectively, like a response to a sound. Stomach vomiting is due to spleen deficiency; when spleen energy fails to descend, it naturally rebounds and causes vomiting. By nourishing spleen energy, stomach energy can stabilize. Use three qian of ginseng and poria, five qian of white atracanthus, one qian each of licorice, cinnamon, medicated leaven, and pinellia, along with three seeds of cardamom, and decoct them in water for consumption. This prescription primarily consists of medicines that nourish the spleen, so why is it also suitable for treating stomach vomiting? It is because the stomach is the gateway of the spleen; the turmoil at this gateway arises from chaos within. Therefore, to ensure peace outside the gateway, one must first pacify the chaos inside. The formula exclusively uses spleen-nourishing medicines, thus the spleen energy is fully restored; what concern is there for vomiting from the stomach? Moreover, the formula includes cardamom, pinellia, and medicated leaven, all of which are effective in stopping vomiting. Is there anything that doesn’t work like a miracle? This is indeed a marvelous method that treats both the spleen and stomach.[105p]
    Method for Treating Sour Ingestion and Diarrhea

    Ingesting sourness relates to heat; diarrhea relates to cold. It appears that heat and cold are distinctly different, and therefore treatment methods should vary. However, it is not understood that while sour ingestion is heat, it arises from the stagnation of liver qi; and while diarrhea is cold, it stems from the liver wood overcoming the spleen. If one were to treat liver stagnation with one method and nourish the spleen with another, the earth element would collapse and the wood would also deteriorate. It is better to address both issues within a single formula.

    The formula uses Chaihu and Cheqianzi, each for one qian; Chenpi, Gancao, and Shenqu, each for five fen; Bai Shaoyao for five qian; and Fuling for three qian, prepared by decoction and taken. Both conditions will be resolved. The uniqueness of this formula lies in the efficacy of Bai Shaoyao, as it is a medicine for the liver channel and is particularly good at alleviating liver qi stagnation; when the wood is relieved, it no longer overcomes the stomach above nor the spleen below.[106p]
    In this formulation, there are also Plantago and Poria to disperse the dampness caused by water, which, when eliminated, flows out through urination. How is there any remaining water to swallow the sourness or residual fluids for diarrhea? Moreover, there are also Pinellia and Massa Medicata Fermentata to resolve phlegm and transform remnants. This is a treatment that possesses both a comprehensive and targeted effect, yet people do not fully appreciate this.

    Regarding diseases of the liver meridian, symptoms such as fullness and distension in the flanks and sour belching and vomiting signify the stagnation of liver wood. The correct method of treatment involves using five qian of white peony, two qian of bupleurum, each one qian of stir-fried gardenia fruit, poria, aged atractylodes, pinellia, and licorice, along with five fen of massa medicata and three qian of moutan root, all decocted in water for consumption. The brilliance of this formula lies in the use of white peony, moutan, and bupleurum, as these three herbs are specifically indicated for the liver wood, particularly white peony, which excels at pacifying the liver without harming the spleen earth. The earth is nourished, allowing the wood to become more comfortable; when the wood is relaxed, the qi is invigorated, alleviating the pain and gradually calming the vomiting.

    Formula for Vomiting
    Bi Xia Dan (from the "Collected Verified Formulas") treats persistent vomiting. Take four taels of northern yellow lead and half a jin of rice vinegar, boil down until dry. Then use charcoal fire to heat until it turns red, grinding into a fine powder. Form into pills the size of a wutong seed. Take seven pills with vinegar soup each time.[107p]
    Yin Yang Pill from "Zheng's Pediatric Formulas"
    Used to treat various forms of vomiting.
    Ingredients: Half tael of sulfur, one qian of mercury, ground into paste.
    Form into small pills the size of a mung bean, administer three pills to a three-year-old, taken with cold water. Adults may take thirty to forty pills.

    Red Stone Fat Powder from "Qian Jin Yi Fang"
    Used for phlegm and drinking water that is vomited at all times. The cause is excessive cold drinks, which weakens the spleen and stomach’s energy, preventing proper digestion of food; the food turns into cold water in the stomach, leading to continual vomiting.
    Ingredients: One jin of red stone fat, crushed and sifted. Take with a spoonful of wine at your discretion, gradually increasing to three spoonfuls. Consuming one jin will prevent vomiting and diarrhea for life, nourishing the five internal organs and promoting weight gain. Some people with phlegm and water, after taking other medicines without effect, find healing with this remedy.

    Additionally, there is a formula from "Ba Cui Fang"
    For treating cold in the stomach with vomiting and nausea, unable to digest food properly; food leads to immediate vomiting.
    Ingredients: Two and a half qian of ginseng, two and a half qian of clove, two and a half qian of patchouli, five qian of tangerine peel, three slices of ginger.
    Instructions: Use two cups of water, decoct to one cup, and take warm.

    Ginseng Banxia Decoction (Zhongjing, same below)
    Used for immediate vomiting after eating.
    Ingredients: One tael of ginseng, one and a half tael of banxia, half jin of ginger.
    Instructions: Use one dou of water, scoop and stir two hundred and forty times, yielding three sheng. Add three he of white honey, boil down to one and a half sheng, and divide for consumption.[108p]
    Xiao Ban Xia Decoction (also known as Ginger and Ban Xia Decoction) treats chest congestion with nausea, feeling as if one is short of breath or experiencing vomiting without actually doing so, accompanied by a sensation of heaviness in the heart region. Soak Ban Xia seven times, one sheng, with ginger half a jin. Combine with seven sheng of water, boil down to one sheng and five ge, and take in divided doses.

    Wu Zhu Yu Decoction treats nausea, drooling, and headaches. Ingredients include one sheng of Wu Zhu Yu, twenty large dates, one liang each of ginger and ginseng. Use five sheng of water, decoct to obtain three sheng. Each dose is seven ge, taken three times daily.

    Qing Ge San (from "Health Family Treasure Formula") treats gastric heat leading to vomiting of food. Ingredients include fifty pieces of cicada molting, cleaned, and one liang of slippery stone, ground into powder. Each dose is two qian, mixed with one cup of water and honey for consumption.

    Ban Xia Jia Fu Ling Decoction (from Zhang Zhongjing) treats nausea, dizziness, and inability to eat. Ingredients include one sheng of Ban Xia, half a jin of ginger, and three liang of Fu Ling, chopped. Add seven sheng of water, decoct to obtain one sheng and half, and take warm in divided doses.

    Cong Bai Decoction (from "Thousand Gold Formulary", same as below) treats cold and hot phlegm causing headaches and discomfort, with a desire to vomit but unable to. Ingredients include fourteen stalks of scallion white, a handful of peach leaves, and pearl powder, and equal parts of Heng Shan, Aconite, and licorice, each half a liang. The six ingredients should be crushed, combined with four sheng each of water and wine, boiled down to three sheng, strained, and pearl powder added. Take one sheng; if vomiting occurs, it will stop. The peach leaves refer to loquat leaves.[109p]
    Pepper and Ginger Soup: Treats accumulated phlegm and fluid in the chest, reduced appetite, insufficient stomach qi, cough, regurgitation, and vomiting.

    Ingredients:

    • Three taels of Sichuan pepper
    • One tael of cinnamon heart
    • One tael of aconite
    • One tael of licorice
    • Two taels each of tangerine peel, balloon flower root, and Poria
    • Three taels of pinellia
    • Seven cups of ginger juice

    Directions: Grind these nine ingredients, boil them with nine sheng of water to extract two and a half sheng, strain, add ginger juice, and continue boiling to extract two sheng. Divide into three doses and take three doses continuously. If intending to take large dispersive pills (Wushishi pills), one must first take this soup, along with Huangqi pills for better effect. An alternative formula does not use licorice.

    Gypsum Soup: Also known as "Clear the Lung Soup." Treats heart heat excess, the urge to vomit but unable, restlessness, wheezing, and headache.

    Ingredients:

    • One jin of gypsum
    • One sheng each of bamboo leaves and fragrant soybean
    • Five taels each of wheat and earth bone bark
    • Three taels of Poria
    • Seven pieces of gardenia seeds

    Directions: Grind these seven ingredients, first boil wheat and bamboo leaves with fifteen sheng of water to extract eight sheng of clear liquid. Then add the other ingredients, boil to extract two sheng, strain, and divide into three doses.

    Another formula treats abdominal bloating with belching, a desire to vomit when eating, diarrhea with watery stools, dry mouth, heavy limbs, irritability, aversion to noise, forgetfulness, and throat obstruction.

    Ingredients:

    • One tael of coptis
    • Two taels of Yu Yu Liang
    • Three taels each of white atractylodes and dried ginger
    • Five taels of hemp seeds
    • Eight taels of mulberry bark
    • Twenty jujubes

    Directions: Grind these seven ingredients, use twelve sheng of water to extract three sheng, and divide into four doses.[110p]
    Banxia Decoction also known as Xiaofuling Decoction. It treats adverse qi, heart vexation, fullness in the chest, vomiting, and qi rising.
    Ingredients: 1 sheng of Banxia, 1 jin of fresh ginger, 5 liang each of Fuling and Guixin.
    Prepare the above four ingredients by grinding them, using 8 sheng of water, and boiling to yield 2.5 sheng. Divide into three doses. If there is shortness of breath, add 2 liang of licorice.

    Qianhu Decoction treats cold and heat vomiting, shortness of breath, hardness and gathering in the chest, fullness with inability to eat, cold and heat, excessive thirst, and deficiency.
    Ingredients: 3 liang each of Qianhu and fresh ginger, 2 liang each of licorice, sodium sulfate, and rhubarb soaked separately, along with 2 liang each of Shaoyao, Fuling, Maimendong, Danggui, Banxia, Shichao, gypsum, shelled gourd root, Huangqin, Fuzi, and Renjian.
    Prepare the above sixteen ingredients by grinding them, using 12 sheng of water, and boiling to yield 6 sheng. Divide into four doses.

    Another formula treats vomiting, coldness and numbness in the limbs, shortness of breath with abdominal heat, and disharmony in the Sanjiao.
    Ingredients: 2 liang each of Qianhu, Chuanxiong, licorice, Danggui, gypsum, Renjian, Guixin, and orange peel; 3 liang of Shaoyao; 4 liang of Banxia; 5 liang of fresh ginger; and 30 dates.
    Prepare the above twelve ingredients by grinding them, using 12 sheng of water, and adding 3 liang of Huangqin, combine and boil to yield 3 sheng. Divide into three doses. In one formula, Huangqin is not used.[111p]
    Wheat Soup: Treats persistent vomiting.
    One liter of wheat, four taels each of ginseng and magnolia bark, one tael of licorice, two and a half taels of green bamboo pith, three cups of fresh ginger juice, and three taels of Poria. Combine these seven ingredients, chop them finely, add eight liters of water, boil down to three liters, strain, and divide into three doses.

    Zhu Ling Powder: Treats vomiting due to cold in the diaphragm.
    Three taels each of Zhu Ling, Poria, and Atractylodes. Grind these three ingredients, filter, and take a thumb-sized spoonful with water, three times a day. For thirst, drink plenty of water.

    Rhinoceros Horn and Ginseng Decoction: Treats nausea, weakness of stomach qi due to evil, wind-heat, and inability to digest food.
    Two taels each of rhinoceros horn and ginseng, five taels of Chinese leek, and one cup of millet. Combine these four ingredients, chop them, and boil in four and a half liters of water until one and seven-tenths liters remain. Add the millet and cook until it is done, divide into four doses, and after a long interval of seven miles, take another dose.

    Another formula: Treats spring and summer epidemic cold, cold invading the stomach, causing the stomach to cool and become uncomfortable.
    Two taels each of tangerine peel, cinnamon, and kudzu root, and one liter of white grass root. Combine these four ingredients, chop, and boil in six liters of water to yield three liters, divide into three doses, and finish all. If there is heat, omit cinnamon.

    Another formula: Treats vomiting and hiccups.[112p]
    Recipe 1: For treating qi collapse and vomiting, take the following ingredients and prepare as directed:

    • Ginseng: 1 tael
    • Hu ma ren (sesame seeds): 8 jiao
    • Orange peel (remove white part): 1 tael
    • Loquat leaves: 8 taels

    Crush these four ingredients and boil the loquat leaves in 10 liters of water. After obtaining 5 sheng, cook until only 3 sheng remain, add sesame seeds, and drink in small doses.

    Recipe 2: For treating qi collapse.

    • Fermented soybeans: 1 sheng
    • Banxia (pinellia): 8 taels
    • Fresh ginger: 2 taels
    • Ginseng: 1 tael
    • Qianhu (hogfennel): 1 tael
    • Cinnamon heart: 1 tael
    • Licorice: 1 tael

    Crush these seven ingredients and boil in 9 liters of water until reduced to 3 sheng. Divide into three doses.

    Recipe 3: For treating prior conditions.

    • Jujube (dates): 15 pieces
    • Prepared aconite: 1 piece
    • Orange peel: 2 taels
    • Fermented soybeans: 1 sheng
    • Fresh ginger: 1 tael
    • Licorice: 1 tael

    Crush these six ingredients and boil in 9 liters of water until reduced to 2 sheng. Divide into three doses, to be taken three times a day.

    Recipe 4: Orange peel soup for dry vomiting and reverse cold in hands and feet.

    • Orange peel: 4 taels
    • Fresh ginger: 1 jin

    Crush these two ingredients and boil in 7 liters of water until reduced to 3 sheng. Divide into three doses; if symptoms persist, continue to take more.

    Another Recipe: For post-typhoid vomiting and inability to retain food.[113p]
    Sheng Lu Gen (Raw Reed Root) 1 sheng, Qing Zhu Ru (Green Bamboo Shoot) 1 sheng, Jing Mi (Waxy Rice) 3 he, Sheng Jiang (Fresh Ginger) 2 liang.
    These four ingredients should be chewed, then simmered with 5 sheng of water until only 2 sheng remains. Divide into three doses. If symptoms persist, take three doses.

    Another Formula for prior symptoms:
    Tong Cao (Chinese Rice Paper Plant) 2 liang, Ji Pi (Orange Peel) 2 liang, Jing Mi 3 he, Sheng Lu Gen 1 sheng.
    These four ingredients should be chewed, then simmered with 4 sheng of water until only 1.5 sheng remains. Divide into three doses.

    Lu Su Yuan (Exposure to Dew) addresses exposure to cold air, tightness in the chest, nausea, and inability to digest cold food. It is also effective for typhoid fever, caused by exposure to cold in the morning and at night, and aversion to cold.
    Fu Zi (Aconite), Wu Tou (Aconite), Gui Xin (Cinnamon Heart), Peng Shi (PK Stone) each 4 liang.
    Grind these four ingredients into a powder, form into pills the size of a yellow bean, and take three pills with wine, twice a day, increasing to ten pills. The medicine is effective against cold, avoid hot foods and proximity to fire, and prefer cold food and drink.

    Ban Xia Tang (Pinellia Decoction) treats lung deficiency with cold, coldness in the heart and abdomen, reversed Qi, distended sensation from the chest to the back, intermittent nausea, vomiting immediately after eating, and deficiency signs.
    Ban Xia (Pinellia) 1 sheng, Sheng Jiang 1 jin, Gui Xin 4 liang, Gan Cao (Licorice), Hou Po (Magnolia Bark) each 2 liang, Ren Shen (Ginseng), Ji Pi 3 liang, Mai Dong (Ophiopogon) 3 liang.
    These eight ingredients should be chewed, then simmered with 10 dou of water until 4 sheng remains. Divide into four doses. For abdominal pain, add 2 liang of Dang Gui (Angelica).[114p]
    Jianzhong Decoction treats the five labors and seven injuries, acute pain in the lower abdomen, a feeling of fullness in the bladder, coldness in the hands and feet, bitter vomiting, sour phlegm, little breath, dizziness, deafness, and a dry mouth. Urination is spontaneous. Ingredients: half a pound of cow's syrup, three taels each of astragalus, dried ginger, and angelica, two taels each of ginseng, pinellia, tangerine peel, peony, and licorice, one tael of aconite, and fifteen dates. These eleven ingredients should be crushed, boiled in one斗 of water (approximately 10 liters) to obtain three and a half sheng (approximately 700 ml) of decoction. After preparing the decoction, dissolve the cow's syrup in it while boiling, divide into four doses. If the practitioner feels deep, use six taels of cinnamon heart and one pound of fresh ginger, omitting tangerine peel and dried ginger.

    Houpǔ Decoction treats obstruction in the upper burner, dry retching, vomiting without expulsion, more cold than heat, a tendency to spit white foam, and swallowing clear saliva that is sour. Ingredients: four taels each of magnolia bark, poria, chuanxiong, white atractylodes, and scrophularia; three taels each of platycodon, aconite, ginseng, and tangerine peel; eight taels of fresh ginger; and eight jiao of evodia. These eleven ingredients should be crushed, boiled in two斗 of water to yield five sheng (approximately 1 liter), and divided into five doses.

    Stop Vomiting Ginseng Decoction treats heat in the lower burner, reversed qi that does not stop, and uncontrollable vomiting, known as "running and feeding." Ingredients: three taels each of ginseng, licorice, scutellaria, and anemarrhena; four taels each of raw reed root, gardenia seed, and fried white atractylodes; four taels of tangerine peel; and eight taels of gypsum. These ten ingredients should be crushed, boiled in nine sheng (approximately 1.5 liters) of water to obtain three sheng (approximately 600 ml) of decoction, strain out the residues, and divide into three doses.[115p]
    Zhu Yu Decoction (by Zhang Zhongjing)
    Used to treat vomiting and chest fullness.

    • Wu Yu: 1 sheng
    • Ren Shen: 3 liang
    • Sheng Jiang: 6 liang
    • Da Zao: 12 pieces

    Combine these four ingredients, add 5 sheng of water, boil down to 3 sheng. Take 7 he in warm form, three times a day.

    Si Ni Decoction
    Used to treat vomiting with weak pulse, frequent urination, and mild fever. Difficult to treat if there are signs of cold limb.

    • Fu Zi: 1 piece, raw
    • Gan Jiang: 1.5 liang
    • Gan Cao: 2 liang, roasted

    Combine these three ingredients, add 3 sheng of water, boil down to 1 sheng and 2 he, discard the residue, and take warm in two portions. Strong individuals may use 1 piece of large Fu Zi and 3 liang of Gan Jiang.

    Fu Zi and Jun Rice Decoction
    Used to treat cold qi in the abdomen, sharp pain like thunder, fullness in the chest and ribs, and vomiting.

    • Fu Zi: 1 piece, processed
    • Ban Xia: 0.5 sheng
    • Jun Rice: 0.5 sheng
    • Gan Cao: 1 liang
    • Da Zao: 10 pieces

    Combine these five ingredients, add 8 sheng of water, cook until the rice is done, remove the residue, and take 1 sheng warm, three times a day.

    Wu Ling Powder
    Used to treat lean individuals with palpitation below the navel, vomiting saliva, and dizziness.

    • Ze Xie: 2.1 fen
    • Zhu Ling: 3 fen
    • Fu Ling: 3 fen
    • Bai Zhu: 3 fen
    • Gui: 2 fen, peeled

    Grind these five ingredients into powder, take with white drink, using a spoonful three times a day. Drink plenty of warm water; sweating will help recovery.[116p]
    Guiling Wuwei Gancao Qu Gui Jia Ganjiang Xixin Banxia Decoction treats cough with phlegm and vomiting. Ingredients: 4 taels of Fuling, 2 taels each of Gancao, Xixin, Ganjiang, and 0.5 sheng each of Wuwei and Banxia. Prepare with 8 sheng of water, boil down to 3 sheng, strain, and take 0.5 sheng warm, three times a day.

    Banxia Xiexin Decoction treats vomiting and abdominal rumbling with a feeling of fullness below the heart. Ingredients: 0.5 sheng of washed Banxia, 1 tael of Huanglian, 3 taels each of Huangqin, Ganjiang, Renshen, and Gancao (roasted), and 12 Da Zao.     Huangqin Jia Banxia Shengjiang Decoction treats dry vomiting with diarrhea. Prepare with 10 sheng of water, boil down to 3 sheng, strain, take 1 sheng warm, twice during the day and once at night.

    Xiaochaihu Decoction treats vomiting with fever. Ingredients: 5 taels of Chaihu, 0.5 sheng of Banxia, 3 taels each of Huangqin, Renshen, Shengjiang, and Gancao, and 12 Da Zao. Prepare with 12 sheng of water, boil down to 6 sheng, strain, and boil again to 3 sheng, take 1 sheng warm, three times a day.[117p]
    Dabanxia Decoction: For treating vomiting due to stomach reflux.
    Ingredients: 2 sheng of Banxia (Pinellia), 3 liang of Ren Shen (ginseng), 1 sheng of honey.
    Preparation: Combine the three ingredients with 12 liters of water, mix the honey evenly 240 times, boil the herbs, and take 2.5 sheng. Warm and consume 1.5 sheng, dividing into two doses.

    Dahuang Gancao Decoction: For treating vomiting that occurs shortly after eating.
    Ingredients: 4 liang of Dahuang (rhubarb), 1 liang of Gancao (licorice).
    Preparation: Combine the two ingredients with 3 sheng of water, boil to extract 1 sheng, and take it warm in two doses.

    Fuling Zexie Decoction: For treating vomiting with thirst and a desire to drink water.
    Ingredients: 0.5 jin of Fuling (Poria), 3 liang of Baizhu (white atractylodes), 4 liang each of Zexie (alisma), Sheng Jiang (ginger), 2 liang each of Gancao (licorice) and Guizhi (cinnamon twig).
    Preparation: Combine the six ingredients with 10 liters of water, boil to extract 3 sheng, then add Zexie and boil again to extract 2.5 sheng. Take 8 he (he is a unit of volume) warm, three times a day.

    Banxia Ganjiang Powder: For treating dry vomiting and regurgitation of foam.
    Ingredients: Equal parts of Banxia (Pinellia) and Ganjiang (dried ginger).
    Preparation: Grind the two ingredients into a powder, take one tablespoon mixed with 1.5 sheng of water, boil to get 7 he, and take it all at once.

    Ju Pi Zhu Ru Decoction: For treating hiccups and reflux.
    Ingredients: 1 jin of Ju Pi (tangerine peel), 0.5 jin of Sheng Jiang (ginger), 2 sheng of Zhu Ru (bamboo shavings), 5 liang of Gancao (licorice), 30 pieces of Da Zao (dates), and 1 liang of Ren Shen (ginseng).
    Preparation: Combine the six ingredients with 10 liters of water, boil to extract 3 sheng, and take 1 sheng warm, three times a day.[118p]
    Gancao Powder Honey Decoction: Used to treat vomiting from roundworms.

    • 2 taels of licorice, 1 tael of powder, 4 taels of honey.
    • Combine these three ingredients, using 3 sheng of water. First, boil the licorice to obtain 2 sheng, strain out the residue, then add the powder and honey, mixing well. Cook until it is like a thin porridge, and take 1 sheng warm; it will stop the vomiting.

    Wumei Pill: Used to treat roundworm convulsions and vomiting.

    • 300 grams of black plum, 6 taels each of asarum, fried aconite, cinnamon twig, ginseng, and yellow bristle grass; 10 taels of dried ginger; 1 jin of coptis; 4 taels each of danggui and Sichuan pepper (sweat removed).
    • Grind and sift these ten ingredients separately, then combine. Soak the black plum in bitter wine overnight, remove the pits and steam. Use 5 sheng of rice to make congee, then mash into a paste and mix with the medicine until well combined. In a mortar, knead with 2,000 grains of honey, forming pills the size of a walnut. Take 10 pills before meals, three times a day, gradually increasing to 20 pills. Avoid raw, cold, slippery, and foul-smelling foods.

    Yangwei Pill (from the "Zhongzang Jing"): Used for spleen and stomach disharmony, loss of appetite, cold in the middle, nausea and vomiting, cold dirt diarrhea, abdominal pain and intestinal noises. Regular use of the warming and stomach-nourishing powder will stimulate appetite.

    • 1.5 taels of clove, 0.3 taels of ginseng, roasted licorice, white cardamom seeds, and half summer, each half tael; 3 taels of dried ginger, fried.
    • Grind these together into a fine powder, then mix with honey to form pills, making 10 pills per 2 taels. Take 1 pill with warm water on an empty stomach before meals, or chew well and swallow with soup, also acceptable.[119p]
      Dingxiang Zhuyutang
      Treats stomach deficiency, nausea, vomiting, and obstruction in the throat.
      Dried ginger and Huangbo, each 2 fen; Dingxiang, roasted licorice, Chaihu, orange peel, and Banxia, each 5 fen; Shengma, 7 fen; Wuzhuyu, Caodoukou, Huangqi, and Renren, each 1 qian; Cangyou, 2 qian; Danggui, 1 qian and 5 fen.
      The above ingredients should be ground to the size of a soybean. For each dose, take half a tael, with 2 bowls of water, decoct until reduced to 1 bowl, remove the sediment, and take warm before meals. Avoid cold substances.

    Baizhu Tang
    Also known as Fuling Banxia Tang. Treats weak stomach qi, heaviness in the body with phlegm, and nausea with the urge to vomit due to wind evils obstructing the spleen and stomach. First, strengthen the spleen and stomach.
    Fried Sheniuq, 2 qian; Chenpi and Tianma, each 3 qian; Baizhu, Baifuling, malt (fried yellow), and Banxia, each 5 qian.
    The above, ground finely. For each dose, take 5 qian, with 2 bowls of water, add 5 slices of fresh ginger, and decoct until reduced to 1 bowl, remove the sediment, and take warm.[120p]
    Buhgan Decoction, also known as Chaihu Banxia Decoction. It treats those with a chronic wind syndrome, who are afraid of the wind, have dry eyes and headaches, dark vision, phlegm in the chest, nausea with a strong urge to vomit, and tightness of the skin and flesh upon encountering wind, making it difficult to lift heavy objects with hands and feet. If one stays in a warm room and sweats slightly, the symptoms will reduce; however, encountering wind causes a recurrence.

    Ingredients:

    • Chaihu: 5 grams
    • Shengma: 5 grams
    • Jiao Ben: 5 grams
    • Baizhu (White Atractylodes): 7 grams
    • Fried Shenqu: 10 grams
    • Cangzhu: 10 grams
    • Banxia: 20 grams
    • Fresh Ginger: 10 slices

    Prepare as a coarse powder, make into one dose, add to a large cup of water, decoct until reduced to half a cup, strain, and take while warm.

    Zaojiao Huatan Pill: Treats labor wind, stagnation of heart and spleen, excessive phlegm and saliva, difficulty in the throat, thick and sticky nasal discharge, blockage causing nausea, lack of appetite, and occasional dizziness.

    Shang Er Huang Pill: Treats injury from heat and food, fullness and discomfort, strong urge to vomit, restlessness, and unease.

    Ingredients:

    Bamboo Reed Decoction: Treats stomach heat from evil influences, with symptoms of irritability and a preference for cold, incessant vomiting.
    Ingredients: Three taels of kudzu root, half a tael of processed pinellia, two taels of honey-fried licorice.
    Preparation: Crush and chew them well, each dose is five qian (a weight measure), add two cups of water, along with a handful of bamboo reed, five slices of fresh ginger, and simmer until reduced to seven-tenths; strain to obtain the clear liquid, let it cool slightly, and consume slowly without regard to timing.

    Jade Floating Pills: Treats weakness of the spleen and stomach in both men and women, alleviates all vomiting; can be taken for prolonged gastrointestinal discomfort regardless of the cause of illness, it is a truly good remedy.
    Ingredients: Ginseng, white silkworms fried to remove silk, white atractylodes, dried ginger processed, cloves, nutmeg wrapped and steamed, tangerine peel, white cardamom seeds, fried wheat bran, processed aconite without skin, aromatic wood without flame, south star processed, betel nut, pinellia soaked seven times, and honey-fried licorice.
    Preparation: Grind them all into fine powder in equal parts, each dose is two qian; mix with one qian of raw wheat flour and stir well, add ginger juice to form small pills the size of a phoenix seed. Boil them in bubbling water until they float, quickly remove, and take with warm ginger tea, without regard to timing. For severe illness, no more than three doses. For those who are sensitive to hot medicines, omit the aconite. For constipation, omit the nutmeg.[123p]
    Wei Dan treats deficiencies of true yang, weak heart fire, lack of nourishment in the spleen and stomach, disrupted harmony, cold and emptiness in the middle region, inability to take in food, chest obstruction, bloating whether from not eating or after eating, phlegm reversal leading to nausea, regurgitation of food, cold and weak internal energy, inability to digest grains, severe abdominal pain, persistent diarrhea, and all diseases of the spleen and stomach.

    Ingredients include:

    • Fifty taels of large pieces of cinnabar without stones
    • Ginseng
    • Reduced cardamom

      -草果仁 (Amomum fruits) all four taels each.

    Prepare these twenty ingredients according to the method. Grind until the size of beans. Take a silver pot, using five jin of white sand honey, combine half of the medicinal ingredients with the honey thoroughly and place in the silver pot. Put the prepared cinnabar in a silk bag and hang it in the pot. Using mulberry wood, boil with heavy broth for four days and nights, then replace the honey with another five jin, mix with the remaining medicinal concoction, and boil for another three days and nights. Extract the sand and dry it, pound it finely in a mortar. Form into small pills, the size of mung beans, and let dry in the shade. Each dose is ten pills, increasing to fifteen before meals, taken with ginseng soup or jujube soup. For vomiting, use light ginger soup. Avoid eating pig and sheep blood.[124p]

    Great Stomach Nourishing Decoction

    Treats damage to the spleen from improper diet, undigested food, vomiting of morning meals in the evening and evening meals in the morning, breath rising with heat, coldness and numbness in the limbs, dysfunction of the triple warmer, as well as cold qi in the stomach.     • 1 liang licorice (roasted)

Each dose is 4 qian, boiled in 1.5 cups of water, with 3 slices of ginger and 1 date, simmered to 70%, filtered, and taken on an empty stomach. Alternatively, it can be made into a fine powder and mixed with rice soup for consumption.

    Ginger Pill: Treats dry vomiting and nausea, benefits bodily fluids, harmonizes stomach qi. Use two pounds of ginger, chop it with the skin, soak with three taels of green skin overnight, then bake until dry.     Thoughtful Food Pill: Assists the spleen and stomach, helps digest food, and stops vomiting.     Ginseng Fragrant Atractylodes Pill: Opens appetite, promotes eating, and stops vomiting.     Treats dry retching and inability to eat.

    Treats hiccups and lack of appetite.

    Dingxiang Fuzisao: Treats weakness of the spleen and stomach, chest fullness, and persistent vomiting.

Also, take one large radish, scoop out a hole, insert the Fuzhi, fill it, cover it with the radish, and roast it over gentle and strong fire until fragrant and cooked. Remove, slice the Fuzhi, dry, and grind into a fine powder. Take one qian with rice soup, three times daily.

    • Fermented sorghum: 3 qian

    Total of twelve ingredients, chopped to the size of mung beans. Take 1 liang with 2 cups of water and 3 slices of ginger, boiled until reduced to 1 cup, strain and take warm before meals.

    Tie Brush Decoction: Treats accumulation of cold phlegm and fluids, persistent vomiting, uncomfortable feeling in the chest, and inability to eat or drink.

    Ingredients:

    • Pinellia: 4 qian (soaked in broth)
    • Cardamom: 3 qian
    • Clove: 3 qian
    • Dry ginger (processed): 3 qian
    • Haritaki skin: 3 qian
    • Fresh ginger: 1 liang

    Total of six ingredients, pulverized, with 5 cups of water, boiled until reduced to 2 and a half cups, strain, divide into three doses without time restrictions. In cases of continuous vomiting, add 3 qian of Aconite and 5 qian of fresh ginger.

    Four Ingredients Ho Leaf Decoction: Treats cold stomach and vomiting, persistent nausea after food and medicine.

    Ingredients:

    • Ho leaf: equal parts
    • Ginseng: equal parts
    • Orange peel: equal parts
    • Pinellia: equal parts

    Prepare with ginger and take warm.[140p]
    Ancient Shen-Yu Decoction: Treats Qi deficiency and cold in the stomach, with symptoms of vomiting cold saliva. Used for dry retching. Ingredients: equal parts of Wu Zhu Yu (Evodia fruit) and Ren Shen (ginseng). Prepare by decocting with ginger and jujube.

    Ancient Ding-Xia Decoction: Treats cold, deficiency in the spleen, phlegm retention, and symptoms of hiccup and vomiting. Ingredients: 3 qian each of Ding Xiang (clove) and Ban Xia (pinellia). Decoction with ginger, taken warm.

    Single Ren Shen Decoction: Treats Qi deficiency and vomiting. Ingredients: 6 liang of Ren Shen. Use 3 cups of water, decoct until reduced to 80%, then take warm. Also consume the residue by cooking it into porridge. If sudden vomiting occurs and porridge is immediately rejected, for weak individuals, take it in pill form to adjust the stomach.

    Single Bai Kou San: Treats cold in the stomach with accumulation, and those with appetite and vomiting after eating. Ingredients: 5 qian of Bai Dou Kou (white cardamom). Grind into powder and mix with good wine to take.

    Jin Shui Liu Jun Decoction: Treats lung and kidney deficiency with cold, leading to phlegm and symptoms such as vomiting. Ingredients: 3 qian each of Dang Gui (angelica), Ban Xia, and Fu Ling (poria), 3-5 qian of Shu Di Huang (rehamannia), 1.5 qian of Chen Pi (dried tangerine peel), and 1 qian of roasted Gan Cao (licorice). Use 2 cups of water and 3-7 slices of fresh ginger, decoct until reduced to 70% and take warm after meals.

    He Wei Er Chen Decoction: Treats cold in the stomach causing phlegm, nausea, vomiting, chest fullness, and belching. Ingredients: 1-2 qian of stir-fried Gan Jiang (dried ginger), 4-5 fen of Sha Ren (sand ginger), and 1.5 qian each of Chen Pi, Ban Xia, and Fu Ling, with 7 fen of roasted Gan Cao. Use 1.5 cups of water, decoct to 70%, and take warm at any time.[141p]
    Lingzhi and Zhuyu Decoction treats phlegm, water retention, and symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and sour swallowing. Use 1.5 qian of Polygonatum, Alisma, and Poria, 2-3 qian of Rhizoma Pinelliae, 0.8 qian of roasted Licorice, and 1-2 qian of fried Ginger and Atractylodes, along with 1 qian of dried Tangerine Peel. Boil with 1.5 sheng of water. For simultaneous liver and kidney cold, add 1-2 qian of Cinnamon.

    Harmonizing Stomach Decoction treats cold and dampness hurting the spleen, cholera with vomiting and diarrhea, as well as phlegm and water retention, vague stomach discomfort, nausea, bloating, and abdominal pain. This is a variant of Pingwei San. Symptoms like vomiting often have weak stomach qi; just smelling Atractylodes can induce nausea, hence ginger is used instead. Use 1.5 qian each of Tangerine Peel, Magnolia Bark with ginger juice, 1-2 qian of dry ginger, and 1 qian of roasted Licorice, boiled with 1.5 sheng of water. Take when warm after boiling for seven minutes. Substances like Patchouli, Guo Oil, Clove, Poria, Pinellia, Hyacinth Bean, Sand Ginger, and Alisma can be added as needed. If there is stagnation in the chest and abdomen along with seasonal cold and heat, add Chaihu.

    Gas Expelling Decoction treats reversed qi, food stagnation, bloating, and vomiting. Use 1.5 qian each of Tangerine Peel, Patchouli, and Bitter Orange, 2 qian each of Cyperus, Alisma, and Radix Linderae, and 0.7-1 qian of Wood Fragrance, along with 1 qian of Magnolia Bark. Boil with 1.5 sheng of water, simmer for seven minutes, and take hot.[142p]
    Da He Zhong Drink: Treats stagnation of diet leading to symptoms such as vomiting.
    Ingredients: Chenpi 1-2 qian, Zhishi 1 qian, Sharen 0.5 qian, Shan Zha, Mai Ya each 2 qian, Zexie, Houpok each 1.5 qian.
    Preparation: In 1.5 sheng of water, boil down to 7-8 parts, and take warm after meals.

    Xiao He Zhong Drink: Treats symptoms of chest and diaphragm fullness, discomfort, and vomiting.
    Ingredients: Chenpi, Fuling, Houpok each 1.5 qian, Shan Zha meat, fried Bian Dou each 2 qian, Gancao 0.5 qian.
    Preparation: In 1.5 sheng of water, add 3-5 slices of fresh ginger and boil to drink.

    Da Fen Qing Drink: Treats accumulation of heat, obstruction, not passing water, vomiting, and related symptoms.
    Ingredients: Fuling, Zexie, Mutong each 2 qian, Zhuling, Zhike, Zhi Zi (or doubled), Cheqianzi each 1 qian.
    Preparation: In 1.5 sheng of water, boil down to 8 parts, and take warm after meals.

    Xiao Fen Qing Drink: Treats difficulties in passing water, damp stagnation, vomiting, swelling, and inability to receive nourishment.
    Ingredients: Fuling, Zexie, Zhuling each 2-3 qian, Yi Ren 2 qian, Zhike, Houpok each 1 qian.
    Preparation: In 1.5 sheng of water, boil down to 7-8 parts, and take before meals.

    Shen Xiang San: Treats pains and discomfort in the chest, abdomen, and stomach, unresolving cold, pain, vomiting, fullness, phlegm-blockage, ineffective medications, this is the most effective.
    Ingredients: Dingxiang, Bai Doukou or Sharen can also be used.[143p]
    Two flavors are equally divided into powder, and mixed with clear broth in a ratio of five to seven parts; for severe cases, one qian, taken daily without restriction.

    Chai Hu Decoction: Used for external conditions of wind and cold, with symptoms of fever, chills, headaches, body aches, and vomiting. Ingredients: Chai Hu (3-5 grams), Fang Feng, Gan Cao each (3 grams), Chen Pi (4.5 grams), Shao Yao (6 grams), fresh ginger (3-5 slices). Combine with one and a half sheng of water, boil down to seven or eight parts, and take while hot.

    Chai Chen Decoction: Treats wind-cold alongside cough, fever, fullness, phlegm, and vomiting. Ingredients: Chai Hu (6-9 grams), Chen Pi (4.5 grams), Gan Cao (3 grams), Ban Xia, Fu Ling each (6 grams), fresh ginger (3-7 slices). Combine with one and a half sheng of water, boil down to seven parts, and take warm away from meals.

    Chou Xin Decoction: Used for all types of vomiting, especially when there is severe internal heat that should not be replenished. Ingredients: Huang Qin, Shi Hu, Mu Tong, Zhi Zi (roasted), Huang Lian each (3-6 grams), fine Gan Cao (1.5 grams), Zhi Qiao, Ze Xie each (1.5 grams). Combine with one and a half sheng of water, boil down to seven parts, and take warm away from meals. If internal heat is severe, cold consumption is even better.

    Tai Qing Decoction: Treats stomach fire leading to irritability and vomiting. Used in conjunction with Bai Hu Tang. Ingredients: Zhi Mu, Shi Hu, Mu Tong each (4.5 grams), Sheng Shi Gao (15-21 grams). Combine with one and a half sheng of water, boil down to seven parts, and can be taken warm or cold. May also add Mai Men Dong.[144p]
    Four-Flavored Rejuvenating Decoction: Treats vomiting, vacuity of original yang, and imminent danger.
    Ingredients: 1-2 taels of ginseng, 2-3 qian of prepared aconite, 2-3 qian of dry ginger (roasted), 1-2 qian of honey-fried licorice.
    Instructions: Boil in 2 sheng of water over strong heat until reduced to 7-8 parts; take warm and sip gradually.

    Six-Flavored Rejuvenating Decoction: Treats vomiting and symptoms of impending loss of yin and yang.
    Ingredients: 1-2 taels or several qian of ginseng, 1 qian of honey-fried licorice, 2-3 qian of prepared aconite, 2-3 qian of dry ginger (roasted), 5 qian or 1 tael of cooked rehmannia, 3 qian of angelica root. Replace with winter melon if there is diarrhea or bleeding.
    Instructions: Boil in 2 sheng of water over strong heat until reduced to 7-8 parts; take warm.

    Yin Regulating Decoction: Treats weakness of true yin, fullness and distension, nausea due to phlegm and fluid, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, etc.
    Ingredients: 3-5-7 qian or 1-2 taels of cooked rehmannia, 1-2 qian of honey-fried licorice, 2-3 or 5-7 qian of angelica root, 1-3 qian of roasted dry ginger, optionally add 1-2 qian of cinnamon.
    Instructions: Boil in 2 sheng of water until reduced to 7-8 parts; take hot.

    Warm Stomach Decoction: Treats middle cold with vomiting, sour regurgitation, diarrhea, lack of appetite; and women's cold in the viscera causing nausea and instability of the fetus.
    Ingredients: 1-2-3 qian or 1 tael of ginseng, 1-2 qian or 1 tael of roasted white atractylodes, 2 qian of roasted hyacinth bean, 1 qian of aged tangerine peel (or omit), 1 qian of honey-fried licorice, 1-2-3 qian of burnt dry ginger, 1-2 qian of angelica root (do not use if there is diarrhea).
    Instructions: Boil in 2 sheng of water until reduced to 7 parts; take warm away from meals.[145p]
    Shen Jiang Drink: Treats the deficiency of the spleen, stomach, and lung qi, coldness, vomiting, coughing with shortness of breath, and symptoms such as children vomiting milk. Use 5 fen or 1-2 qian of dried ginger; or 3-5 pieces of cooked fresh ginger; 3-5 qian of ginseng, or double the amount; 3-5 fen of honey-fried licorice. Combine with 1.5 sheng of water, boil down to 7-8 fen, and take slowly.

    Huang Ya Pills: Treats cold deficiency of the spleen and stomach, issues with digesting food, bloating, diarrhea, sour regurgitation, and vomiting. Use 2 liang of ginseng; 3 qian of charred dried ginger; refine white honey into pills the size of fox nuts, and chew regularly.

    Yi Qi Dan: Treats cold deficiency of the spleen and stomach, and symptoms of vomiting. Use equal parts of ginseng and processed Aconite; refine white honey to the size of jade beans. Take 3-5 fen or 1 qian with hot white soup. This pill is convenient for carrying during travel.

    Wen Zang Pills: Treats vomiting due to intestinal worms. Use appropriate amounts of ginseng, or none if preferred; 4 liang of white atractylodes soaked and fried; 4 liang of angelica root charred in wine; 1 liang of peony root charred; 1 liang of poria; 1 liang of fine nut flesh; 1 liang of prepared fruits of the Sophora genus; 2 liang of dried ginger; 2 liang of Wu Zhi Yu soaked overnight in broth and fried. Grind the latter into a powder, mix with shen qu paste to form pills the size of tung seeds. Take 50-70 pills or 100 pills with hot water when hungry.[146p]
    Sheng Zhuan Decoction treats cold, dampness, diarrhea, and vomiting; it is especially a sacred medicine. Use five to eight qian of winter white atractylodes, roasted, or one to two liang of dried ginger and cinnamon, each one to two qian, and dried tangerine peel as needed or not. Add one and a half bowls of water, decoct to seven parts, and take warm.

    Single Formulas

    For vomiting leading to sudden death due to yin collapse: drink three sheng of freshly drawn water, which is excellent.

    For heart pain with vomiting of water, unable to take food, with fluctuating conditions: two liang of yellow lead, two jin of vinegar, decoct over a slow fire to make a paste, then mix with steamed flatbread to form pills the size of a walnut. Take seven pills, washed down with ginger soup.

    For sudden vomiting, unable to eat: two qian of raw talc powder taken with warm water; also press fine flour with half a cup to stabilize.

    For weak stomach, vomiting, and inability to eat: use two seeds of cardamom, half a liang of galangal, ten bowls of water, boil to extract the juice, add half a cup of fresh ginger juice, and make dough for a knife, cooking it with lamb broth. Eat while hollow.

    For vomiting clear water: decoct and sip dried wormwood.

    For vomiting immediately after eating: four liang of rhubarb, two liang of licorice, three sheng of water, boil to one and a half sheng, and take in two doses.[147p]
    Nausea and vomiting with internal cold phlegm: Take one sheng of Banxia, wash, dry, and grind it; one sheng of wheat flour, mix with water to make pill-sized balls, boil until cooked, and initially swallow four or five pills, taking three times a day, gradually increasing to fifteen pills. Cook and swallow them quickly, feeling the illness lessening you can repeat. Avoid mutton and sugar. This is the formula by Xu Renze.

    For persistent dry retching: Squeeze the juice from kudzu root, take one sheng, and it will heal.

    For continuous vomiting: One large heaping cup of white sesame oil, half a pound of clear oil, simmer to extract three cups, remove the sesame and consume warm.

    For unceasing vomiting: Grind hemp seeds into water to extract juice, add a little salt and eat it, which works immediately. Li Jianyi frequently used it, very effective.

    For drunken vomiting: Boil red beans to extract juice and sip slowly.

    For continuous vomiting: One cup of real fire wine and one cup of freshly drawn well water, mix and consume; it is very effective.

    For dry retching: Chew fresh ginger frequently; it is a sacred remedy for vomiting.

    For persistent vomiting: One tael of fresh ginger, two heaping cups of vinegar sauce, boil with silver ware to extract four cups, drink it along with the dregs. It also kills internal parasites.

    For head-related nausea and vomiting caused by cold stomach phlegm: Use two and a half qian of Sichuan dried ginger and one and two-tenths qian of fried licorice, with one and a half zhong of water, simmer to reduce by half and take, repeatedly effective.[148p]

    • For noisy vomiting: Use genuine orange peel, remove the white part and grind it into powder. At the fifth watch, take five parts on your palm and lick it, then sleep. It will certainly be effective within three days. If the peel is not genuine, it will not work.

    • For vomiting phlegm and water: Take one white betel nut, cook it thoroughly, two and a half qian of orange peel, roast and grind into powder. With one cup of water, decoct it down to half a cup and take it warm.

    • For sour heart vomiting: Use four taels of betel nut and one tael of orange peel, grind into powder. Take a small spoonful with honey water on an empty stomach.

    • For vomiting and seizure: Drink the juice of Caulis Aristolochiae.

    • For persistent dry heaving: Take half a sheng of sugarcane juice warm, three times a day, adding ginger juice for better effect.

    • For stomach cold nausea and gas obstruction: Use three mother cloves and one piece of aged orange peel (remove the white part and roast), decoct with water and take warm.

    • For phlegm stagnation and nausea, with a feeling of fullness in the chest that does not allow for drinking or eating: Use one tael of magnolia bark, roast with ginger juice until yellow and grind into powder. Mix with two qian of non-seasonal rice drink and take.

    • For persistent nausea and inability to eat: Use two taels of myrobalan fruit peel, fry and grind into a paste the size of a walnut, take twenty pills with warm water, three times a day.

    • For nausea due to a change in weather, vomiting immediately after eating: Boil one egg in water for three to five boils, then soak in cold water for a short while and swallow it.[149p]
      Continuous vomiting without distinction between men and women, if porridge, drinks, and medicines cannot be ingested for several days, then the following remedy can be effective: pulverize five-spice fatty resin, mix it with dog bile to form pills the size of lotus seeds. Take one pill at a time, dissolve it in hot ginger wine, and swallow it quickly without rinsing the mouth; then immediately press down with a small amount of warm porridge.

    For vomiting due to spleen deficiency: take half a pound of raw lamb, mix it with garlic, shallots, fermented black beans, and five flavors, and consume on an empty stomach.

    After a disease caused by heavenly influence leading to vomiting and rejection of food: use a fresh lamb liver as a mild dish, and after no more than three doses, food should stay down.

    For sour water vomiting: take ten sheep droppings, two cups of wine, boil down to one cup, and take it all at once; if not resolved, take again, guaranteed to be effective. Alternatively, boiling the urine of a boy and consuming up to three liters will cure it.

    For vomiting after eating: two taels of burnt deer antler ash, one tael of ginseng, ground into powder, take with ginger soup using a spoon size, three times a day.

    For sour vomit: brew the outer layer of a special bean, take one cup, it will be effective.

    For vomiting and regurgitation due to cold deficiency, unable to consume food: half a tael of Asarum without leaves, two and a half qian of cloves, ground into powder, take one qian with persimmon stem soup.

    For persistent vomiting and coldness: take three jin of reed root, chop it and boil in water for a thick juice, drink frequently up to two liters of it.[150p]
    Nausea without cease: Mix vinegar with flour to make two or three dozen small balls, boil them in hot water, strain out, and throw them into cool water. Wait until warm, swallow three or two balls; if nausea stops, there is no need to swallow more; if it does not stop, swallow again in the evening.

    For nausea, with a feeling of tightness in the chest: Take eight taels of fresh ginger, three sheng of water, boil down to one sheng. Wash five he of pinellia; with five sheng of water, boil down to one sheng, mix the juices and continue to boil down to one and a half sheng. Divide and take.

    For dry heaving or vomiting: Equal parts of pinellia and dried ginger; chew them together and boil with one and a half sheng of water, take seven he at once, three times a day.

    For patients with dry heaving: Take a cup of sheep’s milk to drink.

    For dry heaving: Soak horse bean overnight in wine, take the juice and drink.

    Another remedy: Boil three sheng of fermented soybean curd, drink the juice, beneficial.

    Another remedy: Drink one sheng of ginger juice on an empty stomach.

    For nausea: Take one sheng of bitter gourd pulp and seeds, crush them, and with three sheng of wine and water, boil down to one sheng, take at once; shortly after, you may vomit and have a bowel movement, like shrimp skin.

    Another remedy: Drink one hundred days of urine, beneficial.

    Another remedy: Take one sheng of hemp seeds, roast until fragrant, mash to extract three sheng of wine, let it cook down to one sheng, drink it all, twice a day; finishing one stone will cure all ailments, allowing one to eat and drink. If unable to drink wine, have as much as you desire.[151p]
    Prescription for Managing Food and Drink Reactions: Take three sheng of either raw or cooked soup all at once, then stop. For upper abdominal distress and vomiting: take two sheng of mustard seed, ground into a powder, and form into honey pills. Take with well water during the early hours, like taking seven pills daily, twice a day. It can also be taken as a powder on an empty stomach or soaked in alcohol.

    Acupuncture Techniques:

    The "Suwen" states: In cases of heart heat disease, heat causes sudden heart pain, restlessness, tendency to vomit, headache, red face, and no sweating; needle the hand's lesser yin and sun meridians. In cases of spleen heat disease, there is initial heaviness in the head, cheek pain, anxiety with a bluish complexion, desire to vomit with body heat; needle the foot's greater yin and yang ming meridians. The "Lingshu" states: Tendency to vomit with bitter fluid, prolonged sighing, a feeling of dread in the heart, fear of being captured—indicative of bile stagnation and reverse qi in the stomach. If bile leaks, the mouth becomes bitter; if stomach qi reverses, there will be bitter vomiting, thus it is called "vomiting bile." Acupuncture should be applied three cun below the stomach to relieve the reversed qi. If reversed, needle the lesser yang blood vessels to close the bile and adjust its excess and deficiency to expel the pathogenic factor. The "Jia Yi Jing" states: In cases of heat illness, if sweating does not occur along with bitter vomiting and restlessness, the "Chengguang" point is the main treatment. For symptoms of wind in the head and neck, lacking sweat, with chilling and coldness, nausea, tight eyes radiating pain to the back of the head, and heaviness with neck pain, the "Yuzhen" point is the main treatment. For drunkenness with wind-heat, with pain in both temples, inability to eat or drink, and frequent vomiting, the "Shu Gu" point is utilized. For severe cold damage with heat, leading to restlessness and vomiting, the "Dazhui" point is the main treatment.[152p]
    Back pain with aversion to cold, stiff spine when bending or stretching, difficulty in eating, frequent vomiting with excessive saliva, the governing point is the diaphragm (ge shu). Chest and flanks feeling distended and full, back pain, aversion to wind and cold, inability to eat, vomiting that does not stay down, the governing point is the spirit gate (hun men).

    Shivering with chills and convulsions, inability to extend the hands, coughing with phlegm, gas in the chest leading to frequent vomiting, unable to sweat from the temples, feeling disturbed and full, due to convulsions and bloody coughing, the governing point is the chi ze. Pain on the left side and pressure on the right, pressure on the right side and pain on the left.

    With fever, feeling restless and sweating continuously, elbows cramping and swelling, incessant laughter, pain in the heart, red and yellow eyes, blood in urine, feeling nauseous, heat in the chest, feeling bitter and uneasy, sighing deeply, throat dryness and hoarseness, wheezing, body feels hot as fire, head pain feels explosive, shortness of breath with chest pain, the governing point is tai ling.

    With fever, feeling restless and nauseous, experiencing a sense of fullness and heat in the chest that moves, the governing point is jian si.

    With fever and abdominal fullness, good at vomiting and feeling irritated, the governing point is da du.[153p]
    In cases of high fever where sweat does not emerge, with a tendency to vomit, experiencing bitterness and spasms, the body feels contorted, the mouth is locked and makes a sound like sucking, pain in the waist prevents turning, and when trying to turn it feels like being pulled, a tendency to weep, blood can be drawn from above and below, and seeing blood immediately ends the condition.

    For malaria, there is a reversed cough, a heavy heart making it impossible to lie down, severe vomiting, more heat and less cold, desire to close doors and windows, cold extremities with hot feet, treatable at the Taixi point.

    In conditions of yang exhaustion, cold and dread prevail, a hard lower abdomen and headaches, pain in the legs, thighs, and belly, discomfort in digestion, weak urination, and tendency to vomit, treatable at the Sanli point.

    With coughing and vomiting from the diaphragm, unable to eat cold food, alternating cold and heat, skin and flesh pains, shortness of breath preventing sleep, fullness in the chest, tension along the sides, abdominal pain, sharp pain in the stomach, upper breathlessness, coldness and pain in the shoulders and back, no sweat, throat obstruction with abdominal pain, accumulation, silent desire for sleep, lethargy and reluctance to move, persistent dampness in the body, and unshakeable heart pain, treatable at the Pishu point.[154p]
    The lungs are in distress, with pain in the chest, aversion to cold and fullness in the chest, feeling anxious and prone to vomiting bile, heat in the chest, wheezing and counterflow of qi, qi pursuing one another, excessive thick phlegm, inability to breathe, wind in the shoulders and back, sweating, swelling of the face and abdomen, stagnant food causing discomfort in the diaphragm, inability to eat, throat blockage, shoulder oppression, lung distension, skin and bone pain, alternating cold and heat with fullness; the Middle Palace governs this.

    Chill and dryness, troubled tongue, numbness in the arms, frothy saliva and dry lips urging drinking, wrist cramps, finger and limb pain, lung distension with shortness of breath, wind in the ears, cough with wheezing and blockage, arm pain and vomiting, inability to eat or drink, feeling bloated; the Lesser Commerce governs this.

    Alternating cold and heat with coughing and froth, heat in the palms, weakness leading to chills in the shoulders and arms, breath too shallow to sustain, chills and faintness in both hands, alternating cold and heat, restlessness when hungry, good or bad disposition when full, complexion changing, mouth unable to open, aversion to wind and weeping; the Channel Divergence governs this.

    Alternating cold and heat with a tendency to vomit; the Merchant’s Hill governs this.[155p]
    During cold and vomiting, there may be mild heat, fullness beneath the ribs, sore throat and dryness in the throat, pain on the outer side of the knee, weakness in the limbs, swelling under the armpit, and pain from knife injury on the shoulder. The Tai Chong point governs this.

    For Qi hernia causing hiccups, vomiting, and facial swelling, as well as spasm, the Tian Shu point governs it.

    When there is pulling between the chest, ribs, and back, a heavy feeling below the heart, excessive vomiting and salivation, and inability to eat, the You Men point governs it.

    When there is coughing, reversed breathing, inability to catch one's breath, vomiting with a feeling of fullness in the chest, and inability to eat, the Yu Fu point governs it.

    When there is chest fullness, coughing, reversed breathing, troublesome fullness leading to vomiting, and inability to eat, the Shen Cang point governs it.

    When there is chest fullness with no vomiting, bitter taste in the mouth, dry tongue, and inability to eat, the Dan Yu point governs it.

    When there is fullness in the chest and ribs, painful joints and bones, inability to eat, upward vomiting, and heart distress, the Zi Gong point governs it.

    With fullness in the chest and ribs and obstruction of the diaphragm preventing eating and causing vomiting, as well as food regurgitation, the Zhong Ting point governs it.

    If food is impacted, there may be fullness under the ribs with difficulty turning, blueness in the eyes, and vomiting, the Qi Men point governs this.

    With fullness under the ribs and reverse vomiting, the Yang Ling Quan point governs it.[156p]
    Stomach cold and distended, excessive eating, body thin, abdomen full and rumbling, abdominal wind causing pain, fullness in chest and sides, vomiting, pain in the spine, muscle contractions, inability to eat; the stomach point governs this. Headache with inability to eat, intestinal rumbling and swelling, urge to vomit and loose stools; the Sanjiao point governs this. Food and drink undigested, entering the abdomen and then exiting; the lower stomach point governs this.

    Abdomen rumbling persistently, food undigested, pain in the sides preventing sleep, restlessness and heat leading to a lack of appetite, fullness in the chest and sides, shortness of breath and rushing sensation, diaphragmatic vomiting and heart pain, along with excess fullness leading to yellowing of the body, rapid weight loss; the Zhangmen point governs this. Difficulty urinating with pain, milky discharge, sudden hernia, swelling in the lower abdomen, cough, reverse vomiting, sudden suddenness, back pain that prevents bending or raising, face hot and dark, full abdomen, body heat leading to pain; the Xingjian point governs this. Dizziness from wind with tendency to vomit, restlessness and fullness; the Shentang point governs this. If the face is blue, the Shangxing point governs this. For the Shangxing point, first treat the Yinxi, then the Tianyou and Fengchi points.

    Wind in the head and body, tendency to vomit and feel anxious, experiencing cold, short of breath, heat in the palms, urgency in the abdomen, swelling in the armpits; the Jianzhong point governs this. Generally, frequent sighing with loss of appetite, many cold and hot sensations, sweating; when the illness progresses, there is a tendency to vomit; once vomiting ceases, weakness follows—treat with the Gongsun and Jingyu points. If there is significant pain and rigidity in the intestines, swelling in the face, manic heart condition, excessive drinking leading to swelling, large stasis in the abdomen, heat and pain, inability to sleep, and cholera; the Gongsun point governs this. Vomiting and fullness; the Po point governs this.[157p]
    Huang Dan is good for deficiency, with fullness beneath the ribs wanting to vomit, governed by the spleen point.

    When food and drink lead to persistent vomiting, and speech is difficult, governed by the Tonggu point.

    With fullness, body heat and painful deficiency between the ribs, governed by the Xingjian point.

    Cold and hot headaches feel like breaking, with painful eyes and shortness of breath, restlessness, fullness leading to vomiting and difficult speech, governed by the Touwei point.

    With lung heat, breathing difficulties prevent lying down, shortness of breath with foamy vomit, breath chases each other, chest fullness, rib and breast urgency, difficult breathing, trembling, bounding pulse, qi stagnation, and heat in the chest, governed by the lung point.

    With qi pain, difficulty in urination, yellow urine, qi fullness obstructing urination, body alternating between cold and heat, reflux, urinary difficulty, abdominal fullness, governed by the Shimen point.

    The "Pulse Classic" states: If the left wrist guan (radial pulse) is absent in the cun (first position), there is no heart pulse. Bitter heart with toxic pain, heat in the palm, frequent nausea, and oral ulcers, puncture the hand’s taiyang channel, treat yang.

    If the left wrist guan is absent in the shang (second position), there is no liver pulse. Bitter difficulty in urination, urinary hesitation, evil qi beneath the ribs, with frequent vomiting, puncture the foot's shaoyang channel, treat yang.

    If the right wrist guan is absent in the shang (second position), there is no spleen pulse. Bitter shortness of breath with diarrhea, abdominal fullness, heaviness in the limbs, frequent vomiting, puncture the foot's yangming channel, treat yang.

    The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: The Qimen point governs blue eyes and vomiting.[158p]
