    故曰，脾喜暖而恶寒，土恶湿而喜燥，所以东垣《脾胃论》特着温补之法，盖特为胃气而设，庸可忽哉！第在河间则言呕因胃火，是火多实。兹余言呕因胃寒，是寒多虚也。一热一寒，若皆失中和之论。不知呕因火者，非谓其必无，但因火而呕者少，因寒而呕者多；因胃实而呕者少，因胃虚而呕者多，故不得不有此辨。　　虚呕之治，但当以温胃补脾为主，宜人参理中汤为正治。[73p]

    Therefore, it is said that the spleen prefers warmth and dislikes cold, the earth dislikes dampness and enjoys dryness. For this reason, the "Treatise on the Spleen and Stomach" by Dongyuan particularly emphasizes the method of warming and tonifying, which is specifically set for the stomach qi and should not be overlooked! In Hejian, it is mentioned that vomiting arises from stomach fire, which is abundant and solid. Now, I say vomiting arises from stomach cold, which is abundant and deficient. Heat and cold, if both lose their balance, are not aligned with the principle of harmony. It is not to say that there are absolutely no cases of vomiting caused by heat; however, cases of vomiting due to heat are rare, while cases due to cold are common. Vomiting caused by a strong stomach is rare, while that caused by a weak stomach is frequent, hence the necessity for this distinction.

    For the treatment of vomiting due to deficiency, the approach should focus on warming the stomach and tonifying the spleen, and it is appropriate to use Ren Shen Li Zhong Tang as the primary remedy.[73p]

    或温胃饮、圣朮煎、参姜饮之类，亦可酌用；或黄芽丸尤为最妙。若胃口寒甚者，宜附子理中汤，或四味回阳饮，或一气丹主之。若虚在阴分，水泛为痰而呕吐者，宜金水六君煎；虚甚者宜理阴煎，或六味回阳饮。若久病胃虚不能纳榖者，但当以前法酌治之。若胃气微虚而兼痰者，宜六君子汤主之。凡中毒而吐者，当察其所中者何物。盖中热毒而吐者，宜解以寒苦之剂；中阴寒之毒而吐泻不止者，宜解以温热之剂。若因吐泻而脾胃致虚者，非大加温补不可。此证有中寒毒吐泻，治按在后，当并阅之。[74p]

    One may also use warming stomach drinks, such as Sheng Zhu decoction and Ren Ginger drink, or Huang Ya pills, which are particularly effective. If the stomach feels very cold, one should take Fu Zi Li Zhong Decoction, or Si Wei Hui Yang drink, or Yi Qi Dan. If there is deficiency in the yin part, resulting in water retention manifesting as phlegm and vomiting, one should use Jin Shui Liu Jun decoction; if deficiency is severe, then Li Yin decoction or Liu Wei Hui Yang drink should be considered. If there is a long-standing illness causing stomach deficiency and an inability to digest grains, one should treat it as previously mentioned. If there is mild stomach deficiency combined with phlegm, one should use Liu Jun Zi soup. In cases of poisoning accompanied by vomiting, one must ascertain the substance causing the poisoning. Those who vomit due to heat toxins should be treated with cold and bitter remedies; if the cause is cold yin toxins leading to continuous vomiting and diarrhea, one should resolve it with warming remedies. If vomiting and diarrhea have led to spleen and stomach deficiency, it is essential to provide substantial warming and nourishment. This condition involves cold toxin causing vomiting and diarrhea; the treatment is detailed later and should be reviewed.[74p]

    　　　　　实证

    　　凡实邪在胃而作呕者，必有所因，必有见证。若因寒滞者，必多疼痛；因食滞者，必多胀满；因气逆者，必痛胀连于胁肋；因火郁者，必烦热燥渴，脉洪而滑；因外感者，必头身发热，脉数而紧。如无实证实脉而见呕吐者，切不可以实邪论治。　　寒邪犯胃而作呕者，其证有三：一以食饮寒凉或误食性寒生冷等物，致伤胃气，因而作呕。若果寒滞未散而兼胀兼痛者，宜温中行滞，以大小和中饮、神香散，或二陈汤加姜桂之类主之，或和胃饮亦佳。　　一以阴寒气令，或雨水沙气，及水土寒湿之邪犯胃，因而作呕作泄。[75p]

    Evidence of Pathology

    Any instance of food stagnation in the stomach leading to vomiting must have a causative factor and supporting evidence. If due to cold stagnation, it will be accompanied by significant pain; if due to food stagnation, there will be substantial bloating; if due to reversed qi, pain and bloating will extend to the ribs; if due to fire constraint, symptoms will include restlessness, dryness, thirst, and a rapid, slippery pulse; if caused by external pathogens, there will be fever in the head and body, with a rapid and tense pulse. If vomiting occurs without concrete evidence of excess conditions or a strong pulse, one must not treat it as an excess pathology.

    When cold pathogens invade the stomach causing vomiting, there are three presentations: Firstly, ingestion of cold or raw foods or mistakenly eating items that are cold in nature can harm the stomach qi and lead to vomiting. If cold stagnation persists, accompanied by bloating and pain, the appropriate approach is to warm the center and move the stagnation using balanced herbal formulas such as Xiao He (Harmonizing Middle) drink, Shen Xiang San, or adding ginger and cinnamon to Er Chen Tang, or using He Wei Yin. Secondly, it may also be due to cold, damp atmospheric conditions, such as rainy weather or cold, wet soil invading the stomach, resulting in vomiting and diarrhea.[75p]

    若寒滞未散而或胀或痛者，宜温中散寒，以平胃散、神香散、加减二陈汤、除湿汤、局方四七汤、大七香丸之类主之。　　一以风寒外感，或伤寒，或痎疟。凡邪在少阳，表邪未解而渐入里，所以外为寒热，内作呕吐。盖少阳之经，下胸中贯膈而然，此半表半里证也。治宜解表散寒，以柴陈煎、小柴胡汤、正柴胡饮之类主之。若微呕微吐者，邪在少阳。若大呕大吐者，此又邪在阳明，胃家病也。宜二陈汤，或不换金正气散、藿香正气散之类主之。若胃虚兼寒者，惟理中汤、温胃饮之类为宜。　　饮食伤胃而作呕者，如果留滞未消，而兼胀痛等证，宜大和中饮、排气饮、神香散之类主之。或启脾丸亦可酌用。如食已消而呕未止，宜温胃饮主之。[76p]

    If there are signs of cold stagnation yet symptoms of swelling or pain, it is advisable to warm the middle and disperse the cold, using medicines such as Ping Wei San, Shen Xiang San, Jia Jian Er Chen Tang, Chu Shi Tang, Ju Fang Si Qi Tang, and Da Qi Xiang Wan.

    Firstly, this may be caused by an external invasion of wind-cold, or it could be due to cold damage or intermittent fever. When the pathogen is in the Shao Yang, and the exterior pathogen has not resolved but is gradually entering the interior, it manifests as cold and heat on the outside, and vomiting on the inside. This is a condition of being half in the exterior and half in the interior. The treatment should focus on resolving the exterior and dispersing the cold with medicines like Chai Chen Jian, Xiao Chai Hu Tang, and Zheng Chai Hu Yin. If there is slight nausea or vomiting, the pathogen is in the Shao Yang. If there is severe nausea and vomiting, this indicates a pathology in the Yang Ming, related to the stomach. One should use Er Chen Tang, or consider Bu Huan Jin Zheng Qi San or Huo Xiang Zheng Qi San. If there is a deficiency in the stomach accompanied by cold, the appropriate remedies would be Li Zhong Tang and Wen Wei Yin.

    If the eating and drinking have harmed the stomach and caused vomiting, and there is retention of undigested food along with swelling and pain, it is advisable to use Da He Zhong Yin, Pai Qi Yin, or Shen Xiang San. Alternatively, you may also consider Qi Pi Wan. If the food has been digested but the vomiting persists, one should prescribe Wen Wei Yin.[76p]

    　　火在中焦而作呕者，必有火证火脉，或为热渴，或为烦躁，脉必洪数，吐必涌猛，形气声色，必皆壮丽。若察其真有火邪，但降其火，呕必自止。火微兼虚者，宜外台黄芩汤，或半夏泻心汤。火甚者，宜抽薪饮，或大小分清饮。若暑热犯胃，多渴多呕，气虚烦躁，而火有不清者，竹叶石膏汤。若热甚呕吐不止，而火在阳明兼头痛者，白虎汤，或太清饮，或六一散。若冒暑呕吐而火不甚者，宜香薷饮，或五物香薷饮俱可。　　痰饮留于胸中，或寒湿在胃，水停中脘而作呕吐者，宜和胃二陈煎、苓朮二陈煎，或小半夏加茯苓汤、橘皮半夏汤之类，皆可酌用。[77p]

    If there is vomiting due to fire in the middle burner, there must be symptoms of fire and a rapid pulse. It may be accompanied by heat thirst or restlessness, with a pulse that is surging and rapid; vomiting will be forceful, and the overall appearance will be robust. If it is determined that there is indeed a fire pathogen, then reducing the fire will stop the vomiting. If the fire is mild and combined with deficiency, one should use the external formula Huangqin decoction or Banxia Xiexin decoction. If the fire is severe, one should use Chouxin beverage or the major and minor Liangqing drink. If summer heat invades the stomach, causing great thirst and vomiting, with qi deficiency and restlessness, and the fire is not clear, one should use Bamboo leaf and Gypsum decoction. If the heat is severe and vomiting does not stop, with fire in the Yangming and headaches, one should use Baihu decoction, or Taiqing drink, or Liuyi powder. If there is summer heat causing vomiting but the fire is not intense, one should use Xiangru drink or the Five Ingredients Xiangru drink.

    If there is phlegm and fluid retained in the chest, or cold dampness in the stomach, causing water to stagnate in the middle burner and resulting in vomiting, one should use Hewei Erchen decoction, Lingzhi and Bai Zhu Erchen decoction, or Xiao Banxia Jia Fuling decoction or Chenpi Banxia decoction, all of which can be used appropriately.[77p]

    　　气逆作呕者，多因郁怒致动肝气，胃受肝邪，所以作呕。然胃强者未必易动，而易动者多因胃虚。故凡致此者，必当顾胃气，宜六君子汤，或理中汤主之。若逆气未散，或多胀满者，宜二陈汤，或橘皮半夏汤之类主之；或神香散亦佳。　　疟痢作呕者，在疟疾则以表邪内陷。凡邪在少阳阳明太阴者皆能作呕，表解呕必自止。在痢疾之呕，则多因胃气虚寒。盖表非寒邪，无以成疟；里非寒邪，无以成痢。病不知本，尚何医云？二证方论，具载本门。　　朝食午吐，午食晚吐，或朝食暮吐，详后反胃门。　　方治呕吐之极，或反胃粥汤入胃即吐垂死者，人参二两，水一升，煮四合，热服，日再进。兼以人参煮粥食之，即不吐。[78p]

    Nausea and vomiting due to reversed qi are often caused by suppressed anger that stirs liver qi, affecting the stomach with liver evil, hence the vomiting occurs. However, a strong stomach may not easily be disturbed, while a more easily disturbed stomach often signifies weakness. Therefore, for such cases, one must pay attention to the stomach qi, suggesting the use of Six Gentlemen Decoction or Regulation of the Middle Decoction. If the reversed qi has not dispersed, or if there is significant distension, one should use Erchen Decoction or a similar prescription such as Orange Peel and Pinellia Decoction; Shenxiang Powder is also good.

    For vomiting caused by malaria and dysentery, in malaria, it results from external evil penetrating inward. Any pathogen residing in the Shaoyang, Yangming, or Taiyin can cause vomiting. When the exterior is resolved, the vomiting will stop. In the case of dysenteric vomiting, it is often due to weak and cold stomach qi. Indeed, if the exterior is not a cold evil, malaria cannot develop; if the interior is not a cold evil, dysentery cannot occur. If the illness does not understand its root, what can be treated? Discussions of two syndromes are fully recorded in relevant texts.

    Vomiting after breakfast, after lunch, or after breakfast and into the evening should be detailed later under the topic of reversed stomach.

    For extreme cases of vomiting or when vomit causes near death upon ingestion of congee or soup, use two taels of ginseng, one liter of water, boiled until reduced to four portions, and administer while hot, twice daily. Additionally, consuming congee made with ginseng will prevent vomiting.[78p]

    　　　　　吐蛔

    　　凡吐蛔者，必因病而吐蛔，非因蛔而致吐也，故不必治其蛔，而但治其所以吐，则蛔自止矣。　　有因胃火而吐蛔者，以内热之甚，蛔无所容而出也，但清其火，火清而蛔自静，轻者抽薪饮，甚者万应丸之属是也。　　有因胃寒而吐蛔者，以内寒之甚，蛔不能存而出也，但温其胃，胃暖而蛔自安，仲景乌梅丸之属是也。　　有因胃虚无食而吐蛔者，以仓廪空虚，蛔因求食而上出者，此胃气大虚之候，速宜补胃温中，以防根本之败，如温胃饮、理中汤、圣朮煎之属是也。　　以上三者，固皆治蛔之法。然蛔有死者，有活者。若吐死蛔，则但治呕如前可也。若活蛔上出不已，则不得不有以逐之。盖蛔性畏酸苦，但加乌梅为佐使，则蛔自伏也。若胃实火盛者，可加苦楝根，或黄连亦善。其有未尽者，俱详列诸虫本门，及后条吐蛔治按之中。[79p]

    Expulsion of Tapeworms

    When one expels tapeworms, it is always due to an illness causing the expulsion, not the tapeworms causing vomiting. Therefore, it is unnecessary to treat the tapeworms directly; rather, one should treat the underlying cause of the vomiting, after which the tapeworms will cease to present themselves.

    For those who expel tapeworms due to excessive stomach heat, the internal heat is so severe that the tapeworms have nowhere to remain and thus come out. Simply cooling the heat will settle the tapeworms; for mild cases, herbal infusions to reduce the heat suffice, while for more severe conditions, the use of the "Ten Thousand Responding Pills" is applicable.

    For those who expel tapeworms due to excessive stomach cold, the internal cold is too potent, preventing the tapeworms from staying inside. Warming the stomach will restore calmness to the tapeworms, and remedies like "Wu Mei Pills" by Zhongjing can be used.

    If the expulsion is due to a deficiency of the stomach with no food, this indicates that the stomach storage is empty, leading the tapeworms to seek nourishment and thus come out. This is a sign of significant stomach qi deficiency; therefore, it is critical to nourish the stomach and warm the center to protect against fundamental failure, employing practices such as warming the stomach infusion, regulating the middle soup, and the "Sheng Zhu Decoction."

    The aforementioned three methods indeed address the tapeworms. However, it should be noted that there are dead and live tapeworms. If dead tapeworms are expelled, one may simply treat the vomiting as previously discussed. If live tapeworms continue to emerge, one must take measures to eliminate them. Tapeworms are instinctively deterred by sour and bitter substances, so adding Wu Mei as an adjunct will help subdue them. For cases of robust heat in the stomach, one may add bitter neem root or Coptis as they are also effective. Any lingering issues will be detailed in the subsequent sections on tapeworms and their treatment.[79p]

    　　　　　治呕气味论

    　　凡治胃虚呕吐，最须详审气味。盖邪实胃强者，能胜毒药，故无论气味优劣，皆可容受。惟胃虚气弱者，则有宜否之辨。而胃虚之甚者，则于气味之间，关系尤重。盖气虚者，最畏不堪之气，此不但腥臊耗散之气不能受，即微香微郁，并饮食之气，亦不能受，其他可知矣。胃弱者，最畏不堪之味，此非惟至苦极劣之味不能受、即微咸微苦，并五谷正味，亦不能受，而其他可知矣。此胃虚之呕，所以最重气味。使或略有不投，则入口便吐，终无益也。故凡治阳虚呕吐等证，则一切香散咸酸辛味不堪等物，悉当以己意相测，一有不妥，切不可用，但补其阳，阳回则呕必自止，此最确之法，不可忽也。[80p]

    On Treating Vomiting Caused by Weak Stomach

    In treating vomiting due to stomach deficiency, it is crucial to carefully consider the qualities of the substances used. For those with a strong stomach, even toxic substances can be tolerated, regardless of their qualities. However, for a weak stomach, differentiation of suitable and unsuitable substances becomes essential. The more severe the stomach weakness, the more significant the relationship between substances' qualities and the condition. A weak stomach is highly sensitive to unmanageable qualities. Not only can it not tolerate strong, fishy, or foul odors, but even mild fragrances and ordinary food smells can be intolerable. The same goes for those who are aware of their condition. A weak stomach is particularly sensitive to flavors; it cannot withstand extreme bitterness or poor tastes, nor can it tolerate even mild saltiness or bitterness, along with the intrinsic tastes of grains. This highlights why vomiting from stomach deficiency is so impacted by flavors. If there is any slight mismatch, it can lead to immediate vomiting upon ingestion, which offers no benefit. Therefore, in treating symptoms like vomiting due to yang deficiency, all fragrant, salty, sour, and spicy flavors should be measured with personal discretion. If anything appears unsuitable, it must not be used. Instead, one should focus on supplementing the yang; once the yang is restored, the vomiting will inevitably stop. This is the most reliable method and should not be neglected.[80p]

    余尝见一沈姓者，素业医，极多劳碌，且年及四旬，因患(疒颓)疝下坠，欲提使上升，自用盐汤吐法，不知胃虚畏咸，遂致吐不能止，汤水皆呕，如此者一日一夜，忽又大便下黑血一二碗，而脉则微渺如毛，几如将绝。此盖吐伤胃气，脾虚之极，兼以盐汤走血，故血不能摄，从便而下。余令速用人参姜附等剂，以回垂绝之阳，庶乎可疗。忽又一医至，曰：诸逆冲上，皆属火也。大便下血，亦因火也，尚堪用参附乎？宜速饮童便，则呕可愈而血亦止矣。其人以为有理，及童便下咽，即呕极不堪名状，呕不止而命随继之矣。呜呼！夫以胃强之人，亦且闻尿欲呕，况呕不能止而复可加以尿乎？此不惟死者堪怜，而妄用若此者，尚敢称医，诚可恶可恨也！故笔之于此，并以征气味之要。[81p]

    I once encountered a man with the surname Shen, who was a physician by trade and worked very hard. He was nearly forty years old and due to suffering from a hernia that fell downward, he attempted to raise it using a saline solution to induce vomiting. Unaware that his stomach was weak and could not tolerate salty substances, he ended up vomiting incessantly, with both salt water and food coming up for a whole day and night. Suddenly, he passed dark blood in his stool, one or two bowls worth, and his pulse became weak and barely detectable, almost as if it would stop altogether. This was due to the vomiting harming his stomach qi and the extreme weakness of his spleen, compounded by the saline solution which caused blood to flow, preventing it from being retained in the body.

    I instructed him to immediately use ginseng and ginger to revive the vital energy that was on the verge of collapse, hoping it might help. Suddenly, another physician arrived and said, "All rejections and upward pressures are related to heat. The blood in the stool is also due to heat; can we still use ginseng and ginger? It is better to quickly drink young boy's urine; then the vomiting can be cured, and the bleeding will stop." The man believed there was reasoning in this, and upon swallowing the urine, he experienced extreme nausea and continued to vomit uncontrollably, until his life subsequently faded away.

    Ah! Even a person with a strong stomach would feel nauseated at the mere thought of urine, let alone adding it to someone who cannot stop vomiting! It is not only pitiful for those who die this way but how resentful it is that such a practitioner dares to call himself a physician! Therefore, I write this to emphasize the importance of understanding the nature and characteristics of treatments.[81p]

    　　　　　恶心证治

    　　恶心证，胃口泛逆，兀兀不宁之病。凡恶心欲吐，口必流涎，咽之不下，愈咽愈恶，而呕吐继之。亦有不呕吐而时见恶心者。然此虽曰恶心，而实胃口之病，非心病也。此证之因，则有寒、有食、有痰饮、有秽气、有火邪、有阴湿伤胃，或伤寒疟痢诸邪之在胃口者，皆得有之。若欲察之，但当察其虚实寒热，则尽之矣。然实邪恶心者，邪去则止，其来速，其去亦速。虚邪恶心者，必得胃气大复，其病方愈。且此证惟虚寒者十居八九，即有实邪呕恶者，亦必其脾气不健，不能运化而然。此所以凡治恶心者，必当知有实中有虚，勿得妄行攻击，而胃气不可不顾也。　　虚寒恶心，其证最多，若非猝暴而常见，或形气不足之辈，悉以胃气弱也。故凡治此者，多宜以温补为主。[82p]

    Nausea Treatment

    Nausea is a condition characterized by a rebellious stomach, leading to discomfort and restlessness. Generally, when there is a desire to vomit, saliva will flow from the mouth, making swallowing difficult. The more one tries to swallow, the more nausea follows, often leading to vomiting. However, there are instances of nausea without actual vomiting. Although this condition is termed nausea, it fundamentally pertains to stomach issues rather than heart problems.

    The causes of this condition can include cold, food stagnation, phlegm and fluids, foul Qi, fire pathogens, and dampness injuring the stomach, or other pathogens from maladies like cold, malaria, or dysentery affecting the stomach. To understand it better, one must discern between deficiency and excess, and between cold and heat. In cases of excess, the nausea ceases once the pathogen is removed; it comes quickly and goes quickly. In cases of deficiency, the stomach Qi must be significantly restored for recovery to occur.

    Moreover, this condition is predominantly due to deficiency and cold, with at least eight or nine out of ten cases falling into this category. Even in cases of excess nausea, the spleen Qi is often weak and unable to properly transform food, leading to the symptoms. Therefore, in treating nausea, one must recognize the presence of both excess and deficiency, and avoid rash attacks while considering the importance of the stomach Qi.

    For cases of deficiency and cold nausea, these are the most frequent presentations. If not acute and common, or if individuals lack sufficient vitality, it is always due to weakened stomach Qi. Therefore, treatment should primarily focus on warming and strengthening.[82p]

    若脾胃微虚生痰，或兼吞酸嗳腐，咳嗽恶心者，宜六君子汤。若脾胃虚寒痰滞而恶心者，金水六君煎。若脾胃虚寒，或太阴自利，腹痛呕吐恶心者，温胃饮，或理中汤、圣朮煎。若脾肾虚寒，上下不能运行，或胀满，或呕吐，或伤寒阴证，寒邪深入三阴，而恶心呕吐不止者，理阴煎或温胃饮。　　实邪恶心，以一时邪滞犯胃，得吐则滞去，滞去则恶心自解。若有余邪，如法治之。若恶心多痰，及风寒咳嗽，或伤生冷，或饮酒过多，脾胃不和者，二陈汤或橘皮半夏汤。若脾胃多滞，或寒湿伤脾恶心者，平胃散。若胃寒多滞，或伤生冷，或寒痰不清，吞酸胀满恶心者，和胃饮，或和胃二陈煎。若受秽浊寒邪，胀满腹痛恶心者，调气平胃散。若感冒暑热，火盛烦躁恶心者，仲景竹叶石膏汤。若中药毒或诸毒而恶心者，速宜于诸毒门求法治之。[83p]

    If there is slight deficiency in the spleen and stomach leading to phlegm, or if one experiences sour belching and a cough with nausea, the Six Gentlemen Decoction should be used. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and stomach with phlegm stagnation causing nausea, the Jinshui Six Gentlemen Decoction is appropriate. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and stomach, or if the Taiyin is overly beneficial, causing abdominal pain, vomiting, and nausea, one can take Warm Stomach Drink, or the Lizhong Decoction or the Shengzhi Decoction. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and kidney, preventing movement up and down, leading to distention, vomiting, or signs of a cold with yin damage, with deep cold evil causing persistent nausea and vomiting, the Liyin Decoction or Warm Stomach Drink should be applied.

    If the evil is real causing nausea due to a momentary stagnation affecting the stomach, if vomiting occurs, the stagnation will resolve and the nausea will naturally subside. If there is residual evil, treat it accordingly. If nausea is accompanied by excess phlegm, or if there is a cough from wind-cold, or suffering from cold or excessive drinking, leading to disharmony in the spleen and stomach, use the Erchen Decoction or the Tangerine Peel and Pinellia Decoction. If there is significant stagnation in the spleen and stomach, or if cold dampness injures the spleen leading to nausea, apply the Pingwei Powder. If the stomach is excessively cold and has much stagnation, or suffers from cold injuries, or if cold phlegm is unclear, with sour belching and distention causing nausea, use the Harmonizing Stomach Drink or the Harmonizing Stomach Erchen Decoction. If exposed to foul, turbid cold evil leads to distention and abdominal pain with nausea, use the Tiqi Pingwei Powder. If experiencing a cold or summer heat, with rampant fire causing irritability and nausea, apply the Zhongjing Bamboo Leaf and Gypsum Decoction. If nausea arises from toxic Chinese herbs or other toxins, seek treatment from the relevant toxicology methods promptly.[83p]

    　　　　　吐酸吞酸辨证

    　　吐酸一证，在河间言其为热，在东垣言其为寒。夫理有一定，奚容谬异若此，岂理因二子可以易乎？必二子于理有一悖者，此余之不能无言，以东垣为是，而以河间为非也。何以见之？盖河间之说，实本《内经》。经曰：诸呕吐酸，暴注下迫，皆属于热。故河间病机悉训为火，而甚以主寒者为非。不知《内经》此论，乃以运气所属，概言病应，非以呕吐注泄，皆为内热病也。如果言热，则何以又曰：寒气客于肠胃，厥逆上出，故痛而呕也？又曰：太阳之复，心胃生寒，胸中不和，唾出清水，及为哕噫。此言呕吐之有寒也，岂皆热耶？又曰：太阳之胜，寒入下焦，传为濡泄。[84p]

    The occurrence of sour vomiting is discussed as follows: In Hejian, it is said to be caused by heat, while in Dongyuan, it is said to be caused by cold. The principles of medicine have a certain consistency; how can there be such discrepancies? Is it possible that the reasoning can be switched based on these two opinions? Surely, one of these views must be erroneous, and I cannot refrain from voicing my stance that Dongyuan's perspective is correct while Hejian's is wrong.

    How can this be demonstrated? The reasoning from Hejian is actually rooted in the "Inner Canon." The text states that all instances of sour vomiting, due to sudden force or pressure downwards, belong to heat. Thus, Hejian interprets all disease processes as resulting from fire, and harshly criticizes the stance that predominantly attributes this to cold. Yet, they do not recognize that the "Inner Canon" is merely addressing conditions in relation to changes in Qi and broadly categorizing illnesses, rather than asserting that all vomiting and diarrhea are internal heat conditions.

    If we discuss heat, how then is it also said that cold Qi attacks the intestines and stomach, causing pain and resulting in vomiting? Further, it is said that when Taiyang is revived, the heart and stomach produce cold, leading to disharmony in the chest, resulting in the expulsion of clear fluid, and causing belching. This indicates that there are cold factors involved in vomiting; can we thus classify everything as heat? Moreover, it is said that excessive cold enters the lower regions, resulting in diarrhea.[84p]

    此言泄泻之有寒也，岂亦热耶？由此观之，则其此处言热，而彼复言寒，岂非自相矛盾，能无谬乎？不知《内经》之理，圆通详悉，无不周备，故有此言其常而彼言其变者，有此言其顺而彼言其逆者，有此篇未尽而足之他论者，有总言所属而详言所病者，此《内经》之元奥，所以不易穷也。故凡善观此者，务宜悟其源流，察其分合，其博也必烛其为千为万，其约必贯其总归一理。夫如是，斯足称明眼人矣。[85p]

    This statement reveals that there is coldness in the discharge; could it also be heat? From this, if the text speaks of heat here and coldness there, is it not self-contradictory and not erroneous? Not understanding the principles of the "Neijing," which are comprehensive and detailed, nothing is left out. Thus, there are statements about constancy and others about change, some discussing harmony and others discussing opposition. There are parts not fully covered yet complemented by other arguments, and general statements followed by specific diagnoses. This is the profound essence of the "Neijing," which is not easily exhausted. Therefore, those who can observe this well should aim to grasp its origins, discern its combinations, and understand that its breadth can encompass thousands, while its succinctness must connect back to a single principle. If one can do so, they are indeed worthy of being called a discerning individual.[85p]

    倘不能会其巅末，而但知管测一斑，又乌足以尽其妙哉！矧复有不明宗旨，悖理妄谈，谬借经文，证己偏见者，尚难枚举，无暇辨也。兹因二子之论，故并及之，而再悉于左，观者其加政焉！　　辨河间吐酸之论为非。据河间曰：酸者，肝木之味也。由火盛制金，不能平木，则肝木自甚，故为酸也，如饮食热则易于酸矣。或言吐酸为寒者，误也。所以妄言为寒者，但谓多伤生硬粘滑，或伤冷物而为噫酸吞酸，故俗医主于温和脾胃。岂知经言人之伤于寒也则为病热，故凡内伤冷物者，或即阴胜阳而为病寒者，或寒热相击而致肠胃阳气怫郁而为热者；亦有内伤生冷而反病热，得大汗热泄，身凉而愈也。[86p]

    If one cannot grasp its peak and details, but only knows a small part, how can one fully appreciate its wonders? Moreover, there are those who misunderstand the fundamental principles, engage in irrational talks, and misquote scriptures to support their biases, which are too numerous to mention and difficult to clarify. Due to the discussion between the two, I will include it here and request that viewers raise their discernment!

    Regarding the argument that the acidity from Hejian is incorrect. Hejian states: Acid is the flavor of the liver's wood. When fire is strong and governs metal, it cannot balance wood; thus, the liver's wood becomes excessive, resulting in acidity. For instance, when foods are hot, they easily lead to acidity. Some say that vomiting acid is due to cold, which is a mistake. Those who mistakenly claim it is cold merely suggest that excessive consumption can harden and create stickiness or damage cold substances, causing the phenomena of belching acid. Therefore, folk medicine focuses on temperate and harmonious treatments for the spleen and stomach.

    Little do they know that the classics say that when a person is harmed by cold, it manifests as a heat illness. Hence, any internal harm caused by cold substances could lead to an excess of yin over yang, resulting in illness due to cold, or the clash of cold and heat causing the stomach and intestines' yang energy to stagnate, leading to heat. There are also cases of internal harm from cold resulting in a rebound illness of heat, where profuse sweating and heat relief may occur, leading to recovery.[86p]

    若久喜酸而不已，则不宜温之，宜以寒药下之，后以凉药调之，结散热去则气和也。凡此皆河间之说，余每见之，未尝不反复切叹。观其所言病机，则由火及金，由金及木，由木及脾，所以为酸。若发微谈理，果可转折，如此则指鹿为马，何患无辞？惟其执以为热，故不得不委曲若此。若余言其为寒，则不然也。夫酸本肝木之味，何不曰火衰不能生土，则脾气虚而肝邪侮之，故为酸也。岂不于理更为明切，而何以曲折强解有若是乎？又若《内经》所言人之伤于寒也则为病热，此言伤寒证寒邪在表，则为三阳之发热，及其传里，则为阳明之内热，岂以内伤冷物而亦云病热者耶？又岂有内伤冷物而可以汗解者耶？即以气血强盛之人，偶伤生冷，久留不去，而郁为热者，此以郁久化热，或亦有之，岂果因生冷而反热耶？矧《内经》本以外感言，而河间引以证内伤，谬亦甚矣。[87p]

    If one has long been troubled by sourness and it does not cease, then it is inappropriate to warm it; instead, it is advisable to use cold medications to purge it, and later to adjust it with cooling medicines, leading to the resolution of heat and the harmonization of qi. All of this are the teachings of Hejian; whenever I see it, I cannot help but repeatedly marvel. Observing what is said about the pathogenesis, it stems from fire to metal, from metal to wood, and from wood to the spleen, hence the sourness. If one speaks faintly in inquiry, it could indeed turn around; under such circumstances, pointing at a deer and calling it a horse would face no reproach. It is solely because they hold steadfastly to it being heat that they cannot help but twist and turn in explanation like this. However, if I say it is cold, it is not so. Sourness fundamentally belongs to the flavor of the liver wood. Why not say that the fire is weak and cannot generate earth, thus the spleen's qi is deficient and the liver's evil burdens it, resulting in sourness? Would this not be clearer in reasoning? Why then insist on such convoluted explanations? Furthermore, as the "Inner Canon" states, when a person is harmed by cold, it is considered a disease of heat; this refers to the injury of cold evils at the surface, leading to the fever of the three yangs, and when transmitted internally, it becomes the internal heat of yangming. Can it really be said that internal injuries from cold substances also represent disease heat? Is it plausible to think that one can resolve inner injuries from cold by sweating them out? Even for robust individuals, should they inadvertently be harmed by raw cold, lingering for a long time and accumulating into heat, this is a case of prolonged stagnation transforming into heat; could it truly be due to raw cold causing subsequent heat? Moreover, the "Inner Canon" originally speaks of external pathogens, while Hejian improperly uses it as evidence for internal injuries, which is quite erroneous.[87p]

    此不惟大害轩岐之旨，而致后人执以借口，其害又将何如也！　　辨东垣吐酸之论为是。据《发明》曰：《内经》言诸呕吐酸皆属于热，此上焦受外来客邪也，胃气不受外邪故呕，仲景以生姜、半夏治之。以杂病论之，呕吐酸水者，甚则酸水浸其心，其次则吐出酸水，令上下牙酸濇不能相对，以大辛热药疗之必减也。[88p]

    This not only harms the essence of Xuanqi, but also leads future generations to use it as an excuse; what greater harm could follow? To clarify the argument of Dongyuan regarding sourness: according to "Explanation," the "Inner Canon" states that all sour vomiting belongs to heat, which occurs when the upper burner is invaded by external evil. The stomach qi does not accept the external evil, resulting in vomiting. Zhongjing treated this with ginger and pinellia. Discussing it in terms of mixed diseases, those who vomit sour water may suffer severely, with the sour water permeating their heart; next, they will vomit sour water, causing their upper and lower teeth to feel sour and unable to meet. Treating this with potent hot herbs will definitely reduce it.[88p]

    酸味者，收气也，西方肺金旺也，寒水乃金之子，子能令母实，故用大咸热之剂泻其子，以辛热为之佐，而泻肺之实，病机作热攻之，误矣。盖杂病酢心，浊气不降，欲为中满，寒药岂能治之乎？此东垣之说也，余谓其最为得理。但其立言太讳，如所云收气及西方金旺、水为金子等义，人有未达，每多忽之。即在丹溪亦曰：东垣不言外得风寒，而作收气立说，欲泻肺金之实；又谓寒药不可治酸，而用安胃汤、加减二陈汤，俱犯丁香，且无治湿热郁积之法，为未合经意也。因考丹溪治法则用茱连丸、二陈汤，且曰宜用炒吴茱萸，顺其性而折之，乃反佐之法也，必用黄连为君以治之。[89p]

    The sour taste represents the gathering of energy; in the west, the lung is associated with metal, which is strong. Cold water is the child of metal; the child can cause the mother to bear fruit. Thus, one should use large doses of salty, warming agents to drain the child, complemented by acrid and warming substances, to drain the lung's fullness. If the illness arises from heat attacking, this is a mistake. The essence of various illnesses is related to the heart being affected, with turbid energy not descending, resulting in a fullness in the center. Can cold medicine treat this? This is the argument of Dongyuan, which I believe is most reasonable. However, the way he articulates it can be too obscure; terms like "gathering energy" and "the west's metal being strong, water as the child of metal" may not be easily understood, and many often overlook them. Even in Danxi’s teachings, he also mentions that Dongyuan does not speak of external wind and cold but establishes the idea of gathering energy to drain the fullness of lung metal. He further argues that cold medicine cannot treat sourness, yet employs Anwei Decoction and the modified Erchen Decoction, both containing clove, while lacking methods for treating damp-heat accumulation. This does not align with the classic understanding. Upon examining Danxi's treatment methods, they utilize Zhu Lian Pill and Erchen Decoction, and also mention that it is advisable to use fried Wu Zhu Yu, aligning with its nature to properly address the issue. Therefore, yellow lily must be used as the sovereign medicine to treat it.[89p]

    此丹溪之意，亦主于热，正与东垣相反。而欲以芩连治吐酸，则不可不辨也。故余以东垣之说，请为之疏焉。夫所谓收气者，金气也，即秋气也。《内经》曰：秋气始于上。盖阴盛之渐，必始于上，以阳气之将退也。寒肃之渐，必始于上，以阳气之日降也。其云：金旺者，非云肺气之充实，正言寒气之有余也。其云子令母实者，以寒在上焦，则收气愈甚，故治用咸热等剂，以泻其子，亦无非扶阳抑阴之道最切当也。丹溪未达其意，而反以非之，抑又何也？即如丁香气味辛爽无毒，凡中焦寒滞，气有不顺者，最其所宜，又何至以犯字相戒，而使后人畏之如虎耶？盖丹溪但知丁香不可犯，而不知黄连、黄芩，又岂吞酸证所宜轻犯者哉？然说虽如此，而说有未尽，则云寒云热，犹不无疑，谨再竟其说焉。[90p]

    The intention of Danxi is primarily about heat, which is directly contrary to Dongyuan's views. However, when using Qinnian to treat acid reflux, one must discern carefully. Therefore, I will elaborate on Dongyuan's theories. The so-called "gathering of qi" refers to the metal qi, or autumn qi. The "Inner Canon" states: "Autumn qi begins above." This indicates that the gradual increase of yin must start above, as the yang qi is about to retreat. The gradual onset of cold must begin above as well, as the yang qi declines. When it is said that the metal is strong, it does not mean the fullness of lung qi; it actually refers to an excess of cold qi. The saying that the son envelops the mother implies that with cold in the upper burner, the gathering of qi becomes more intense. Thus, using warm and hot remedies to drain the son is merely a suitable way to support yang and suppress yin. If Danxi did not grasp this intention and instead criticized it, what is the reason? For instance, cloves possess a spicy and refreshing flavor without toxicity; they are most appropriate for addressing cold stagnation in the middle burner, where qi is not flowing smoothly. How could one warn against them as if they are dangerous and instill fear in future generations? Danxi only understood that cloves should not be treated harshly, yet he did not realize the roles of Huanglian and Huangqin. How could one lightly treat sour substances that are suited for such cases? Nonetheless, even though my explanation stands, I must further clarify the discussions on cold and heat, as doubts remain. Thus, I will reiterate my arguments.[90p]

    　　吐酸证诸言为热者，岂不各有其说？在刘河间则曰，如饮食热则易酸矣。在戴原礼则曰，如榖肉在器，湿热则易为酸也。又有相传者曰：观之造酒者，凉作则甘，过热则酸，岂非酸由热乎？诸说如此宛然可信，而欲人不从，不可得也。凡诸似是而非者，正以此类。譬之射者，但能不离于前后左右，便云高手。不知犯此四字，尚足以言射乎？而诸家之说，亦犹是耳。何以见之？盖察病者，当察以理；察理者，当察以真。即如饮食之酸由乎热，似近理矣，然食在釜中，使能化而不酸者，此以火力强而速化无留也。若起置器中，必久而后酸，此停积而酸，非因热而酸也。尝见水浆冷积既久，未有不酸者，此岂热耶，因不行也。又云造酒者，热作则酸，亦似近理。然必于二三日之后，郁热不开，然后成酸，未有热作及时，而遂致酸者。且人之胃气，原自大热，所以三餐入胃，俱能顷刻消化，此方是真阳火候之应。[91p]

    The arguments stating that sourness is due to heat must each have their explanations, right? Liu Hejian says that when food is hot, it easily becomes sour. Dai Yuanli states that if grains and meat are in a moist and hot vessel, they can easily turn sour. Others claim that when observing winemaking, if the fermentation process is cool, the wine turns sweet, but if it’s overly hot, it turns sour. Isn't it clear that sourness arises from heat? All these theories sound credible, but insisting that people do not accept them is impossible. In matters of this nature, they are often mistaken. It’s like an archer who claims to be skilled simply by not deviating from front, back, or sides. They do not realize that even such basic errors are enough to question their skill in archery. The various theories about this are very much the same. How can we know? One must examine patients by reasoning; reasoning must be based on truth. Just as the sourness of food seems to stem from heat, it appears plausible, yet when food is in a pot, if it can transform without becoming sour, it is because the heat is strong and quickly changes it without leaving anything behind. However, if placed in a vessel, it will take a long time to sour; this is due to accumulation and does not arise from heat. I have often seen water that has been cold and stagnant for a long time, which inevitably becomes sour. Is this due to heat? No, it’s due to inactivity. Furthermore, when winemaking is concerned, heat leading to sourness seems plausible. However, it is only after two or three days of fermentation, when the accumulated heat dissipates, that it becomes sour. There has never been a case where heat immediately causes sourness. Moreover, the digestive energy in humans is primarily derived from strong heat, so when food enters the stomach during meals, it can be digested in an instant; this reflects the true response of yang fire in its proper state.[91p]

    若如造酒者，必待竟日而后成，则日不再餐，胃气能无惫乎？若必如冷作之不酸，方云无火，则饮食之化，亦须旬曰，此其胃中阳气，不已竭乎？是可见胃气本宜暖，稍凉不可也。酒瓮本宜疏，郁闷不可也。故酒瓮之化，亦安能如胃气之速，而胃气之健，又安可同酒瓮之迟乎？此其性理相悬，奚啻十倍，有不待辨也明矣。且人之余食在胃，以速化为贵。若胃中阳气不衰，而健运如常，何酸之有？使火力不到则其化必迟，食化既迟则停积不行而为酸为腐，此酸即败之渐也。故凡病吞酸者，多见饮食不快，自食有不快，必渐至中满痞隔泄泻等证。岂非脾气不强、胃脘阳虚之病，而犹认为火，能无误乎？余向在燕都，尝有一缙绅患此而求治者，余告以寒，彼执为热，坚持造酒之说，以相问难，莫能与辨，竟为芩连之属所毙，而终不能悟，岂非前说之误之也耶？亦可哀矣！余故曰：人之察理，贵察其真。若见理不真，而疑似固执，以致酿成大害者，无非此类。[92p]

    If, like a winemaker, one must wait until the end of the day for the wine to be complete, then one cannot eat again that day; how can one not feel weary in the stomach? If it must be like cold fermentation that yields no sourness and thus is said to be without heat, then the transformation of food must also take days. Is it not evident that the yang energy in the stomach would have already depleted? It is clear that the stomach's energy should be warm; it cannot endure being slightly cool. A wine vessel should remain open; it should not become damp and stagnant. Therefore, how can the transformation in a wine vessel be as swift as the energy in the stomach, and how can the strength of stomach energy be compared to the slowness of a wine vessel? This is a matter of nature and reasoning; it is not merely a matter of tenfold, and there is no need for further clarification. Moreover, the leftover food in the stomach values quick transformation. If the yang energy in the stomach does not decline and operates healthily as usual, why would there be any sourness? If the firepower is insufficient, then the transformation must be slow. Once the transformation is delayed, food accumulates and cannot move, leading to sourness and rotting; this sourness is a gradual onset of spoilage. Thus, any illnesses characterized by sour stomach discomfort are often seen when food does not move quickly, resulting in discomfort from self-consumption, and will inevitably lead to fullness, stifling, and diarrhea. Could it not be the weakness of the spleen and yang deficiency in the stomach, yet still be misinterpreted as heat? I once encountered a gentleman in the capital who suffered from this and sought treatment from me; I told him it was cold, yet he persisted in believing it was heat, adhering to the winemaking argument, unable to differentiate, and ultimately fell victim to the likes of qinlian, never coming to understand. Is this not a case of misunderstanding from earlier discussions? It is indeed lamentable! Thus, I say: it is vital for one to discern truth and reason. If one grasps false reasoning and stubbornly clings to misplaced doubts, leading to major harm, it is nothing but this sort of case.[92p]

    此似是而非之谈，所以不可不辨也。　　吞酸之与吐酸，证有三种：凡喉间嗳噫，即有酸水如酢浸，心(食曹)杂不堪者，是名吞酸，即俗所谓作酸也。此病在上脘最高之处，不时见酸而泛泛不宁者是也。其次则非如吞酸之近，不在上脘而在中焦胃脘之间，时多呕恶，所吐皆酸，即名吐酸，而渥渥不行者是也。[93p]

    This may seem like valid discourse, but it must not go unexamined. There are three types of experiencing acidity: First, when there is belching with sour water like vinegar effervescing in the throat, accompanied by discomfort in the heart (chest), this is known as "swallowing acid," commonly referred to as "having acidity." This condition is located at the highest point of the upper abdomen, where sourness often appears, causing unease.

    Second, it is not as close to "swallowing acid." It is situated between the middle and upper parts of the stomach; often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, with everything expelled being sour, this is called "vomiting acid," typically involving excessive moisture that fails to resolve.[93p]

    又其次者，则本无吞酸吐酸证，惟或偶因呕吐所出，或酸或苦，及诸不堪之味，此皆肠胃中痰饮积聚所化，气味每有浊恶如此，此又在中脘之下者也。但其顺而下行则人所不觉，逆而上出则喉口难堪耳。凡此三者，其在上中二脘者，则无非脾胃虚寒，不能运化之病，治此者，非温不可；其在下脘偶出者，则寒热俱有，但当因证以治其呕吐，呕吐止则酸苦无从见矣。虽然，此亦余之论证，故不得不曲进其说。若以实理言之，则凡胃强者，何暇计及于酸苦；其有酸苦者，必其停积不行而然。此宜随证审察，若无热证热脉可据，而执言湿中生热，无分强弱，惟用寒凉，则未有不误者矣。[94p]

    Furthermore, regarding the secondary issues, there is fundamentally no evidence for sour vomiting or sour regurgitation; these may arise incidentally due to vomiting, whether sour or bitter, along with various intolerable flavors. All of these are caused by phlegm and fluid accumulation in the stomach and intestines, leading to foul or turbid tastes, especially below the middle burner (Zhongwan). If the movement is downward, it goes unnoticed by people; if it rises, it is difficult to endure at the throat and mouth.

    Concerning these three conditions, those in the upper and middle burners are simply due to deficiency and coldness of the spleen and stomach, which are unable to process properly; treatment for this must involve warming. As for those occasionally arising in the lower burner, there may be both cold and heat present, but treatment should be based on the symptoms of vomiting; once vomiting ceases, sour and bitter flavors will no longer be present.

    Nevertheless, this is merely my analysis, and I cannot help but approach the matter delicately. In practical terms, those with strong stomachs have no time to dwell on sourness and bitterness; if these sensations occur, it must be because of stagnation and blockage. This should be carefully examined according to the symptoms. If there are no signs of heat or a heated pulse to rely on, and one insists on the idea of heat arising from dampness without distinguishing between strength and weakness, then solely using coldness and cooling methods has led to many errors.[94p]

    　　　　　论治

    　　治吞酸吐酸，当辨虚实之微甚，年力之盛衰。实者可治其标，虚者必治其本。　　凡胃气未衰，年质壮盛，或寒或食，偶有所积而为酸者，宜用行滞温平之剂，以二陈汤、平胃散、和胃饮之类主之。中气微寒者，宜加减二陈汤，或橘皮汤，甚者宜温胃饮。气微虚者，宜藿香安胃散。此皆治标之法也。[95p]

    On Treatment

    For the condition of sourness in the stomach, one must discern the subtle differences between excess and deficiency, as well as the vigor of youth versus the frailty of age. In cases of excess, the symptom can be treated; in cases of deficiency, the root must be addressed. If the stomach qi is not weak and the constitution is strong, and there are occasional accumulations causing sourness due to either cold or food, one should use warming and moving remedies such as Erchen Decoction, Pingwei Powder, or Hewei Decoction to treat the symptoms. If there is slight cold in the middle qi, one should modify Erchen Decoction or use Orange Peel Decoction; in severe cases, Warm Stomach Decoction is advisable. If there is a slight deficiency of qi, use Huoxiang Anwei Powder. These are all methods to treat the symptoms.[95p]

    　　脾胃气虚，及中年渐弱，而饮食减少，时见吞酸吐酸者，惟宜温补脾胃，以理中汤、温胃饮、圣朮煎之类主之，切不可用清凉消耗等药。若虚在阴分，下焦不暖，而水邪上泛为酸者，宜用理阴煎最妙。　　丹溪曰：治酸必用吴茱萸，顺其性而折之，乃反佐之法也。不知此实正治，非顺性也。盖其性热，最能暖中下二焦；其味辛苦，最能胜酸濇之味。谓之反佐，见之过矣。　　用黄连为君，以治吐酸，乃丹溪之法也。观其治案，有一人酸块自胸直上咽喉，甚恶，以黄连浓煎，冷候酸块欲上，与数点饮之即下。盖味苦沉降，故酸得苦而即下，此亦扬汤止沸之法耳。[96p]

    When the spleen and stomach are deficient in qi, especially in middle age as one becomes gradually weaker, leading to reduced food intake and occasional sour belching, it is best to gently tonify the spleen and stomach. This can be done with formulas like Lizhong Decoction, Wengui Decoction, or Shengjiang Decoction; one must definitely avoid using cooling and depleting medications. If the deficiency is in the yin aspect and the lower burner is not warm, causing water pathogens to rise and create sourness, it is most effective to use the Recipe for Nourishing Yin.

    Danxi said: To treat sourness, one must use Wu Zhu Yu, following its nature to counter it, which is indeed a method of correction. However, it is not merely about following its nature. Its nature is warm and it is most effective in warming the middle and lower burners; its taste, being pungent and bitter, is best at overcoming the sour and heavy flavors. To call it a corrective method is an exaggeration.

    Using Huang Lian as the sovereign herb to treat sour vomiting is indeed Danxi's method. Observing his case studies, there was a patient who had sour lumps rising from the chest straight to the throat, which was very severe. By making a strong decoction of Huang Lian and cooling it before giving it to address the sour lump, just a few drops caused it to descend. The bitter taste sinks down, so when the sourness encounters bitterness, it immediately descends. This is also a method of calming boiling water with soup.[96p]

    若年壮气强，偶有所积，及酒湿不行，而酸楚上泛者，或用此法，未必即伤胃气，而亦可墬引下行，即权宜用亦无不可，然终非治本之道也。若气体略有虚弱，及内伤年衰之辈，而患吐酸者，必不可妄用芩连，再残阳气，虽暂得苦降之力，而胃气愈伤，则病必日甚而无可为矣。　　呕吐清水，古法以二朮、二陈汤或六君子汤，本皆正治之法。然余尝治水泛为饮者，觉自脐下上冲，而吐水不竭，以理阴煎治之，其妙如神。故此三方，皆宜酌用。[97p]

    If a young person is strong and has some reserves, and due to alcohol consumption feels a rising acidity and distress, they may use this method without immediately harming their stomach’s energy. It could effectively help in guiding things downward; thus, using it as a temporary remedy is acceptable, though it is not a fundamental solution. However, if one's energy is slightly weak, especially in those who have internal injuries or are older and suffer from acid reflux, one must avoid recklessly using Qinyin, as it further depletes the Yang energy. While it may provide temporary relief from bitter regurgitation, it ultimately damages stomach energy, and the condition will worsen with no recourse.

    For vomiting clear fluids, the traditional methods using Erzhong, Erchen Decoction, or Liu Junzi Decoction are all proper treatments. Yet, I have treated those suffering from water regurgitation by using the method of managing the Yin and simmering it, and the results are remarkably effective. Therefore, all three approaches should be considered for use.[97p]

    　　凡肌表暴受风寒，则多有为吞酸者，此其由息而入则脏气通于鼻，由经而入则脏俞系于背。故凡寒气一入，则胃中阳和之气，被抑不舒，所以滞浊随见，而即刻见酸，此明系寒邪犯胃也。今以讹相传者，皆云肌表得风寒，则内热愈郁，而酸味刺心，何其谬也！夫因郁成热者，必以渐久而成，或一日或二日，然后郁而为热也。今凡受寒吞酸者，无不随寒而酸，见在即刻，岂即刻便成郁热耶？惟其非热，所以却之之法，亦惟肌表宜温暖，药剂宜香燥，此自寒者热之之正治。而说者必欲执言为热，故尔强解。所谓道在迩而求诸远，凡属谬妄者，何非此类？
    　　　　石室秘箓 【清　陈士铎】

    　　　　　呕吐治法[98p]

    When the skin is exposed to wind and cold, it often leads to symptoms of sourness upon swallowing. This occurs because the breath (qi) enters through the nose, and through the meridians, it connects the internal organs to the back. Therefore, once cold enters the body, the yang and harmonious qi in the stomach is suppressed and unable to circulate freely, resulting in stagnation and the immediate sensation of sourness, which clearly indicates that cold evil has invaded the stomach.

    Currently, those who spread misinformation claim that when the skin is exposed to wind and cold, internal heat becomes more agitated, and the sour taste pricks the heart—a gross misunderstanding! The development of internal heat due to stagnation must occur gradually over time, whether one day or two, leading to stagnation and then heat. However, anyone who experiences cold and sourness does so immediately; how could it turn into agitated heat so quickly? It is precisely because it is not heat that the remedy involves warming the skin and using fragrant, drying medicines, which are the appropriate treatments for cold. Yet, those who insist on interpreting this as heat forcefully rationalize it. This illustrates the notion of seeking distant truths while ignoring nearby realities; all such misconceptions belong to this category.[98p]

    　　吐呕之证，人以为胃虚，谁知由于肾虚。无论食入即出是肾之衰，凡有吐证，无非肾虚之故。故治吐不治肾，未窥见病之根也。方用人参三钱，白朮、薏仁、芡实各五钱，砂仁三粒，吴茱萸五分，水煎服。此方似平治脾胃之药，不知皆治肾之法。方中除人参救胃之外，其余药品，俱入肾经，而不止留在脾也。肾火生脾，脾土始能生胃，胃气一转，吐呕始平，此治胃而用治肾之药，人知之乎？　　更有大吐之证，舌如芒刺，双目红肿，人以为热也，不知此乃肾水干槁，火不能藏，水不能润，食入即出耳。法当用六味地黄汤一料煎服，恣其吞饮，则余火下息，而饮食可入。盖胃为肾之关，胃中之火，必得肾中之水以润之，肾水耗不能上润脾胃，则胃火沸腾，涌而上出，以致双目红肿，舌如芒刺也。但此证时躁时静，一时而欲饮水，及至水到又不欲饮，即强饮之，又不十分宽快，此乃上假热而下真寒也，理宜六味汤内加附子、肉桂，煎冷与饮，始合病源。[99p]

    The symptoms of vomiting are often attributed to a deficiency of the stomach, but they are actually caused by a deficiency of the kidneys. Regardless of whether food is ingested and immediately expelled, it reflects the decline of the kidneys. All instances of vomiting are fundamentally due to kidney deficiency. Thus, treating vomiting without addressing the kidneys fails to address the root of the illness.

    The formula consists of three qian of ginseng, five qian each of white atracary, job’s tears, and foxnut, three grains of amomum, and five fen of wuzhuyu, to be decocted and taken. This formula appears to be a remedy for the spleen and stomach, but it is, in fact, a treatment for the kidneys. Aside from ginseng, which supports the stomach, all other ingredients enter the kidney channel and do not simply remain in the spleen. Kidney fire nourishes the spleen, allowing the spleen’s earth to generate the stomach; when the stomach qi transforms, vomiting and nausea begin to settle. This is a treatment for the stomach using kidney remedies—does anyone realize this?

    Furthermore, in cases of severe vomiting where the tongue resembles a thorn and both eyes are red and swollen, people tend to think it is due to heat, not knowing that it is actually due to the dryness of kidney water, causing fire not to be contained and water not to moisten—resulting in immediate expulsion of food. The appropriate method is to use a decoction of Liuwei Dihuang Tang, allowing ample drinking, which will diminish the excess heat and enable food and drink to be ingested. The stomach serves as the gate of the kidneys; the fire in the stomach must depend on the water from the kidneys to moisten it. If kidney water is depleted and cannot ascend to moisten the spleen and stomach, then stomach fire will boil, surging upwards to cause red and swollen eyes and a thorn-like tongue.

    However, this condition can be both restless and calm—at times longing for water, but when water is offered, there is reluctance to drink. Even when compelled to drink, it doesn’t bring much relief. This indicates a false heat above and true cold below. It is advisable to add fuzi and cinnamon to the Liuwei Tang, decocting it cold for consumption to address the source of the illness.[99p]

    而今止用六味地黄汤者何？盖肾寒而胃正热，温肾之药，必经过胃经，热性发作，肾不及救，而胃反助其邪火之焰，则病热转添。不若竟用六味地黄汤，使其直趋肾宫，虽经过胃中，不致相犯，假道灭虢，不平胃而胃自平矣，此亦逆治之法也。　　大吐之人，治之不可缓也。法当用人参五钱，茯苓、白朮各三钱，甘草三分，陈皮一钱，豆蔻仁三粒，水煎服。此方纯用健胃补脾之剂，而人不知其中奥妙也。[100p]

    Why is it that nowadays only Liu Wei Di Huang Tang is used? It is because of kidney cold and proper stomach heat. To warm the kidneys, one must use medicine that passes through the stomach channel; if the heat nature arises, the kidneys cannot intervene, and the stomach instead assists the evil fire, leading to an increase in the illness heat. It would be better to use Liu Wei Di Huang Tang directly aimed at the kidney palace, which, although passing through the stomach, does not cause conflict; it is like extinguishing the fire by using an indirect route, where the stomach becomes balanced without direct treatment. This is also a method of reverse treatment.

    For a person with severe vomiting, treatment should not be delayed. The method should employ five qian of ginseng, three qian each of poria and white atractylodes, three fen of licorice, one qian of dried tangerine peel, and three grains of cardamom seeds, boiled in water for consumption. This prescription purely uses ingredients to strengthen the stomach and nourish the spleen, yet many do not understand its underlying intricacies.[100p]

    大吐之后，津液已干，如何又用健脾补胃以重燥之，得毋伤之太甚耶？不知脾胃之气健，而后津液能生，茍以润药补之，则脾胃恶湿，反足伤其真气，所以不用润剂而反用燥药也。他脏腑恶燥，惟脾胃脏腑反恶湿而喜燥，以人参、白朮投之，正投其所好，又安有燥烈之虞哉？　　大吐有寒邪直入肾宫，将脾胃之水，挟之尽出，手足厥逆，少腹痛不可忍，以火热之物熨之少快，否则寒冷欲死。方用附子一个，白朮四两，肉桂一钱，干姜三钱，人参三两救之。下喉便觉，吐定再进，则安然如故。盖肾水养人，何能克心以杀人？惟阴寒邪气，直入肾宫，则肾火逃避，而诸邪挟众逆犯，心君不宁矣。[101p]

    After a great purge, if the fluids are already depleted, how can one use strengthening the spleen and nourishing the stomach to counteract dryness without causing excessive harm? It is not understood that the energy of the spleen and stomach must be strong for fluids to be generated. If one simply uses moistening medicines, the spleen and stomach, which dislike dampness, will be harmed, thereby injuring their genuine energy. This is why drying medicines are used instead. Other organs may dislike dryness, but the spleen and stomach specifically dislike dampness and prefer dryness. By using ginseng and white atractylodes, one addresses what they need without the fear of excessive dryness.

    After a great purge, if there is cold evil directly entering the kidney palace, and the water from the spleen and stomach is entirely expelled, causing extremities to become cold and abdominal pain unbearable, one must use something hot to provide slight relief; otherwise, the chill may be fatal. Therefore, use one piece of aconite, four ounces of white atractylodes, one pennyweight of cinnamon, three pennyweights of dried ginger, and three ounces of ginseng to rescue them. Once swallowed, relief will be felt; if the vomiting settles, then all will return to normal. The water of the kidneys nourishes a person; how can it counteract the heart to cause death? It is only the invasion of cold evil directly into the kidney palace that causes the kidney fire to retreat, allowing various evils to launch their attacks and disturb the heart monarch.[101p]

    所以必用附子、肉桂、干姜一派辛辣大热之物，而又必多用人参以定变，使诸药遍列分布，无非春温之气，自然寒邪散而吐止，此方之所以霸而奇也。　　大吐之证，明是虚寒，亦有用参至数两者。然而吐不可一类同观，其势不急，不妨少用，可以徐加。倘寒未深而吐不甚，亦以参数两加之，恐增饱满之证矣。　　大吐之证，虚寒居多，然亦有热而吐者，不可不讲。热吐者，必随痰而出，不若寒吐之纯是清水也。热吐不可用参，以二陈汤饮之得宜。[102p]

    Therefore, it is essential to use aconite, cinnamon, and dried ginger, which are all pungent and warming substances, and to employ ginseng in abundance to stabilize changes. This ensures that the various medicines are evenly distributed, ultimately embodying the warm energy of spring, naturally dispelling cold evils and stopping the vomiting. This is the reason why this formula is both dominant and remarkable.

    In cases of significant vomiting, it is clear that there is a deficiency of cold, and using multiple liang of ginseng is beneficial. However, vomiting should not be uniformly treated; if the condition is not urgent, it is acceptable to use less and gradually increase the dosage. If the cold is not severe and the vomiting is mild, then adding a couple of liang of ginseng might lead to an increase in fullness.

    While significant vomiting predominantly results from cold deficiency, there are also cases of vomiting due to heat, which cannot be overlooked. In cases of heat-induced vomiting, it must be accompanied by phlegm, unlike cold vomiting, which is purely clear water. For heat vomiting, ginseng should not be used; instead, it is appropriate to drink Er Chen Tang.[102p]

    若寒吐必须加人参两许，而杂以辛热之品，始能止呕而定吐。第人参可以暂用，而不可日日服之。吐多则伤阴，暂服人参止吐则可，若日日服之，必至阳有余而阴不足，胃中干燥，恐成闭结之证矣。所以人参可暂而不可常也。　　呕吐之证，一时而来，亦小证也。然而倾胃而吐，必伤胃气，胃气一伤，多致不救。其证有火有寒，火吐宜清火而不可降火，寒吐宜袪寒而不可降寒。盖降火则火引入脾，而流入于大肠，必变为便血之证；降寒则寒引入肾，而流入于膀胱，必变为遗溺之证矣。[103p]

    If there is severe vomiting, one must add a small amount of ginseng and mix it with warm and spicy ingredients to stop the vomiting effectively. Ginseng can be used temporarily, but it should not be taken daily. Excessive vomiting can damage the yin; therefore, using ginseng temporarily to stop the vomiting is acceptable, but if taken daily, it will surely lead to an excess of yang and a deficiency of yin, resulting in dryness in the stomach, which may cause blockage. Hence, ginseng can be used temporarily but should not be taken continuously.

    Vomiting is a condition that arises quickly and is a minor ailment. However, if the stomach is tilted and vomits, it will inevitably harm the stomach qi, and once the stomach qi is damaged, it often leads to severe consequences. The symptoms may be caused by heat or cold; for heat-induced vomiting, one should clear the heat but must not suppress it. For cold-induced vomiting, one should dispel the cold but must not suppress it. Suppressing heat brings the heat into the spleen and flows into the large intestine, which may lead to hematochezia; suppressing cold brings the cold into the kidneys and flows into the bladder, likely resulting in urinary incontinence.[103p]

    我今酌定二方：一治火吐，名清火止吐汤，茯苓一两，人参二钱，砂仁三粒，黄连三钱，水煎服。此方解火退热，则呕吐自止。妙在茯苓分消火势，引火缓行于下，而非峻袪于下也。尤妙人参以扶胃气，则胃土自能克水，不必止吐，吐自定也。况又有砂仁之止呕乎？所以一剂而吐止耳。一治寒吐，名散寒止呕汤，白朮二两，人参五钱，附子、干姜各一钱，丁香三分，水煎服。此方散寒而仍用补脾健土之药，则寒不能上越，而亦不敢下行，势不得不从脐中而外遁也。[104p]

    I have now formulated two remedies:

    The first treats heat-related vomiting, called the Clear Heat and Stop Vomiting Decoction. It consists of one tael of Poria, two qian of Ginseng, three pieces of Sand Ginger, and three qian of Huang Lian, which should be decocted in water and taken orally. This remedy clears heat and reduces fever, thus stopping the vomiting on its own. Its effectiveness lies in Poria's ability to dissipate fire's influence, gently directing the heat downwards rather than forcefully expelling it. Moreover, Ginseng supports the stomach's energy, allowing it to counteract the presence of water naturally, making it unnecessary to deliberately stop the vomiting. Adding Sand Ginger also aids in halting nausea, which is why a single dose is sufficient to stop the vomiting.

    The second treats cold-related vomiting, called the Disperse Cold and Stop Vomiting Decoction. It contains two taels of Bai Zhu, five qian of Ginseng, one qian each of Fu Zi and Gan Jiang, and three fen of Clove, decocted in water and taken orally. This formula disperses cold while still using tonics to strengthen the spleen and support digestion. Thus, the cold cannot rise uncontrollably, and it also cannot descend freely; it must escape from the center and outwards.[104p]

    一剂亦即奏功如响。　　胃吐由于脾虚，脾气不下行，自必上反而吐，补其脾气，则胃气自安。用人参、茯苓各三钱，白朮五钱，甘草、肉桂、神曲、半夏各一钱，砂仁三粒，水煎服。此方乃治脾之药居多，何以用之于胃吐之病反宜也？盖胃为脾之关，关门之沸腾，由于关中之溃乱，然则欲关外安静，必先关内敉宁。方中全用补脾之药，则脾气得全，又何患胃口之吐哉？况方中又有砂仁、半夏、神曲等类，全是止吐之品，有不奏功如神者乎？此又脾胃双治之妙法也。[105p]

    A single dose acts effectively, like a response to a sound. Stomach vomiting is due to spleen deficiency; when spleen energy fails to descend, it naturally rebounds and causes vomiting. By nourishing spleen energy, stomach energy can stabilize. Use three qian of ginseng and poria, five qian of white atracanthus, one qian each of licorice, cinnamon, medicated leaven, and pinellia, along with three seeds of cardamom, and decoct them in water for consumption. This prescription primarily consists of medicines that nourish the spleen, so why is it also suitable for treating stomach vomiting? It is because the stomach is the gateway of the spleen; the turmoil at this gateway arises from chaos within. Therefore, to ensure peace outside the gateway, one must first pacify the chaos inside. The formula exclusively uses spleen-nourishing medicines, thus the spleen energy is fully restored; what concern is there for vomiting from the stomach? Moreover, the formula includes cardamom, pinellia, and medicated leaven, all of which are effective in stopping vomiting. Is there anything that doesn’t work like a miracle? This is indeed a marvelous method that treats both the spleen and stomach.[105p]

    　　　　　吞酸吐酸治法

    　　吞酸，火也；泄泻，寒也。似乎寒热殊而治法宜变。不知吞酸虽热，由于肝气之郁结；泄泻虽寒，由于肝木之克脾。然必一方以治木郁，又一方以培脾土，则土必大崩而木亦大雕矣，不若于一方之中而两治之。方用柴胡、车前子各一钱，陈皮、甘草、神曲各五分，白芍药五钱，茯苓三钱，水煎服，二证皆愈。此方之绝奇，在白芍之妙，盖白芍乃肝经之药，最善舒木气之郁，木郁一舒，上不克胃，下不克脾。[106p]

    Method for Treating Sour Ingestion and Diarrhea

    Ingesting sourness relates to heat; diarrhea relates to cold. It appears that heat and cold are distinctly different, and therefore treatment methods should vary. However, it is not understood that while sour ingestion is heat, it arises from the stagnation of liver qi; and while diarrhea is cold, it stems from the liver wood overcoming the spleen. If one were to treat liver stagnation with one method and nourish the spleen with another, the earth element would collapse and the wood would also deteriorate. It is better to address both issues within a single formula.

    The formula uses Chaihu and Cheqianzi, each for one qian; Chenpi, Gancao, and Shenqu, each for five fen; Bai Shaoyao for five qian; and Fuling for three qian, prepared by decoction and taken. Both conditions will be resolved. The uniqueness of this formula lies in the efficacy of Bai Shaoyao, as it is a medicine for the liver channel and is particularly good at alleviating liver qi stagnation; when the wood is relieved, it no longer overcomes the stomach above nor the spleen below.[106p]

    方中又有车前、茯苓以分消水湿之气，水尽从小便出，何有余水以吞酸，剩汁以泄泻？况又有半夏、神曲之消痰化粕哉。此一治而有分治之功，世人未尽知也。　　肝经之病，两胁胀满，吞酸吐酸等证，乃肝木之郁也。正治之法，方用白芍五钱，柴胡二钱，炒栀子、茯苓、苍朮、半夏、甘草各一钱，神曲五分，丹皮三钱，水煎服。此方之妙，妙在用白芍、丹皮、柴胡也。盖三味乃肝木专经之药，而芍药尤善平肝，不去远凌脾土，土得养而木益舒，木舒而气爽，痛自除，吐渐止也。

    　　半夏汤　一名小茯苓汤。治逆气，心中烦闷，气满，呕吐，气上。　　半夏一升　生姜一斤　茯苓　桂心各五两　　右四味(口父)咀，以水八升，煮取二升半，分三服。若少气加甘草二两。
    　　前胡汤　冶寒热呕逆，少气，心下坚聚彭亨，满不得食，寒热，消渴，补不足。　　前胡　生姜各三两　甘草　(石卜)硝　大黄别浸，各二两　芍药　茯苓　麦门冬　当归　半夏　滑石　石膏　(艹舌)蒌根　黄芩　附子　人参　　右十六味(口父)咀，以水一斗二升，煮取六升，分四服。　　又方　治呕吐，四肢痹冷，短气腹热，三焦不调。　　前胡　芎藭　甘草　当归　石膏　人参　桂心　橘皮各二两　芍药三两　半夏四两　生姜五两　大枣三十枚　　右十二味(口父)咀，以水一斗二升，下黄芩三两，合煮取三升，分三服。一方不用黄芩。[111p]

    Banxia Decoction also known as Xiaofuling Decoction. It treats adverse qi, heart vexation, fullness in the chest, vomiting, and qi rising.
    Ingredients: 1 sheng of Banxia, 1 jin of fresh ginger, 5 liang each of Fuling and Guixin.
    Prepare the above four ingredients by grinding them, using 8 sheng of water, and boiling to yield 2.5 sheng. Divide into three doses. If there is shortness of breath, add 2 liang of licorice.

    Qianhu Decoction treats cold and heat vomiting, shortness of breath, hardness and gathering in the chest, fullness with inability to eat, cold and heat, excessive thirst, and deficiency.
    Ingredients: 3 liang each of Qianhu and fresh ginger, 2 liang each of licorice, sodium sulfate, and rhubarb soaked separately, along with 2 liang each of Shaoyao, Fuling, Maimendong, Danggui, Banxia, Shichao, gypsum, shelled gourd root, Huangqin, Fuzi, and Renjian.
    Prepare the above sixteen ingredients by grinding them, using 12 sheng of water, and boiling to yield 6 sheng. Divide into four doses.

    Another formula treats vomiting, coldness and numbness in the limbs, shortness of breath with abdominal heat, and disharmony in the Sanjiao.
    Ingredients: 2 liang each of Qianhu, Chuanxiong, licorice, Danggui, gypsum, Renjian, Guixin, and orange peel; 3 liang of Shaoyao; 4 liang of Banxia; 5 liang of fresh ginger; and 30 dates.
    Prepare the above twelve ingredients by grinding them, using 12 sheng of water, and adding 3 liang of Huangqin, combine and boil to yield 3 sheng. Divide into three doses. In one formula, Huangqin is not used.[111p]

    　　小麦汤　治呕吐不止。
    　　小麦一升　人参　厚朴各四两　甘草一两　青竹茹二两半　生姜汁三合　茯苓三两　　右七味(口父)咀，以水八升，煮取三升，去滓，分三服。

    Wheat Soup: Treats persistent vomiting.
    One liter of wheat, four taels each of ginseng and magnolia bark, one tael of licorice, two and a half taels of green bamboo pith, three cups of fresh ginger juice, and three taels of Poria. Combine these seven ingredients, chop them finely, add eight liters of water, boil down to three liters, strain, and divide into three doses.

    Zhu Ling Powder: Treats vomiting due to cold in the diaphragm.
    Three taels each of Zhu Ling, Poria, and Atractylodes. Grind these three ingredients, filter, and take a thumb-sized spoonful with water, three times a day. For thirst, drink plenty of water.

    Rhinoceros Horn and Ginseng Decoction: Treats nausea, weakness of stomach qi due to evil, wind-heat, and inability to digest food.
    Two taels each of rhinoceros horn and ginseng, five taels of Chinese leek, and one cup of millet. Combine these four ingredients, chop them, and boil in four and a half liters of water until one and seven-tenths liters remain. Add the millet and cook until it is done, divide into four doses, and after a long interval of seven miles, take another dose.

    Another formula: Treats spring and summer epidemic cold, cold invading the stomach, causing the stomach to cool and become uncomfortable.
    Two taels each of tangerine peel, cinnamon, and kudzu root, and one liter of white grass root. Combine these four ingredients, chop, and boil in six liters of water to yield three liters, divide into three doses, and finish all. If there is heat, omit cinnamon.

    Another formula: Treats vomiting and hiccups.[112p]

    　　人参一两　胡麻仁八合　橘皮去白，一两　枇杷叶八两　　右四味(口父)咀，以水一斗煮枇杷叶，取五升，下药煮取三升，内麻仁，稍饮之。　　又方　治气厥呕哕不得息。
    　　豉一升　半夏八两　生姜二两　人参　前胡　桂心　甘草各一两　　右七味(口父)咀，以水九升，煮取三升，分三服。　　又方　治前证。
    　　大枣十五枚　附子一枚　橘皮二两　豉一升　生姜　甘草各一两　　右六味(口父)咀，以水九升，煎取二升，分三服，日三。
    　　橘皮汤　治干呕哕，若手足厥逆者。　　橘皮四两　生姜半斤
    　　右二味(口父)咀，以水七升，煮取三升，分三服，不止，更合服之。　　又方　治伤寒后哕，干呕不下食。[113p]

    Recipe 1: For treating qi collapse and vomiting, take the following ingredients and prepare as directed:

    • Ginseng: 1 tael
    • Hu ma ren (sesame seeds): 8 jiao
    • Orange peel (remove white part): 1 tael
    • Loquat leaves: 8 taels

    Crush these four ingredients and boil the loquat leaves in 10 liters of water. After obtaining 5 sheng, cook until only 3 sheng remain, add sesame seeds, and drink in small doses.

    Recipe 2: For treating qi collapse.

    • Fermented soybeans: 1 sheng
    • Banxia (pinellia): 8 taels
    • Fresh ginger: 2 taels
    • Ginseng: 1 tael
    • Qianhu (hogfennel): 1 tael
    • Cinnamon heart: 1 tael
    • Licorice: 1 tael

    Crush these seven ingredients and boil in 9 liters of water until reduced to 3 sheng. Divide into three doses.

    Recipe 3: For treating prior conditions.

    • Jujube (dates): 15 pieces
    • Prepared aconite: 1 piece
    • Orange peel: 2 taels
    • Fermented soybeans: 1 sheng
    • Fresh ginger: 1 tael
    • Licorice: 1 tael

    Crush these six ingredients and boil in 9 liters of water until reduced to 2 sheng. Divide into three doses, to be taken three times a day.

    Recipe 4: Orange peel soup for dry vomiting and reverse cold in hands and feet.

    • Orange peel: 4 taels
    • Fresh ginger: 1 jin

    Crush these two ingredients and boil in 7 liters of water until reduced to 3 sheng. Divide into three doses; if symptoms persist, continue to take more.

    Another Recipe: For post-typhoid vomiting and inability to retain food.[113p]

    　　生芦根　青竹茹各一升　粳米三合　生姜二两　　右四味(口父)咀，以水五升，煮取二升，分三服。不止，服三剂。　　又方　治前证。
    　　通草　橘皮各二两　粳米三合　生芦根一升　　右四味(口父)咀，以水四升，煮取一升半，分三服。
    　　露宿圆　治遇冷气，心下结紧，呕逆，寒食不消。又主伤寒，晨夜触寒冷，恶气。　　附子　乌头　桂心　礜石各四两
    　　右四味为末，蜜丸如胡豆大，以酒服三丸，日二，加至十丸。药耐寒冷，忌热食近火，宜冷饮食。
    　　半夏汤　治肺劳虚寒，心腹冷，气逆，游气胸胁，气满，从胸达背痛，嗳气往来，呕逆，饮食即吐，虚乏不足。　　半夏一升　生姜一斤　桂心四两　甘草　厚朴各二两　人参　橘皮　麦冬各三两　　右八味，(口父)咀，以水一斗，煮取四升，分四服。腹痛加当归二两。[114p]

    Sheng Lu Gen (Raw Reed Root) 1 sheng, Qing Zhu Ru (Green Bamboo Shoot) 1 sheng, Jing Mi (Waxy Rice) 3 he, Sheng Jiang (Fresh Ginger) 2 liang.
    These four ingredients should be chewed, then simmered with 5 sheng of water until only 2 sheng remains. Divide into three doses. If symptoms persist, take three doses.

    Another Formula for prior symptoms:
    Tong Cao (Chinese Rice Paper Plant) 2 liang, Ji Pi (Orange Peel) 2 liang, Jing Mi 3 he, Sheng Lu Gen 1 sheng.
    These four ingredients should be chewed, then simmered with 4 sheng of water until only 1.5 sheng remains. Divide into three doses.

    Lu Su Yuan (Exposure to Dew) addresses exposure to cold air, tightness in the chest, nausea, and inability to digest cold food. It is also effective for typhoid fever, caused by exposure to cold in the morning and at night, and aversion to cold.
    Fu Zi (Aconite), Wu Tou (Aconite), Gui Xin (Cinnamon Heart), Peng Shi (PK Stone) each 4 liang.
    Grind these four ingredients into a powder, form into pills the size of a yellow bean, and take three pills with wine, twice a day, increasing to ten pills. The medicine is effective against cold, avoid hot foods and proximity to fire, and prefer cold food and drink.

    Ban Xia Tang (Pinellia Decoction) treats lung deficiency with cold, coldness in the heart and abdomen, reversed Qi, distended sensation from the chest to the back, intermittent nausea, vomiting immediately after eating, and deficiency signs.
    Ban Xia (Pinellia) 1 sheng, Sheng Jiang 1 jin, Gui Xin 4 liang, Gan Cao (Licorice), Hou Po (Magnolia Bark) each 2 liang, Ren Shen (Ginseng), Ji Pi 3 liang, Mai Dong (Ophiopogon) 3 liang.
    These eight ingredients should be chewed, then simmered with 10 dou of water until 4 sheng remains. Divide into four doses. For abdominal pain, add 2 liang of Dang Gui (Angelica).[114p]

    　　建中汤　治五劳七伤，小腹急痛，膀胱虚满，手足逆冷，食饮苦吐酸痰，吐泄少气，目眩耳聋口焦，小便自利。　　胶饴半斤　黄芪　干姜　当归各三两　人参　半夏　橘皮　芍药　甘草各二两　附子一两　大枣十五枚　　右十一味(口父)咀，以水一斗，煮取三升半，汤成，下胶饴烊沸，分四服。深师有桂心六两，生姜一斤，无橘皮、干姜。
    　　厚朴汤　治上焦闭塞，干呕，呕而不出，热少冷多，好吐白沫，清涎吞酸。　　厚朴　茯苓　芎藭　白朮　元参各四两　桔梗　附子　人参　橘皮各三两　生姜八两　吴茱萸八合　　右十一味(口父)咀，以水二斗，煮取五升，分为五服。

    Jianzhong Decoction treats the five labors and seven injuries, acute pain in the lower abdomen, a feeling of fullness in the bladder, coldness in the hands and feet, bitter vomiting, sour phlegm, little breath, dizziness, deafness, and a dry mouth. Urination is spontaneous. Ingredients: half a pound of cow's syrup, three taels each of astragalus, dried ginger, and angelica, two taels each of ginseng, pinellia, tangerine peel, peony, and licorice, one tael of aconite, and fifteen dates. These eleven ingredients should be crushed, boiled in one斗 of water (approximately 10 liters) to obtain three and a half sheng (approximately 700 ml) of decoction. After preparing the decoction, dissolve the cow's syrup in it while boiling, divide into four doses. If the practitioner feels deep, use six taels of cinnamon heart and one pound of fresh ginger, omitting tangerine peel and dried ginger.

    Houpǔ Decoction treats obstruction in the upper burner, dry retching, vomiting without expulsion, more cold than heat, a tendency to spit white foam, and swallowing clear saliva that is sour. Ingredients: four taels each of magnolia bark, poria, chuanxiong, white atractylodes, and scrophularia; three taels each of platycodon, aconite, ginseng, and tangerine peel; eight taels of fresh ginger; and eight jiao of evodia. These eleven ingredients should be crushed, boiled in two斗 of water to yield five sheng (approximately 1 liter), and divided into five doses.

    Stop Vomiting Ginseng Decoction treats heat in the lower burner, reversed qi that does not stop, and uncontrollable vomiting, known as "running and feeding." Ingredients: three taels each of ginseng, licorice, scutellaria, and anemarrhena; four taels each of raw reed root, gardenia seed, and fried white atractylodes; four taels of tangerine peel; and eight taels of gypsum. These ten ingredients should be crushed, boiled in nine sheng (approximately 1.5 liters) of water to obtain three sheng (approximately 600 ml) of decoction, strain out the residues, and divide into three doses.[115p]

    Zhu Yu Decoction (by Zhang Zhongjing)
    Used to treat vomiting and chest fullness.

    • Wu Yu: 1 sheng
    • Ren Shen: 3 liang
    • Sheng Jiang: 6 liang
    • Da Zao: 12 pieces

    Combine these four ingredients, add 5 sheng of water, boil down to 3 sheng. Take 7 he in warm form, three times a day.

    Si Ni Decoction
    Used to treat vomiting with weak pulse, frequent urination, and mild fever. Difficult to treat if there are signs of cold limb.

    • Fu Zi: 1 piece, raw
    • Gan Jiang: 1.5 liang
    • Gan Cao: 2 liang, roasted

    Combine these three ingredients, add 3 sheng of water, boil down to 1 sheng and 2 he, discard the residue, and take warm in two portions. Strong individuals may use 1 piece of large Fu Zi and 3 liang of Gan Jiang.

    Fu Zi and Jun Rice Decoction
    Used to treat cold qi in the abdomen, sharp pain like thunder, fullness in the chest and ribs, and vomiting.

    • Fu Zi: 1 piece, processed
    • Ban Xia: 0.5 sheng
    • Jun Rice: 0.5 sheng
    • Gan Cao: 1 liang
    • Da Zao: 10 pieces

    Combine these five ingredients, add 8 sheng of water, cook until the rice is done, remove the residue, and take 1 sheng warm, three times a day.

    Wu Ling Powder
    Used to treat lean individuals with palpitation below the navel, vomiting saliva, and dizziness.

    • Ze Xie: 2.1 fen
    • Zhu Ling: 3 fen
    • Fu Ling: 3 fen
    • Bai Zhu: 3 fen
    • Gui: 2 fen, peeled

    Grind these five ingredients into powder, take with white drink, using a spoonful three times a day. Drink plenty of warm water; sweating will help recovery.[116p]

    Dabanxia Decoction: For treating vomiting due to stomach reflux.
    Ingredients: 2 sheng of Banxia (Pinellia), 3 liang of Ren Shen (ginseng), 1 sheng of honey.
    Preparation: Combine the three ingredients with 12 liters of water, mix the honey evenly 240 times, boil the herbs, and take 2.5 sheng. Warm and consume 1.5 sheng, dividing into two doses.

    Dahuang Gancao Decoction: For treating vomiting that occurs shortly after eating.
    Ingredients: 4 liang of Dahuang (rhubarb), 1 liang of Gancao (licorice).
    Preparation: Combine the two ingredients with 3 sheng of water, boil to extract 1 sheng, and take it warm in two doses.

    Fuling Zexie Decoction: For treating vomiting with thirst and a desire to drink water.
    Ingredients: 0.5 jin of Fuling (Poria), 3 liang of Baizhu (white atractylodes), 4 liang each of Zexie (alisma), Sheng Jiang (ginger), 2 liang each of Gancao (licorice) and Guizhi (cinnamon twig).
    Preparation: Combine the six ingredients with 10 liters of water, boil to extract 3 sheng, then add Zexie and boil again to extract 2.5 sheng. Take 8 he (he is a unit of volume) warm, three times a day.

    Banxia Ganjiang Powder: For treating dry vomiting and regurgitation of foam.
    Ingredients: Equal parts of Banxia (Pinellia) and Ganjiang (dried ginger).
    Preparation: Grind the two ingredients into a powder, take one tablespoon mixed with 1.5 sheng of water, boil to get 7 he, and take it all at once.

    Ju Pi Zhu Ru Decoction: For treating hiccups and reflux.
    Ingredients: 1 jin of Ju Pi (tangerine peel), 0.5 jin of Sheng Jiang (ginger), 2 sheng of Zhu Ru (bamboo shavings), 5 liang of Gancao (licorice), 30 pieces of Da Zao (dates), and 1 liang of Ren Shen (ginseng).
    Preparation: Combine the six ingredients with 10 liters of water, boil to extract 3 sheng, and take 1 sheng warm, three times a day.[118p]

    　　甘草粉蜜汤　治吐蛔。
    　　甘草二两　粉一两　蜜四两
    　　右三味，以水三升，先煮甘草取二升，去滓，内粉蜜，搅令和，煎如薄粥，温服一升，差即止。
    　　乌梅圆　治蛔厥吐蛔。
    　　乌梅三百个　细辛　附子炮　桂枝　人参　黄蘗各六两　干姜十两　黄连一斤　当归　川椒去汗，各四两　　右十味，异捣筛，合治之，以苦酒浸乌梅一宿，去核蒸之，五升米作饭，熟捣成泥，和药，令相得，内臼中，与蜜杵二千下，丸如梧子大。先食饮服十丸，日三服，稍加至二十丸。禁生冷滑臭等物。
    　　养胃丹 【《中藏经》】 　治脾胃不和，全不思食，中脘停寒，呕逆恶心，脏寒泄利，腹痛肠鸣。常服温中养胃散，即思食。　　丁香一两半　人参三分　甘草炙　白豆蔻仁　半夏曲各半两　干姜三两，炮。干生姜尤佳　　右同为细末，炼蜜为丸，每两作十丸。每服一丸，温汤化下，空心食前服之。或细嚼汤下，亦可。[119p]

    Gancao Powder Honey Decoction: Used to treat vomiting from roundworms.

    • 2 taels of licorice, 1 tael of powder, 4 taels of honey.
    • Combine these three ingredients, using 3 sheng of water. First, boil the licorice to obtain 2 sheng, strain out the residue, then add the powder and honey, mixing well. Cook until it is like a thin porridge, and take 1 sheng warm; it will stop the vomiting.

    Wumei Pill: Used to treat roundworm convulsions and vomiting.

    • 300 grams of black plum, 6 taels each of asarum, fried aconite, cinnamon twig, ginseng, and yellow bristle grass; 10 taels of dried ginger; 1 jin of coptis; 4 taels each of danggui and Sichuan pepper (sweat removed).
    • Grind and sift these ten ingredients separately, then combine. Soak the black plum in bitter wine overnight, remove the pits and steam. Use 5 sheng of rice to make congee, then mash into a paste and mix with the medicine until well combined. In a mortar, knead with 2,000 grains of honey, forming pills the size of a walnut. Take 10 pills before meals, three times a day, gradually increasing to 20 pills. Avoid raw, cold, slippery, and foul-smelling foods.

    Yangwei Pill (from the "Zhongzang Jing"): Used for spleen and stomach disharmony, loss of appetite, cold in the middle, nausea and vomiting, cold dirt diarrhea, abdominal pain and intestinal noises. Regular use of the warming and stomach-nourishing powder will stimulate appetite.

    • 1.5 taels of clove, 0.3 taels of ginseng, roasted licorice, white cardamom seeds, and half summer, each half tael; 3 taels of dried ginger, fried.
    • Grind these together into a fine powder, then mix with honey to form pills, making 10 pills per 2 taels. Take 1 pill with warm water on an empty stomach before meals, or chew well and swallow with soup, also acceptable.[119p]

    Dingxiang Zhuyutang
    Treats stomach deficiency, nausea, vomiting, and obstruction in the throat.
    Dried ginger and Huangbo, each 2 fen; Dingxiang, roasted licorice, Chaihu, orange peel, and Banxia, each 5 fen; Shengma, 7 fen; Wuzhuyu, Caodoukou, Huangqi, and Renren, each 1 qian; Cangyou, 2 qian; Danggui, 1 qian and 5 fen.
    The above ingredients should be ground to the size of a soybean. For each dose, take half a tael, with 2 bowls of water, decoct until reduced to 1 bowl, remove the sediment, and take warm before meals. Avoid cold substances.

    Baizhu Tang
    Also known as Fuling Banxia Tang. Treats weak stomach qi, heaviness in the body with phlegm, and nausea with the urge to vomit due to wind evils obstructing the spleen and stomach. First, strengthen the spleen and stomach.
    Fried Sheniuq, 2 qian; Chenpi and Tianma, each 3 qian; Baizhu, Baifuling, malt (fried yellow), and Banxia, each 5 qian.
    The above, ground finely. For each dose, take 5 qian, with 2 bowls of water, add 5 slices of fresh ginger, and decoct until reduced to 1 bowl, remove the sediment, and take warm.[120p]

    　　补肝汤　一名柴胡半夏汤。治素有风证，不敢见风，眼濇头痛，眼黑，胸中有痰，恶心兀兀欲吐，遇风便觉皮肉紧，手足难举重物。如居暖室，少出微汗，其证乃减，再或遇风即复。　　柴胡　升麻　槁本各五分　白茯苓七分　炒神曲　苍朮各一钱　半夏二钱　生姜十片　　右为粗末，都作一服，水一大盏，煎至半盏，去柤，稍热服。

    Buhgan Decoction, also known as Chaihu Banxia Decoction. It treats those with a chronic wind syndrome, who are afraid of the wind, have dry eyes and headaches, dark vision, phlegm in the chest, nausea with a strong urge to vomit, and tightness of the skin and flesh upon encountering wind, making it difficult to lift heavy objects with hands and feet. If one stays in a warm room and sweats slightly, the symptoms will reduce; however, encountering wind causes a recurrence.

    Ingredients:

    • Chaihu: 5 grams
    • Shengma: 5 grams
    • Jiao Ben: 5 grams
    • Baizhu (White Atractylodes): 7 grams
    • Fried Shenqu: 10 grams
    • Cangzhu: 10 grams
    • Banxia: 20 grams
    • Fresh Ginger: 10 slices

    Prepare as a coarse powder, make into one dose, add to a large cup of water, decoct until reduced to half a cup, strain, and take while warm.

    Zaojiao Huatan Pill: Treats labor wind, stagnation of heart and spleen, excessive phlegm and saliva, difficulty in the throat, thick and sticky nasal discharge, blockage causing nausea, lack of appetite, and occasional dizziness.

    Ingredients:

    • Zaojiao wood (white skin, roasted): 1 liang
    • Bai Fuzhi (white precursors): 1 liang, roasted
    • Banxia prepared with water: washed 7 times
    • Nanking Down: 1 liang, roasted
    • Shenghuo (white alum): 1 liang, dried
    • Red Reishi (peeled): 1 liang
    • Ren Shen (ginseng): 1 liang
    • Zhiqiao (bitter orange): 2 liang, roasted

    Prepare as a fine powder, mix with fresh ginger juice into a paste, and form into pills the size of a wutong seed. Each dose is 30 pills, taken with warm water after meals.

    Shang Er Huang Pill: Treats injury from heat and food, fullness and discomfort, strong urge to vomit, restlessness, and unease.

    Ingredients:

    • Huangqin (Scutellaria): 2 liang
    • Huanglian (Coptis): marinated in wine, 1 liang
    • Gan Cao (Licorice): 2 grams
    • Shengma: 3 grams
    • Chaihu: 3 grams

    Prepare as an extremely fine powder, mix with soup to form pills the size of mung beans. Each dose is 50-70 pills, taken with clear soup according to the extent of injury. An alternate recipe adds 5 grams of fried Zhi Shi (bitter orange) to reduce the quantity of fiber.[121p]
